Article_Name: 2017年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2017 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2017. Although no official timeframe was set for this typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to the waters of the Pacific Ocean and the South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2017 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) with international names and are assigned international numbers starting with 17xx. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter "W." Tropical depressions that enter or form within the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) are given local names by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (with the international name being the official one). Additionally, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau may differ from those used in Taiwan. The information for each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak intensity during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

The Hong Kong Observatory (HKO) reported the latest developments of the observatory on March 23, 2017, indicating that 2016-2017 was one of the warmest winters on record since 1884. The observatory predicted that the annual rainfall would be normal to below normal, with four to seven tropical cyclones entering within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong, a number close to the normal level. However, during June to August of that year, four consecutive storms directly hit Hong Kong, prompting the observatory to issue tropical cyclone warning signals of No. 8 or above, far exceeding expectations. As a result, the observatory revised its forecast in late August to six to nine tropical cyclones, reaching the normal level.

Liu Yingwei, Senior Technical Advisor for Meteorology at the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau (Portuguese: SMG), stated during the tropical cyclone prevention meeting held by the government’s civil defense structure on April 5 that it is expected that 5 to 7 tropical cyclones will affect Macao this year, with the first and last tropical cyclones anticipated to appear in mid-June and late September, respectively. This year, 5 to 7 tropical cyclones are expected to affect Macao, and all agencies and departments within the civil defense structure must remain vigilant and carry out prevention and publicity work.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (CWB) presented the 2017 weather outlook and risk assessment at the 3531st Executive Yuan meeting on January 12, predicting that 3 to 4 typhoons would hit Taiwan during the summer, and the formation of the first typhoon in the Northwest Pacific would occur earlier than the previous year. On June 26, the Central Weather Bureau held a typhoon outlook press conference, forecasting that 3 to 5 typhoons would hit Taiwan during the summer, with the climate average being 3.6. The total number of typhoons forming in the western North Pacific was estimated to be about 21 to 25, close to the climate average of 23.1. Lu Guochen, director of the Weather Forecast Center, stated that the climate this year is normal, with a low likelihood of El Niño or La Niña events. Therefore, the formation and impact of typhoons this year are also expected to be normal. Regarding the intensity of typhoons hitting Taiwan, he mentioned that there is a 70% to 80% chance of them being of moderate typhoon strength or above, and the possibility of autumn typhoons cannot be ruled out, reminding the public to prepare for typhoon prevention.

The China National Marine Forecast Center predicted that 11 to 13 typhoons in the Northwest Pacific and South China Sea would affect China's seas in 2017, with 6 to 7 typhoons making landfall on China's southeastern coast. [11] Additionally, according to the Fujian Meteorological Bureau's forecast on April 11, 6 to 7 tropical cyclones would affect Fujian Province during the typhoon season (June to September), with 1 to 2 typhoons possibly making landfall or severely impacting Fujian Province in the summer. [12]
The Philippine PAGASA predicts that 8-12 tropical cyclones will enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility from April to September this year.

The Vietnam Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center predicts that ENSO will transition to El Niño in the second half of this year. The typhoon season will become increasingly evident in the latter half of the year, with an estimated 13-15 storms entering the South China Sea, of which about 3-4 are expected to directly or indirectly affect Vietnam.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content:
PAGASA: Dante  
In mid to late April 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Chuuk near the equator. Although this low-pressure area formed over the open ocean, its center was initially very disorganized. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W at 9 a.m. on the 20th of the same month, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 8 a.m. on the 21st. With the assistance of high atmospheric pressure, low wind shear, and relatively high sea temperatures, the low-pressure area began to consolidate, and its structure became more organized. Major weather agencies predicted its movement path to be west-northwest, with some agencies optimistic about its development and intensity, while others were less so.  

The Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded it to a tropical depression at 8 p.m. on the 23rd, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center subsequently raised its rating to "medium" at 4 a.m. on the 24th, then to "high" at 1 p.m. the same day. Benefiting from favorable environmental conditions nearby, the low-pressure area continued to develop, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression at 2 a.m. on April 25, assigning it the number 03W. The Japan Meteorological Agency also issued a gale warning for Tropical Depression 03W at 8 a.m. on the same day.  

As Tropical Depression 03W rapidly developed and intensified, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm at 2 a.m. on April 26, followed by the Japan Meteorological Agency at 8 a.m., which also upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 1701 and naming the tropical cyclone "Muifa." It became the first named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season.  

Although the tropical storm was named, major weather agencies were not optimistic about its subsequent intensity development and predicted it would change direction, shifting from west-northwest to north and then to east-northeast, due to the influence of an eastward-moving westerly trough. As expected, "Muifa" moved along the weak point of the subtropical ridge southeast of Japan, gradually moving toward the westerly trough and slowly weakening.  

As "Muifa" weakened, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression at 8:50 p.m. on April 27, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning at 5 a.m. the next day. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 8 p.m. on the 29th. Finally, "Muifa" dissipated over the open ocean east of the Philippines, with some of its cloud systems merging into an extratropical cyclone.

Merbok was the second named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 04W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, and was also the first tropical cyclone to affect the South China region that year. After the formation of Muifa in April, the Northwest Pacific remained calm throughout May until a low-pressure area formed in central Philippines in June. It intensified into a severe tropical storm, named Merbok, crossed the South China Sea towards eastern Guangdong, and eventually moved inland and gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Emong, also known as Nanmadol, was the third named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 05W. Initially identified as disturbance 98W, it was later reclassified as 99W. It moved northwestward from the waters east of the Philippines to the waters east of Taiwan, gradually intensifying into a severe tropical storm before turning northeastward. Its first landfall was in Nagasaki City, Nagasaki Prefecture, Japan; the second landfall was in Uwajima City, Ehime Prefecture; and the third landfall was in Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture. Eventually, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Talas was the fourth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 06W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Talas originated from a monsoon depression, and initially, some weather agencies predicted it would merge with a tropical disturbance near the Philippines and strike the Pearl River Delta. However, it eventually developed independently and intensified into a severe tropical storm. It made landfall in Vietnam's Nghe An Province at 2:10 a.m. on July 17. After landfall, its intensity rapidly weakened due to the frictional effects of the terrain and dissipated on July 18. Although it had dissipated, the trailing airflow brought heavy rain to the northern South China Sea and the coastal areas of South China.

Oma was the fifth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 07W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of the 19th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Oma to a tropical depression when it was over the sea 2,000 kilometers southeast of Japan. Six hours later, authorities issued a gale warning, and on the morning of the 21st, it was upgraded to a tropical storm, given the international designation 1705, and named Oma. On the afternoon of the 23rd, it began to be influenced by Tropical Storm Rose and took a southeastward path, while also rapidly intensifying. Between the 25th and 27th, it gradually absorbed Rose and resumed a westward path, with its intensity significantly decreasing. On the evening of the 27th, it shifted to a southwestward movement, approaching the Ogasawara Islands. From the night of the 30th to the 31st, it rapidly intensified again to reach the strength of a Category 5 hurricane. It weakened to a typhoon on August 5 and made landfall on Yakushima, Japan. On the morning of August 8, although its structure had already become loose, it still affected northern Japan. In the Joint Typhoon Warning Center's best track data, Oma's maximum wind speed was downgraded from 140 knots (equivalent to a Category 5 hurricane) to 135 knots (equivalent to a Category 4 hurricane).

Rose was the sixth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 09W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. As Mawar intensified, a baroclinic system west of the International Date Line gradually transformed into a low-pressure area on the morning of the 19th, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 97W at 9 a.m. The low-level circulation center of this low-pressure area was partially exposed to the west due to dry air intrusion and vertical wind shear, but its eastern outflow channel continued to improve, and the warm sea surface provided sufficient energy. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded this low-pressure area to a tropical depression at 2 a.m. on the 20th, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" three hours later (at 5 a.m.). 

In the afternoon, its deep convection gradually filled the previously exposed eastern side of the low-level circulation center, organizing a broader low-level circulation center. Its extratropical cyclone characteristics also gradually weakened. Additionally, as the system was located beneath a strong upper-level low-pressure area, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium" at 2 p.m. and classified the system as a subtropical depression. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning at 3:30 p.m., indicating the possibility of intensifying into a tropical storm within a day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system to a subtropical storm at 8 a.m. on the 21st, then raised its rating to "high" at 1:30 p.m. and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency officially upgraded the tropical depression to a tropical storm at 3:15 p.m., naming it Rose and assigning it the international number 1706. The China Meteorological Administration followed suit at 3:48 p.m. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center subsequently announced at 5 p.m. that the system had transitioned into a tropical storm, designating it as Tropical Cyclone 09W.

Initially influenced by a deep subtropical ridge, Rose moved northward. On the morning of the 22nd, it shifted westward, approaching Tropical Cyclone Mawar, and developed a "pinhole eye" in the afternoon. In the evening, Rose moved into cooler waters, and its subtropical characteristics re-emerged. Temperature scanning systems indicated that Rose developed partial cold-core structures, suggesting it was a "hybrid system." Its low-level circulation center was once again exposed, with upper-level convection dissipating, though low-level clouds continued to spiral into the center. By the 24th, it formed a central dense overcast area. On the 25th, Rose began interacting with Mawar, and Mawar's outflow caused strong vertical wind shear on Rose, leading to significant weakening. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Rose to a tropical depression at 5 p.m. and 9 p.m., respectively, with the latter issuing its final warning at 11 a.m. on the 26th. Rose rotated counterclockwise around Mawar and was fully absorbed into Mawar's circulation by midnight on the 28th.

PAGASA: Fabian Lock is the seventh named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 10W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Following the appearances of Nesat and Roke, another disturbance emerged over the waters southeast of Eluanbi. On July 21 at 12:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Lock to a tropical depression. On the afternoon of the 22nd at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and subsequently named it Lock. It then continued moving northwest toward the South China Sea and made landfall near the Sai Kung East Country Park in Hong Kong. As it passed over Shenzhen, it rapidly weakened due to terrain disruption.

Sanka was the eighth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 08W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Shortly after Talas dissipated, a low-pressure area formed in the central Philippine Sea on July 19, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. Initially, major agencies believed Sanka would develop further, with a chance of making landfall near the Pearl River Estuary. However, predictions later changed, forecasting it to move toward Hainan Island as a tropical depression. Initially, it had strong convection, but after entering the southern South China Sea, its intensity began to weaken due to high wind shear and low sea temperatures. However, as it moved to the central South China Sea, it strengthened again, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression at 11 a.m. on July 21. Although it redeveloped, its intensity did not significantly increase and it lingered near the waters off Hainan Island, even exhibiting a slight Fujiwhara effect with Roke. After Roke moved inland into Shenzhen, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Sanka at 3 p.m. on July 23. Subsequently, it made landfall in Quang Binh Province, Vietnam, at 4:30 p.m. on July 25. By 8 p.m., as it moved further into Laos, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression due to land friction.

PAGASA: Gorio Nesat is the ninth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 11W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Nesat to a tropical depression at 3 PM on the 25th and issued a gale warning six hours later. At 11 AM on the 26th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. On the morning of the 28th, various agencies adjusted its path westward, indicating it would head directly toward Taiwan. At 7:10 PM on the 29th, it made landfall in Su'ao Township, Yilan County, Taiwan, and at 10:30 PM the same evening, it exited via Zhunan Township, Miaoli County, entering the Taiwan Strait. On the morning of the 30th, it made landfall in Fuqing City, Fuzhou, Fujian, weakened into a severe tropical storm, and continued to weaken on the same day.

PAGASA: Huaning (Nesat) is the 10th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 12W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On July 26 at 4 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned disturbance number 92W to a low-pressure area that formed northeast of the Paracel Islands. The next day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Nesat to a tropical depression at 2 p.m. On July 28, as its structure gradually improved, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert at 5 a.m., subsequently upgrading it to a tropical depression at 3 p.m. and assigning it the tropical cyclone number 12W. The following day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. On the afternoon of July 30 at 4:30 p.m., it made landfall in Fenggang, Fangshan, Pingtung, Taiwan, and exited to sea from Fangyuan, Changhua, at 12:30 a.m. on July 31. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a remnant low.

Nesat was the eleventh named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 13W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of August 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. It weakened and dissipated on August 6.

The banyan tree was the twelfth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 14W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The banyan tree formed on August 10 in the northwest Pacific, moved northwest, and gradually strengthened. It began to weaken on the evening of the 15th and dissipated on August 17.

PAGASA: Typhoon Hato was the 13th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 15W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Hato formed on the afternoon of August 20, with the Japan Meteorological Agency assigning it the international designation 1713. Benefiting from the favorable environment of the Luzon Strait and the South China Sea, along with reduced vertical wind shear and warm sea waters that stored energy for nearly a month, it began to intensify rapidly. At this time, satellite imagery revealed the gradual development of an eye structure at its center. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded its intensity from the upper limit of a tropical storm to the upper limit of a severe tropical storm at 2:50 PM, and further upgraded it to a typhoon at 11:40 PM. That night, it slowed down again before resuming a steady west-northwest path by early morning on the 23rd, heading directly toward the area west of the Pearl River Estuary. At noon on the 23rd, it passed over the waters near the Pearl River Estuary and made landfall south of Zhuhai, Guangdong, at 12:50 PM, gradually weakening thereafter. Supported by an active southwest monsoon, its weakening slowed as it crossed the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region on the 24th. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression only at 2:40 PM.

PAGASA: Jolina Paka was the 14th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 16W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On August 23, Paka formed as a tropical depression over the waters east of the Philippines, with the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigning it the disturbance number 96W. On August 24, it continued to develop with a well-organized structure. At 8 PM, the China Meteorological Administration first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 AM on the 25th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Paka, assigning it the international number 1714. On the evening of the 25th, it crossed central Luzon, where its intensity temporarily weakened due to the terrain of Luzon, before entering the central South China Sea the following morning. After entering the South China Sea, its movement speed significantly increased, moving northwestward at approximately 30 kilometers per hour, heading directly toward the area west of the Pearl River Estuary, and re-strengthening. Paka made landfall along the southeastern coast of Taishan, Guangdong, around 9 AM. It subsequently weakened into a tropical storm, moved into the inland area of Guangxi by the evening, and dissipated on the 28th.

Coral was the 15th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 17W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On August 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Coral to a tropical storm. On August 30, various meteorological agencies upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On August 31, it was gradually upgraded to a typhoon by various meteorological agencies. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Mawar was the sixteenth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 18W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the afternoon of August 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Mawar to a tropical depression. At 3 a.m. on September 1, it was upgraded to a tropical storm. It dissipated on September 4.

PAGASA: Kiko was the 17th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 19W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of September 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Kiko to a tropical depression. On September 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it back to a tropical depression. On September 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency indicated in the weather map that it had merged into a frontal system.

PAGASA: Lannie Talim is the 18th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 20W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On September 9, it was confirmed by the Japan Meteorological Agency to have intensified into Talim. At 2 a.m. on September 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 9 a.m. on the same day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 15, it began to weaken. On September 18, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Maring Doksuri was the 19th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 21W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. At 3 a.m. on September 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Doksuri to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning six hours later. On September 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to Tropical Depression 21W. That evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, naming it Doksuri and assigning it the international designation 1719. After being named, it began to intensify. On the afternoon of September 15, it made landfall in Vietnam and quickly weakened, completely dissipating by September 16.

PAGASA: Odette Kanu was the 20th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 24W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. At 12:40 AM on October 13, Kanu made landfall in Santa Ana, Cagayan, Philippines, shortly after which it moved out to sea, continuing towards the coast of mainland China and intensifying. On October 15, it made landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula and weakened. On October 16, it lingered in the Gulf of Tonkin, soon weakening into a tropical depression, and completely dissipated the following day.

PAGASA: Paolo Lan is the 21st named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 25W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and classified as a "super large" typhoon by the Japan Meteorological Agency. Influenced by a strong subtropical high-pressure ridge, there was a lull in the typhoon season in the Northwest Pacific from late September to early October, until the subtropical high-pressure ridge shifted northward, allowing tropical disturbances to redevelop in the Northwest Pacific. On October 11, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned disturbance number 91W to a low-pressure system near the Chuuk Islands. The combination of warm sea temperatures and weak wind shear facilitated the intensification of this disturbance. On October 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to Tropical Depression 25W, and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm the next day, naming it, with meteorological agencies subsequently upgrading its status. On October 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On the morning of October 20, Lan's cloud-wrapped eye expanded into a large eye, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center indicated that Lan had entered a rapid intensification phase. On the afternoon of October 20, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded Lan to a severe typhoon. At 2 a.m. on October 21, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded Lan to a super typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon at 8 a.m. On October 22 at 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded Lan to a moderate typhoon. At 3 a.m. on October 23, it made landfall in Kakegawa City, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded Lan to a mild typhoon, and at 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Lan's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center increased from 95 knots (175 km/h) to 100 knots (185 km/h), and the central minimum pressure lowered from 925 hPa to 915 hPa.

PAGASA: Quedan (Saola) was the 22nd named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 27W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The Japan Meteorological Agency analyzed it as a low-pressure area at 9:00 AM on the 19th and as a tropical disturbance at 3:00 PM on the same day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert at 5:30 AM on October 19, designating it as Tropical Depression 27W, and later upgraded it to a tropical storm. On the evening of October 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:25 AM on October 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. On October 24, it was upgraded to a tropical storm and named Saola. At 12:50 PM on October 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Ramil (Damrey) was the 23rd named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 28W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
At 9 a.m. on October 31, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the same day, at 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. On November 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Damrey. On the evening of November 2, various agencies upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At noon on November 3, various agencies upgraded it to a typhoon. On the morning of November 4, it made landfall in Vietnam and gradually weakened. At 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Salome, Hai Kui is the 24th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 30W. The Japan Meteorological Agency marked it as a tropical depression on the weather map at 8 a.m. on the 9th. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the designation Tropical Depression 30W. It was expected to gradually strengthen after entering the South China Sea and move towards the Hainan Island area. On the same day at 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the designation 1724 and naming it Hai Kui. On November 12 at 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression and considered it to have completely dissipated a day later.

PAGASA: Tino (Haikui) is the 25th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 31W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. This tropical depression entered the South China Sea and gradually intensified. On November 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Haikui, with the designation 1725. It entered the central South China Sea in the afternoon of the 18th. At 3 a.m. on November 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Haikui to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Urduja, also known as Kai-Tak, was the 26th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 32W. Kai-Tak formed on December 12. It then crossed the central Philippine islands and southwestern Palawan Island.  
On December 19, it moved west-southwest across the southern South China Sea, heading toward the southern Malay Peninsula and Singapore area. On the morning of December 22, at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Kai-Tak to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Vinta (Tembin) is the 27th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 33W. On December 21, Tembin rapidly intensified into a severe tropical storm. Initially moving southwestward, it later shifted to a westward direction and made landfall on Mindanao Island in the Philippines in the evening. On December 22, it weakened into a tropical storm due to the influence of land terrain and crossed Mindanao Island to reach the Sulu Sea in the evening, moving westward toward Palawan Island and the South China Sea. On the evening of December 23, as its center passed near the southwestern coast of Palawan Island, it absorbed moisture and heat from the Sulu Sea, causing its cloud system to expand, deep convection to intensify, and the development of an eye-like feature. On December 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Tembin to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Agaton Bolaven is a tropical cyclone that spanned two years (2017 Pacific typhoon season to 2018 Pacific typhoon season). Its original low-pressure area formed on December 21, 2017, south of the Marshall Islands at low latitudes, and was assigned the disturbance number 98W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. However, the designation was later removed due to unfavorable development conditions. The low-pressure area redeveloped on December 28, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the disturbance number 99W. On December 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency marked this system as a tropical depression on its weather map. Subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 01W on January 2, 2018, and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm on January 3, naming it Bolaven. Bolaven thus became the first tropical cyclone of 2018 and was also the third earliest recorded storm in the Northwest Pacific to form and be named. However, upon entering the South China Sea, its development was hindered by lower sea temperatures, and the system eventually dissipated in the central South China Sea.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones assessed as tropical storms or tropical depressions by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, but only classified as tropical depressions by the Japan Meteorological Agency.

PAGASA: Auring, disturbance number 96W by the US Naval Research Laboratory, was designated as Tropical Depression 01W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
On January 7, 2017, a low-pressure area formed east of the Philippines and developed into the first tropical cyclone of 2017 the following day, receiving the designation 01W from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Computer numerical forecast models accurately predicted it would pass over the Philippines and enter the South China Sea, though there was an error in intensity prediction as it lingered over the Philippines, cut off from moisture supply, and weakened into a low-pressure area. However, after entering the South China Sea, it was able to rebuild its cloud bands, but vertical wind shear caused its intensity to fluctuate between a low-pressure area and a tropical depression. Subsequently, the northeast monsoon brought dry air, causing it to weaken significantly. It then made landfall in Vietnam and quickly moved out to sea but failed to reorganize, eventually dissipating near the Gulf of Thailand.

PAGASA: Bising U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 98W → 99W.  
On January 31, 2017, a low-pressure area formed in the waters east of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it disturbance number 98W. At that time, it was guided by the equatorial anticyclone and influenced by the northeast monsoon, developing slowly. However, under conditions of weak vertical wind shear, warm sea temperatures, and good upper-level divergence, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 2 PM on February 2, and upgraded it to "medium" at 2 PM the following day. Due to its convection becoming active, the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded it to a tropical depression and immediately issued a gale warning, indicating it would strengthen into a tropical storm within a day. However, on the 5th, vertical wind shear in the area significantly increased, exposing its low-level circulation center and dissipating its convection. The Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning at 8 AM, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating back to "low" at 2 PM that afternoon, further canceling the rating at 2 PM on the 6th. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory also canceled its disturbance number. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency maintained its classification as a tropical depression, predicting it would remain stationary. As the northeast monsoon weakened, it became more favorable for it to absorb sea energy and gradually repair its low-level circulation center. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it a new disturbance number, 99W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as "low" at 2 PM on the 7th. Affected by an extratropical cyclone, it gradually weakened, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating again at 2 PM on the 8th. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 8 AM.

U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 91W.  
On the afternoon of March 17, 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the waters south of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 91W. At 2:00 PM on March 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of March 21 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM on March 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Crising, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 92W, was designated as Tropical Depression 02W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
02W was a relatively weak tropical cyclone, but the heavy rains it brought caused disasters in the Philippines. After crossing the Philippines, it entered the South China Sea, initially affected by dry air and vertical wind shear. Later, supported by moist air, it strengthened several times, but after passing through the Luzon Strait, it weakened and dissipated again due to vertical wind shear.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 97W.  
On the morning of June 22, 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the northeastern waters of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it disturbance number 97W. By midday on June 22, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," upgraded it to "medium" on the 24th, and further to "high" by midday on June 25, simultaneously issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert, which was canceled at 5 a.m. the following morning. Subsequently, its rating was downgraded to "medium" and "low," and the rating was canceled at 2 p.m. on the 28th. On the morning of June 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, at which time it was located over the waters east of Taiwan. In the early hours of June 30, it crossed the waters near Okinawa and entered the East China Sea, with its low-level circulation center no longer clearly visible on radar. On July 1, it reorganized, causing strong winds, heavy rain, and lightning near Yakushima and Tanegashima in the early hours. After making consecutive landfalls on the two islands, its low-level circulation center was once again disrupted. It then moved northward along the coast of Kyushu, carried by the jet stream.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 90W → 91W.  
After Severe Tropical Storm Nanmadol, another low-pressure area formed in the waters east of the Philippines and was assigned disturbance number 90W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, which was later canceled. On the morning of July 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, and on the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it a new disturbance number, 91W. At 4:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of forming into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," but by 3 AM the next day, it was directly upgraded to "high," and a tropical cyclone formation alert was issued simultaneously, indicating a higher likelihood of it strengthening into a tropical depression within the next day and moving toward the waters east of Taiwan. After crossing the waters east of Taiwan and entering the East China Sea, it showed no signs of strengthening. Therefore, at 3 AM on the 7th, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its 24-hour tropical cyclone formation rating to "medium" and canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert. By 2 PM, its rating was canceled, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On the afternoon of July 12, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated a low-pressure area generated in the northwest waters of Iwo Jima as Disturbance 93W. The next day, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "medium" at 2 p.m. However, as it moved to higher latitude regions where the environment was unfavorable for tropical cyclone development, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the related assessment at 4 a.m. on the 15th, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 2 p.m. the following afternoon. It eventually transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number changed from 93W to 96W. On the morning of July 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded a low-pressure area near the International Date Line to a tropical depression [55]. Three hours later, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. As it gradually moved southeast, the surrounding environment caused its warm system to gradually turn cold, and the U.S. Ocean Prediction Center classified it as a subtropical cyclone at 8 PM [56][57].  
On July 29, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the disturbance number 96W, and the U.S. Ocean Prediction Center continued to classify it as a subtropical storm [58][59]. At 10 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone [60].

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 98W was upgraded to a tropical depression by the Japan Meteorological Agency at 2 a.m. on the 26th, but soon dissipated and merged into the circulation of Pakhar.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 90W.  
On the afternoon of August 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression at 6 PM and issued a gale warning three hours later. On the afternoon of August 29, at 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area and canceled the gale warning.

PAGASA: Nando, designated as disturbance 90W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, was classified as Tropical Depression 22W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
A low-pressure area formed in late September near the waters off Luzon and gradually developed after moving into the northern South China Sea. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On September 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, with a central minimum pressure of 1002 hPa. Subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number "22W." It moved quickly west-northwest at a speed of about 30 km/h, interacting with the northeast monsoon, which strengthened winds along the Guangdong coast. The China Meteorological Administration reported that it made landfall in Wanning City, Hainan Province, at 9:20 PM on September 24. It then crossed the Beibu Gulf and began moving toward northern Vietnam, gradually weakening. It made landfall in Quang Ninh Province, Vietnam, at 2 PM on September 25 and dissipated on September 26.  
As the low-pressure area in the northern South China Sea intensified into a tropical depression, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the Standby Signal No. 1 at 11:10 PM on September 23. Under the combined influence of its outer rainbands and easterly airflow, some areas in Hong Kong recorded over 20 mm of rainfall, and offshore areas experienced strong winds on the 12th. Among the Observatory's eight reference automatic weather stations, Cheung Chau recorded strong winds, and Cheung Chau Beach briefly experienced gale-force winds. During this period, an incident occurred where a sudden voltage drop trapped 17 people in an elevator for about an hour, who were later rescued by firefighters. All tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 7:20 PM, with the system located about 520 km southwest of Hong Kong at the time. Under its influence, some offshore and highland areas recorded strong winds.  
Meanwhile, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Signal No. 1 at midnight on September 24, with the tropical depression located about 570 km south-southeast of Macao at the time. Strong winds were consistently recorded on the three major bridges during the day. The Meteorological Bureau updated its "Special Report" at 12:30 PM, advising drivers to exercise caution due to occasional strong winds and gusts on the bridges. All signals were lowered at midnight on September 25, with the signal duration lasting exactly one day, as the system was located about 480 km southwest of Macao at the time.  
Typhoon blue warnings were issued in Hainan, Guangdong, and Guangxi. Due to heavy rainfall, the China Meteorological Administration issued a yellow rainstorm warning for southern regions, with some areas experiencing up to 140 mm of precipitation. It made landfall in Quang Ninh Province, Vietnam, at 2 PM on September 25 and dissipated in northern Vietnam on the 26th. The heavy rains it triggered caused landslides, but fortunately, there were no casualties. The Vietnam Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center recorded 150 mm of rainfall in Hanoi, and waves as high as 3 meters (9.8 feet) were observed in Ha Long Bay.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 97W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as Tropical Depression 23W.  
On October 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, and at 8 PM the same evening, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 5 AM on October 9, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning.  
At 5:50 AM on October 10, it made landfall in Ha Tinh Province, Vietnam, and dissipated that evening.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 94W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigned it the number Tropical Depression 26W.  
A day later, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning, and shortly after, it merged into Lan's circulation.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 95W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as Tropical Depression 29W. On the morning of October 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m. on November 1, a maritime strong wind warning was issued, but it was canceled by 2 a.m. the next day as it failed to develop due to the influence of Typhoon Damrey. On November 3, it made landfall on the Malay Peninsula and gradually moved away from the Gulf of Thailand into the Andaman Sea, after which the Japan Meteorological Agency ceased tracking it. However, it later interacted with the remnants of Damrey's low-pressure area through the Fujiwhara effect and returned to the Gulf of Thailand, at which point the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a low-pressure area.

The northern part of the Malay Peninsula was affected by it, bringing 15 hours of continuous storms to Penang starting in the afternoon of November 4. This caused over 80% of the area to suffer from flooding, land subsidence, landslides, storm surges, and other disasters, resulting in 7 deaths.
The following timeline lists the formation and dissipation times of typhoons this year, and details of each storm can be found in the sections above.

Tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (i.e., international naming). Once the tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, names from the following list are used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the Typhoon Committee of the World Meteorological Organization, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting 10 names, arranged in alphabetical order based on the English name of the country. Names not used this year are shown in gray, while those already used this season are shown in black. The storm names for 2017 may overlap with some storm names from 2000, 2004 to 2005, and 2011 to 2012.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form within, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. An auxiliary list is also prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2017, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list summarizes all systems that developed or moved into the North Pacific west of the International Date Line during 2017. It also outlines the system's intensity, duration, affected land areas, and any deaths or losses associated with the system.

Info_Box:
First system formed: January 7, 2017 (Tropical Depression WP01)  
Last system dissipated: January 4, 2018 (Tropical Storm Bolaven)  
Name: Lan  
* Maximum wind speed: 185 km/h (115 mph) (10-minute average wind speed)  
* Minimum pressure: 915 hPa (mbar)  
Number of tropical depressions: 41 official, 1 unofficial  
Number of storms: 27, 1 carried over to 2018  
Number of typhoons: 11  
Number of super typhoons: 2  
Death toll: 853  
Economic loss: $15.1 billion (2017 USD)

Article_Name: 2015年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The 2015 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2015. Although no official timeframe was set for this typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. In 2015, tropical storms formed in this region every month, marking the first time this occurred since the Japan Meteorological Agency began keeping records. 

This article is limited to the Pacific Ocean and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms forming in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are referred to as hurricanes and are included in the 2015 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international identification numbers starting with 15xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assigns tropical depressions in this region identification numbers ending with the letter W.

Tropical depressions entering or forming within the Philippine Area of Responsibility are given local names by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). Additionally, as China, Hong Kong, and Macau use the same Chinese translations, while Taiwan may use different Chinese names, a single storm may have two different Chinese names. The information for each tropical cyclone is based on its peak intensity during its existence.

The tropical cyclones of the 2015 season were notably stronger, making it the season with the most super typhoons (13 in total) since the Hong Kong Observatory adopted a new tropical cyclone classification system in 2009, which added the categories of "severe typhoon" and "super typhoon." It was also the first season to have four super typhoons before June.

The Director of the Hong Kong Observatory (HKO), Shun Chi-ming, stated at a press briefing held by the Observatory on March 23 that 4 to 7 tropical cyclones are expected to enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong during the year, which is considered a normal level. He also mentioned that the typhoon season might begin in June or later. The Observatory planned to extend the forecast period for tropical cyclone tracks from 3 days to 5 days during the typhoon season of that year. However, the Director noted that due to the erratic movement of some tropical cyclones, the 5-day forecast would still have significant errors. On June 20, following the formation of Tropical Storm Kujira, the Observatory implemented the 5-day tropical cyclone track forecast. Affected by the El Niño phenomenon, after Typhoon Linfa directly hit Hong Kong in early July, there were nearly three months without any tropical cyclones affecting Hong Kong until early October, when Severe Typhoon Mujigae hit, ending this rare lull. This not only marked the second consecutive year without storms hitting Hong Kong in August but also made it the first typhoon season since records began in 1946 where no storms hit Hong Kong in both August and September. As a result, on August 22, the Hong Kong Observatory revised the expected number of tropical cyclones entering the 500-kilometer range to 3 to 6, which is considered normal to slightly below normal.

The Acting Director of the Meteorological Monitoring Center of the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau (Portuguese: SMG), Wong Chan Sing, stated during a meeting on April 14 that it is predicted that 4 to 6 tropical cyclones will affect Macao within the year, with at least one possibly leading to the issuance of a No. 8 typhoon signal. The first tropical cyclone is expected to appear in mid-June. The Macao Meteorological Bureau will use the electronic display screen outside the Barrier Gate Building to release warnings about tropical cyclones, heavy rain, or storm surges.

The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) of the Ministry of Transportation held a typhoon outlook press conference on June 30, predicting that 2 to 4 typhoons would hit Taiwan during the summer, which is within the normal range. Affected by the El Niño-Southern Oscillation phenomenon, typhoons are expected to develop further east, and higher sea surface temperatures may result in stronger typhoons, all of which are expected to be at least moderate typhoons. Authorities also predict that the likelihood of typhoons affecting Taiwan is higher in summer than in autumn.

According to the "Overview of Marine Disasters in the South China Sea in 2014 and Outlook for Marine Disasters in 2015" published by the National Marine Environmental Forecasting Center of the State Oceanic Administration on May 19, 2015, the number of typhoon wave events in the Northwest Pacific and South China Sea regions during the year is predicted to be slightly below the annual average, approximately 23 to 25 times. The number of typhoon wave events in the South China Sea region throughout the year is expected to be close to the annual average, about 8 to 10 times. At the same time, the report predicts that 3 to 4 typhoon wave events will severely affect the coastal areas of Guangdong, Guangxi, and Hainan during the year, with 2 to 3 of these events severely impacting the Guangdong coast. Additionally, during the period from July to September, 1 to 2 strong typhoons or super typhoons may bring disastrous wave events to South China. The first typhoon wave event affecting the South China coast may occur from late June to early July, slightly later than the annual average, while the last typhoon wave event affecting the South China coast may occur from late September to early October, slightly earlier than the annual average. [4] 

Furthermore, according to the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau's forecast on May 23, during the flood season (May to October) of that year, 3 to 4 tropical cyclones are expected to affect Hainan Island, 2 fewer than the annual average. One tropical cyclone is expected to make landfall on Hainan Island, 1 fewer than the annual average. The intensity of tropical cyclones affecting Hainan Province is expected to be stronger than the annual average. The first tropical cyclone affecting Hainan Island may occur in mid-July, and the last one may occur in late October. [5] The Haikou Meteorological Bureau also predicted on May 26 that 3 to 4 tropical cyclones would affect Haikou City during the year, with 1 to 2 of them causing severe impacts or making landfall in Haikou City. [6]

The Philippine PAGASA predicts that the number of tropical cyclones reaching typhoon strength (118 km/h or above) within the year will increase due to the El Niño phenomenon. [7] The agency also forecasts that 11-16 tropical cyclones will enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility from June to December this year. [8]

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: On January 2, 2015, the leeward low pressure of Tropical Storm Jangmi developed over the sea northwest of Sabah. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly gave it a "MEDIUM" rating for the chance of forming into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it and raised its rating to "HIGH." On the afternoon of January 3, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating to "LOW." On the afternoon of January 4, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center removed its rating. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Amang On January 9, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 7 PM on January 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 7:30 AM on January 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Mekkhala. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 01W. At 8 AM on January 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM on January 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 AM on January 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM on January 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 AM on January 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 AM on January 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered Mekkhala to have gradually dissipated. Mekkhala was the first named storm to form in the Northwest Pacific this year. In the best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency afterward, Mekkhala's intensity was revised downward to a severe tropical storm, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 60 knots, and the central minimum pressure revised upward to 975 hPa.

On February 4, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near Kosrae, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 94W. At 8 a.m. on February 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." By 2 p.m., the rating was upgraded to "MEDIUM." At 8 p.m. on February 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 6:30 a.m. on February 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. By 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 02W. At 2 a.m. on February 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Higos. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on February 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. By 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised Higos' intensity to a Category 2 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson scale. At 2 a.m. on February 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its intensity to a Category 1 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson scale but later canceled this downgrade. By 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson scale, later revising it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 5 a.m. on February 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly downgraded it to a typhoon. By 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 2 a.m. on February 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. By 2 p.m. on February 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Higos had merged into a frontal system. Higos was once the strongest tropical cyclone in February in the Northern Hemisphere on record by the Japan Meteorological Agency, but this record was broken by Typhoon Wutip in 2019. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Higos' intensity was revised downward, with the maximum sustained winds near the center adjusted to 90 knots, and the central minimum pressure revised upward to 940 hPa.

PAGASA: Betty  
On March 6, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Kiribati, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On the morning of March 9 at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On the afternoon of March 10 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of March 11 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 1:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 03W.  

On March 12 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Bavi. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On March 17 at 11:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration classified Bavi, which had entered its area of responsibility, as a tropical storm and named it Betty, issuing the first tropical cyclone advisory. At 8:00 PM on March 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On March 18 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory. On March 19 at 5:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration downgraded it to a low-pressure area and issued the final (fifth) tropical cyclone advisory. On March 23 at 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered Bavi to have gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Chedeng Maysak was once the strongest tropical cyclone in the Northern Hemisphere on record from January to April, with its maximum sustained wind speed near the center and central pressure surpassing the record of Typhoon Andy in 1989. However, this record was broken by Typhoon Surigae in 2021. Maysak was also one of the tropical cyclones recorded by the Japan Meteorological Agency to reach the "violent" typhoon classification in March and April. According to the Hong Kong Observatory's classification, Maysak was the second tropical cyclone of that year to reach the super typhoon level (the first being Typhoon Higos in February), indicating that it was the first season since the Hong Kong Observatory introduced the new tropical cyclone classification system in 2009, adding the "severe typhoon" and "super typhoon" levels, to have two super typhoons appear before or in April. Although Maysak's movement path followed the "westward" storm pattern of the Northwest Pacific typhoon season, moving directly from the Northwest Pacific through the Philippines into the South China Sea, this type of path generally occurs from June to October. Maysak taking this path in April was extremely rare. As a result, Maysak became the first storm since Typhoon Neoguri in 2008 to enter the northern South China Sea in April. At that time, the environment in the South China Sea was unfavorable for tropical cyclone development, and Maysak was ultimately weakened and dissipated in the northern South China Sea under the influence of the northeast monsoon, a situation similar to tropical cyclones entering the northern South China Sea in November.

On March 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 2 PM on March 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 7:30 AM on April 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 AM on April 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 05W. At 8 AM on April 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Haishen. At 2 AM on April 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.

PAGASA: Dodong  
On April 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near Chuuk, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 3 AM on May 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  
At 8 AM on May 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 06W.  
At 2 AM on May 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Noul. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on May 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon.
