At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM on September 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 21W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 PM on September 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Dujuan. At 8:00 AM on September 23, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM on September 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM on September 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 AM on September 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 8:00 AM on September 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2:00 AM on September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM on September 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Dujuan had merged into a frontal system.

PAGASA: Kabayan On September 28, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northwest of Yap Island. At 12:00 PM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On September 29 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. 

On October 1 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 22W. At 3:25 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

On October 2 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Mujigae. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it back to a tropical storm. 

On October 3 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a typhoon. 

On October 4 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly raised its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. 

On October 5 at 5:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Mujigae had gradually dissipated.

On September 27, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the northern waters of the Marshall Islands. At 11 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At midnight on September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8 a.m. on September 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 8 p.m. on October 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 6 a.m. on October 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "HIGH" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Mujigae. At 2 a.m. on October 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 24W. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on October 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on October 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m. on October 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m. on October 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on October 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Mujigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Lando  
On October 11, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 12 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to a "HIGH" rating and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On October 13 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 24W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Koppu. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 15 at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On October 16 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On October 17 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. On October 18 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. On October 19 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 20 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 21 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 23 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On October 12, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near the Marshall Islands. On the same day, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On October 13 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. On October 14 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Champi. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 25W. On October 15 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 16 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. On October 17 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On October 18 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. On October 19 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. On October 22 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On October 24 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 25 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Champi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Marilyn  
On November 12, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near the Marshall Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 2 p.m. on November 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 8 a.m. on November 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 27W. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it In-fa.  
At 11 a.m. on November 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2 a.m. on November 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 6:45 a.m. on November 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 hurricane level under the Saffir-Simpson scale. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 3 hurricane level under the Saffir-Simpson scale.  
At 8 a.m. on November 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 4 hurricane level under the Saffir-Simpson scale.  
At 8 p.m. on November 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 2 a.m. on November 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 8 a.m. on November 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that In-fa had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  
This name was used for the first time, replacing Parma, which was retired due to its destructive impact on the Philippines.

PAGASA: Nona  
A low-pressure area formed approximately 120 kilometers south of Chuuk State on the evening of December 7, 2015, and moved west-northwest along the deep easterly winds on the southern side of the subtropical ridge. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the low-pressure area to a tropical depression at 8 a.m. on December 9. Although the Northwest Pacific experienced a period of calm for over half a month after Typhoon In-fa in November, with sea surface temperatures rising above 28 degrees Celsius, restoring a significant energy supply, the system's initial development was slow and disorganized due to strong vertical wind shear. By December 10, as wind shear weakened and upper-level divergence strengthened, the system began to develop deep convection, and a low-level circulation center formed. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the system at 8:45 p.m., indicating it was expected to strengthen into a tropical storm within a day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system at 1:30 p.m. the following day (December 11). However, half an hour later, the Japan Meteorological Agency officially upgraded the system to a tropical storm, naming it Melor and assigning it the international designation 1527. At that time, Melor was located approximately 50 kilometers south of Yap Island. This led the Hong Kong Observatory, which had not previously mentioned the system, to suddenly announce at 4:15 p.m. that "the low-pressure area in the Northwest Pacific has intensified into a tropical depression and has been named Melor." The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded Melor in two consecutive advisories, first classifying it as a tropical depression with the designation 28W at 11 p.m. and then upgrading it to a tropical storm at 5 a.m. on December 12. The Hong Kong Observatory followed suit at 9:45 a.m.

On December 14, Typhoon Melor made landfall in the Philippines.  
On December 17, Melor transitioned into a low-pressure area.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones assessed as tropical storms by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.

On June 23, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 2 PM on June 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 PM on June 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its assessment. At 1 AM on June 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 10:30 AM on June 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system's assessment to "MEDIUM." At 8 PM on July 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM on July 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had merged into the cloud system of Typhoon Chan-hom.

On July 14, 2015, a tropical disturbance formed over the sea east of Luzon. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated. On July 15, its residual cloud system redeveloped over the sea northeast of Luzon. At 5 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 8 p.m. on July 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had merged into the cloud system of Typhoon Nangka.

On July 18, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Kume Island. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7 a.m. on July 19, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 9 a.m. on July 20, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory canceled the designation. At 2 a.m. on July 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On July 18, 2015, a low-pressure area formed within a low-pressure trough in inland Guangdong. At 11 a.m. on July 20, the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression, internally numbered TD02, with a maximum central wind speed of 15 meters per second (54 kilometers per hour). At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Central Meteorological Observatory determined that the tropical depression was approaching the coastal area of Yangjiang, with a maximum central wind speed of 13 meters per second (47 kilometers per hour), and ceased numbering it. At 11 a.m. on July 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered the tropical depression to have gradually dissipated.

On July 23, 2015, a low-pressure area formed near the eastern coast of Luzon. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 12W. On the afternoon of July 24, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On the morning of July 25, at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on the system. On the morning of July 26, at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On August 1, 2015, a high-altitude cold vortex over the southeastern sea of Honshu transformed into a tropical disturbance. At 1:00 PM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned the disturbance the designation 95W. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." On August 2 at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 14W. On August 4 at 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On August 6 at 5:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On October 7, 2015, at 1:30 AM, 08C in the central Pacific crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific region, and thus came under the jurisdiction of the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) for reporting. At 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression. On October 9, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.
PAGASA: Onyok

On December 20, 2015, Tropical Depression 29W developed as a leeward low pressure area over the sea west of Sabah. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On December 24 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.
The following timeline lists the formation and dissipation times of typhoons this year, and details of each storm can be found in the sections above.

Tropical cyclones formed in the Northwest Pacific region are named by the Japan Typhoon Center (i.e., international naming). Once the tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, names from the following list are used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting five names, arranged alphabetically by the English name of the country. In the list of names used in 2015, five names were replaced: the new names "Barijat," "Mun," "Lan," "Bailu," and "Yun-yeung" replaced "Utor," "Fitow," "Vicente," "Haiyan," and "Lingling," respectively. Storm names in 2015 may overlap with some storm names from 2002 to 2003 and 2008 to 2009. Note:

At the 48th session of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, it was decided to retire the 13th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Soudelor," and the 22nd named tropical cyclone of the season, "Mujigae," due to the significant damage caused by the typhoons in mainland China and Taiwan. It was also decided to retire the 24th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Koppu," and the 27th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Melor," due to the significant damage caused by the typhoons in the Philippines.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2015, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all typhoons that were active in the Northwest Pacific in 2015. It includes the typhoon's intensity, duration, name, landfall locations, death toll, and total damages. All damages are measured in US dollars. The storm names in parentheses are the local names used by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration; unnamed tropical depressions are identified using storm numbers provided by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The formula for calculating ACE:

∑(v_max^2)/10^4

Data is taken every 6 hours, with the unit being 10^4 kt^2. [33]
