Article_Name: 2015年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The 2015 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during the year 2015. Although no official timeframe was set for this typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. In 2015, tropical storms formed in this region every month, marking the first time this occurred since the Japan Meteorological Agency began keeping records. 

This article is limited to the Pacific Ocean and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are referred to as hurricanes and are included in the 2015 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) with international names and are assigned international numbers starting with 15xx. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter "W."

Any tropical depressions that enter or form within the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) are given local names by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) for local warning purposes. As a result, a storm may have two different English names (with the international name being the official one). Additionally, since China, Hong Kong, and Macau use the same Chinese name, while Taiwan may use a different Chinese name, a single storm may have two different Chinese names. The information on each tropical cyclone is based on its peak intensity during its existence.

The tropical cyclones of the 2015 season were notably stronger, making it the season with the most super typhoons (13 in total) since the Hong Kong Observatory adopted a new tropical cyclone classification system in 2009, which added the categories of "severe typhoon" and "super typhoon." It was also the first season to have four super typhoons before June.

The Director of the Hong Kong Observatory (HKO), Shun Chi-ming, stated at a press briefing held by the Observatory on March 23 that 4 to 7 tropical cyclones are expected to enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong during the year, which is considered a normal level. He also mentioned that the typhoon season might begin in June or later. The Observatory planned to extend the forecast period for tropical cyclone tracks from 3 days to 5 days during the typhoon season of that year. However, the Director noted that due to the erratic movement of some tropical cyclones, the 5-day forecast would still have significant errors. On June 20, following the formation of Tropical Storm Kujira, the Observatory implemented the 5-day tropical cyclone track forecast. Affected by the El Niño phenomenon, after Typhoon Linfa directly hit Hong Kong in early July, there were nearly three months without any tropical cyclones affecting the region until early October, when Severe Typhoon Mujigae ended this rare lull. This not only marked the second consecutive year without storms hitting Hong Kong in August but also made it the first typhoon season since records began in 1946 where no storms affected Hong Kong in both August and September. As a result, on August 22, the Hong Kong Observatory revised the expected number of tropical cyclones entering the 500-kilometer range to 3 to 6, which is considered normal to slightly below normal.

The Acting Director of the Meteorological Monitoring Center of the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau (Portuguese: SMG), Wong Chan Sing, stated during a meeting on April 14 that it is predicted that 4 to 6 tropical cyclones will affect Macao this year, with at least one possibly leading to the issuance of a No. 8 typhoon signal. The first tropical cyclone is expected to appear in mid-June. The Macao Meteorological Bureau will use the electronic display screen outside the Barrier Gate Building to release warnings about tropical cyclones, heavy rain, or storm surges.

The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) of the Ministry of Transportation held a typhoon outlook press conference on June 30, predicting that 2 to 4 typhoons would affect Taiwan during the summer, which is within the normal range. Influenced by the El Niño-Southern Oscillation phenomenon, typhoons are expected to develop further east, and higher sea surface temperatures may result in stronger typhoons affecting Taiwan, all of which are expected to be at least moderate typhoons. Authorities also predict that the likelihood of typhoons impacting Taiwan is higher in summer than in autumn.

According to the "Overview of Marine Disasters in the South China Sea in 2014 and Outlook for Marine Disasters in 2015" published by the National Marine Environmental Forecasting Center of the State Oceanic Administration on May 19, 2015, the number of typhoon wave events in the Northwest Pacific and South China Sea regions during the year is predicted to be slightly below the annual average, approximately 23 to 25 occurrences. The number of typhoon wave events in the South China Sea region throughout the year is expected to be close to the annual average, about 8 to 10 occurrences. At the same time, the report predicts that 3 to 4 typhoon wave events will severely affect the coastal areas of Guangdong, Guangxi, and Hainan during the year, with 2 to 3 of these events severely impacting the Guangdong coast. Additionally, during the period from July to September, 1 to 2 strong typhoons or super typhoons may bring disastrous wave events to South China. The first typhoon wave event affecting the South China coast may occur from late June to early July, slightly later than the annual average, while the last typhoon wave event affecting the South China coast may occur from late September to early October, slightly earlier than the annual average. [4] 

Furthermore, according to the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau's forecast on May 23, during the flood season (May to October) of that year, 3 to 4 tropical cyclones are expected to affect Hainan Island, which is 2 fewer than the annual average. One tropical cyclone is expected to make landfall on Hainan Island, which is 1 fewer than the annual average. The intensity of tropical cyclones affecting Hainan Province is expected to be stronger than the annual average. The first tropical cyclone affecting Hainan Island may occur in mid-July, and the last one may occur in late October. [5] The Haikou Meteorological Bureau also predicted on May 26 that 3 to 4 tropical cyclones would affect Haikou City during the year, with 1 to 2 of them causing severe impacts or making landfall in Haikou City. [6]

The Philippines' PAGASA predicts that the number of tropical cyclones reaching typhoon strength (118 km/h or above) within the year will increase due to the El Niño phenomenon. [7] The agency also forecasts that 11-16 tropical cyclones will enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility from June to December this year. [8]

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: On January 2, 2015, the leeward low pressure of Tropical Storm Jangmi developed over the sea northwest of Sabah. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly gave it a "MEDIUM" rating for the chance of forming into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." On January 3 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating to "LOW." On January 4 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Amang On January 9, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 7 PM on January 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 7:30 AM on January 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Mekkhala. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 01W. At 8 AM on January 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM on January 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 AM on January 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM on January 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 AM on January 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 AM on January 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered Mekkhala to have gradually dissipated. Mekkhala was the first named storm to form in the Northwest Pacific this year. In the best track released afterward by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Mekkhala's intensity was revised downward to a severe tropical storm, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 60 knots, and the minimum central pressure revised upward to 975 hPa.

On February 4, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near Kosrae, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 94W. At 8 a.m. on February 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." By 2 p.m., the rating was upgraded to "MEDIUM." At 8 p.m. on February 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 6:30 a.m. on February 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. By 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 02W. At 2 a.m. on February 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Higos. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on February 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. By 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised Higos' intensity to a Category 2 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson scale. At 2 a.m. on February 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its intensity to a Category 1 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson scale but later canceled this downgrade. By 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson scale, later revising it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 5 a.m. on February 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly downgraded it to a typhoon. By 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 2 a.m. on February 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. By 2 p.m. on February 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Higos had merged into a frontal system. Higos was once the strongest tropical cyclone in February in the Northern Hemisphere on record by the Japan Meteorological Agency, but this record was broken by Typhoon Wutip in 2019. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Higos' intensity was revised downward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 90 knots, and the central minimum pressure revised upward to 940 hPa.

PAGASA: Betty  
On March 6, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Kiribati, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On the morning of March 9 at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On the afternoon of March 10 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression. On the morning of March 11 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 1:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 03W.  

On March 12 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Bavi. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm. On March 17 at 11:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration classified Bavi, which had entered its area of responsibility, as a tropical storm and named it Betty, issuing the first tropical cyclone advisory. At 8:00 PM on March 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On March 18 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory. On March 19 at 5:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration downgraded it to a low-pressure area and issued the final (fifth) tropical cyclone advisory. On March 23 at 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Bavi had gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Chedeng Maysak was once the strongest tropical cyclone in the Northern Hemisphere on record from January to April, with its maximum sustained wind speed near the center and central pressure surpassing the record of Typhoon Andy in 1989. However, this record was broken by Typhoon Surigae in 2021. Maysak was also one of the tropical cyclones recorded by the Japan Meteorological Agency to reach the "violent" typhoon rating in March and April. According to the Hong Kong Observatory's classification, Maysak was the second tropical cyclone of the year to reach the super typhoon level (the first being Typhoon Higos in February), indicating that it was the first season since the Hong Kong Observatory introduced the new tropical cyclone classification system in 2009, adding the "severe typhoon" and "super typhoon" levels, to have two super typhoons appear before or in April. Although Maysak's movement path followed the "westward" storm pattern of the Northwest Pacific typhoon season, moving from the Northwest Pacific through the Philippines into the South China Sea, this type of path generally occurs from June to October. Maysak taking this path in April was extremely rare. As a result, Maysak became the first storm since Typhoon Neoguri in 2008 to enter the northern South China Sea in April. At that time, the environment in the South China Sea was unfavorable for tropical cyclone development, and Maysak was ultimately weakened and dissipated in the northern South China Sea under the influence of the northeast monsoon, a situation similar to tropical cyclones entering the northern South China Sea in November.

On March 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 2:00 PM on March 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 7:30 AM on April 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 AM on April 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 05W. At 8:00 AM on April 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Haishen. At 2:00 AM on April 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.

PAGASA: Dodong  
On April 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near Chuuk, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On May 2 at 3 AM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:30 PM, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 PM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it.  

On May 3 at 8 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 06W. On May 4 at 2 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Noul. At the same time, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm. On May 6 at 2 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm, and the JTWC simultaneously upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon.  

On May 7 at 8 AM, the JTWC upgraded Noul's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. At 8 PM, the JTWC further upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon. On May 9 at 8 AM, the JTWC temporarily downgraded Noul's intensity to 95 knots, equivalent to a Category 2 typhoon, but at 2 PM, it was upgraded again to 105 knots. At 8 PM, the JTWC upgraded Noul's intensity to a Category 4 typhoon.  

On May 10 at 2 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 8 AM, the JTWC upgraded Noul's intensity to a Category 5 typhoon. On May 11 at 2 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a typhoon. On May 12 at 8 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the JTWC issued its final warning for it. At 5 PM, the JMA determined that Noul had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  

In the JMA's post-analysis best track, Noul's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained winds near the center adjusted to 110 knots, but the central minimum pressure was revised upward to 920 hPa.

On May 3, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8 a.m. on May 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 10:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 p.m. on May 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 2 a.m. on May 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 07W. At 8 p.m. on May 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m. on May 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Dolphin. At 8 a.m. on May 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 a.m. on May 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Dolphin's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 a.m. on May 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 a.m. on May 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 5 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m. on May 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. At 8 a.m. on May 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on May 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Dolphin had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On June 18, 2015, a low-pressure area formed within a monsoon trough in the central South China Sea. At 8 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. On June 19 at 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." On June 20 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 08W. On June 21 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Kujira. On June 22 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 23 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it again to a tropical storm. On June 24 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it again to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. On June 25 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Kujira had gradually dissipated. In the best track released afterward by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Kujira's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 45 knots.

PAGASA: Falcon  
On June 25, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Kosrae. At 12:00 noon, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 9:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
On June 27, at 5:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system's rating to "MEDIUM."  
On June 30, at 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 8:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 09W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Chan-hom.  
On July 1, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 2, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon.  
On July 3, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 6, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency re-upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center re-upgraded it to a typhoon.  
On July 7, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency re-upgraded it to a typhoon.  
On July 8, at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Chan-hom's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  
On July 9, at 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  
On July 10, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  
On July 12, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 13, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Chan-hom had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Egay  
On June 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northwest of Palau. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. On July 1 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its assessment to "MEDIUM."  

At 1:30 a.m. on July 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert for the system and upgraded its assessment to "HIGH." At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 10W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Linfa.  

At 2 a.m. on July 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 5 at 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 7 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a severe tropical storm.  

At 2 a.m. on July 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 10 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency considered Linfa to have gradually dissipated.  

In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Linfa's intensity was revised downward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 50 knots, and the minimum central pressure revised upward to 980 hPa.

On July 1, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the southeastern sea of the Marshall Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On July 3 at 7 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "MEDIUM." At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded the rating to "HIGH." At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 11W. On July 4 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Chan-hom. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 5 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 6 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On July 7 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Chan-hom's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 9 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. On July 10 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. On July 12 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again upgraded its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 13 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 17 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 18 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On July 19 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Chan-hom had merged into a frontal system.

PAGASA: Goring On the morning of July 13, 2015, at 5:00 AM, Halola, located in the central North Pacific, crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific region, and was subsequently monitored by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA). At 8:20 AM, the JMA classified it as a severe tropical storm, retaining the Central Pacific name Halola. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) classified it as a tropical storm. On July 14, at 8:00 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the JTWC also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the JTWC further upgraded Halola's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. On July 16, at 11:00 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 17, at 2:00 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 18, at 8:00 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 19, at 2:00 PM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. On July 20, at 8:00 AM, the JMA reclassified it as a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the JMA reclassified it as a severe tropical storm. On July 21, at 8:00 AM, the JMA reclassified it as a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the JTWC reclassified it as a typhoon. On July 23, at 2:00 AM, the JTWC once again upgraded its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. On July 24, at 2:00 AM, the JTWC downgraded its intensity to a Category 1 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. On July 25, at 2:00 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 6:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 26, at 5:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression. Simultaneously, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. On July 27, at 8:00 AM, the JMA determined that Halola had gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Hanna  
On July 28, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of the Marshall Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. On July 29 at 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2:00 PM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 10:30 PM, the JTWC further upgraded its rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  

On July 30 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. At 2:00 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 13W. At 8:00 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Soudelor. Simultaneously, the JTWC also upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On August 2 at 2:00 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the JTWC also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the JTWC raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.  

On August 3 at 2:00 AM, the JTWC raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon. At 8:00 AM, the JTWC raised its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a super typhoon.  

On August 4 at 2:00 AM, the JTWC raised its intensity to a Category 5 typhoon.  

On August 5 at 8:00 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a typhoon.  

On August 8 at 4:40 AM, Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau reported that Soudelor made landfall at the mouth of the Liwu River in Xiulin Township, Hualien County, Taiwan.  

On August 9 at 2:00 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. Simultaneously, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. At 8:00 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On August 11 at 2:00 PM, the JMA determined that Soudelor had merged with a front and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On August 5, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea east of the Northern Mariana Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On August 6, at 6:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "MEDIUM." At 1:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded the rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the system. On August 7, at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 15W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Molave. On August 8, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 9, at 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a subtropical depression and issued its final warning. On August 11, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical storm and resumed issuing advisories, with a maximum one-minute average wind speed of 45 knots, later adjusted to 50 knots. On August 14, at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Molave had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Ineng  
On August 11, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Pohnpei. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On August 12 at 4:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On August 13 at 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system's rating to "MEDIUM." On August 14 at 1:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded its rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 16W. On August 15 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Goni. On August 16 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On August 17 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On August 19 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On August 24 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On August 25 at 5:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 26 at 5:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Goni had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Goni's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 100 knots.

On August 12, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the northern waters of the Marshall Islands. At 7 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 11 p.m. on August 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "MEDIUM." At 3:30 a.m. on August 14, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded the rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 17W. At 2 a.m. on August 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Atsani. At 2 p.m. on August 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m. on August 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 a.m. on August 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further raised its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 a.m. on August 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a super typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 5 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 a.m. on August 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m. on August 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m. on August 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 5 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Atsani had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

At 2:00 PM on September 1, 2015, Kilo crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific Ocean from the Central North Pacific, and the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) took over issuing advisories. At 3:20 PM, the JMA classified it as a typhoon, retaining the Central Pacific name Kilo. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) also classified it as a typhoon. On September 4 at 2:00 AM, the JTWC upgraded its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On September 7 at 2:00 AM, the JTWC again upgraded its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On September 9 at 8:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 10 at 2:00 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 11 at 8:00 AM, the JTWC issued its final advisory. At 8:00 PM, the JMA determined that Kilo had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the post-analysis best track released by the JMA, Kilo's intensity was revised downward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 80 knots and the minimum central pressure revised upward to 950 hPa.

On September 2, 2015, a low-pressure area formed within a trough northwest of the Northern Mariana Islands. On the same day, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On September 5 at 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 6 at 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On September 7 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Etau. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 18W. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 8 at 5 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 9 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Etau had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On September 11, 2015, a low-pressure area formed in the central South China Sea. At 1 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On September 13, at 1 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "MEDIUM." At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 7 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 19W. On September 14, at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Vamco. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On September 15, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Vamco had gradually dissipated. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Vamco's intensity was revised downward, and its central minimum pressure was adjusted upward to 998 hPa.

On September 13, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea east of the Northern Mariana Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At midnight on September 14, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. 

At 2 a.m. on September 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 20W. At 2 a.m. on September 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Krovanh. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. 

At 2 a.m. on September 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. 

At 2 a.m. on September 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 p.m. on September 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. 

At 2 a.m. on September 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. 

At 2 a.m. on September 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Krovanh had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Jenny On September 15, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Guam. At 8:00 AM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. At 5:00 AM on September 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 3:00 PM on September 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "MEDIUM." At 2:00 AM on September 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further raised its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM on September 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 21W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 PM on September 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Dujuan. At 8:00 AM on September 23, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM on September 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM on September 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 AM on September 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 8:00 AM on September 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2:00 AM on September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM on September 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Dujuan had merged into a frontal system.

PAGASA: Kabayan  
On September 28, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northwest of Yap Island. At 12:00 PM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W.  
At 2:00 AM on September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 5:00 AM, the JTWC upgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 2:00 AM on October 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the JTWC also upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 22W. At 3:25 PM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2:00 AM on October 2, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Mujigae. At the same time, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the JTWC upgraded it again to a tropical storm.  
At 2:00 AM on October 3, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the JTWC upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2:00 AM on October 4, the JTWC raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. At 2:00 PM, the JTWC directly raised its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. At 8:00 PM, the JTWC issued its final warning for it. At 11:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 5:00 AM on October 5, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the JMA determined that Mujigae had gradually dissipated.

On September 27, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the northern waters of the Marshall Islands. At 11 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At midnight on September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8 a.m. on September 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 8 p.m. on October 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 6 a.m. on October 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Mujigae. At 2 a.m. on October 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 24W. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on October 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on October 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m. on October 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m. on October 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on October 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Mujigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Lando  
On October 11, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Chuuk. On the same day, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 12 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to a "HIGH" rating and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On October 13 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 24W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Koppu. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 15 at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On October 16 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On October 17 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. On October 18 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. On October 19 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 20 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 21 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 23 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On October 12, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near the Marshall Islands. On the same day, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On October 13 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. On October 14 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Champi. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 25W. On October 15 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 16 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. On October 17 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On October 18 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. On October 19 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. On October 22 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On October 24 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 25 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Champi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Marilyn  
On November 12, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near the Marshall Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 2 p.m. on November 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 8 a.m. on November 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 27W. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it In-fa.  
At 11 a.m. on November 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2 a.m. on November 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 6:45 a.m. on November 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center adjusted its intensity to a Category 2 hurricane level under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center adjusted its intensity to a Category 3 hurricane level under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  
At 8 a.m. on November 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center adjusted its intensity to a Category 4 hurricane level under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  
At 8 p.m. on November 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 2 a.m. on November 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 8 a.m. on November 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that In-fa had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  
This name was used for the first time, replacing Parma, which was retired due to its destructive impact on the Philippines.

PAGASA: Nona  
A low-pressure area formed approximately 120 kilometers south of Chuuk State on the evening of December 7, 2015, and moved northwestward along the deep easterly winds on the southern side of the subtropical ridge. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the low-pressure area to a tropical depression at 8 a.m. on December 9. Although the Northwest Pacific had experienced over half a month of inactivity since Typhoon In-fa in November, with sea surface temperatures rising above 28 degrees Celsius, restoring a significant energy supply, the system's initial development was slow and disorganized due to strong vertical wind shear. By December 10, as wind shear weakened and upper-level divergence strengthened, the system began to develop deep convection, and a low-level circulation center formed. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the system at 8:45 p.m., predicting it would intensify into a tropical storm within a day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system at 1:30 p.m. the following day (December 11). However, half an hour later, the Japan Meteorological Agency officially upgraded the system to a tropical storm, naming it Melor and assigning it the international designation 1527. At that time, Melor was located approximately 50 kilometers south of Yap Island. This prompted the Hong Kong Observatory, which had not previously mentioned the system, to suddenly announce at 4:15 p.m. that "the low-pressure area in the Northwest Pacific has intensified into a tropical depression and has been named Melor." The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded Melor in two consecutive advisories, first classifying it as a tropical depression with the designation 28W at 11 p.m. and then upgrading it to a tropical storm at 5 a.m. on December 12. The Hong Kong Observatory followed suit at 9:45 a.m.

On December 14, Typhoon Melor made landfall in the Philippines.  
On December 17, Melor transitioned into a low-pressure area.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones assessed as tropical storms by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.

On June 23, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 2 PM on June 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 PM on June 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its assessment. At 1 AM on June 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 10:30 AM on June 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system's assessment to "MEDIUM." At 8 PM on July 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM on July 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had merged into the cloud system of Typhoon Chan-hom.

On July 14, 2015, a tropical disturbance formed over the sea east of Luzon. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated. On July 15, its residual cloud system redeveloped over the sea northeast of Luzon. At 5 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 8 p.m. on July 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had merged into the cloud system of Typhoon Nangka.

On July 18, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Kume Island. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7 a.m. on July 19, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 9 a.m. on July 20, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory canceled the designation. At 2 a.m. on July 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On July 18, 2015, a low-pressure area formed within a low-pressure trough in inland Guangdong. At 11 a.m. on July 20, the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression, internally numbered TD02, with maximum wind speeds of 15 meters per second (54 kilometers per hour). At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Central Meteorological Observatory determined that the tropical depression was approaching the coastal area of Yangjiang, with maximum wind speeds of 13 meters per second (47 kilometers per hour), and ceased numbering it. At 11 a.m. on July 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On July 23, 2015, a low-pressure area formed near the eastern coast of Luzon. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 12W. On July 24 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 25 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on the system. On July 26 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On August 1, 2015, a high-altitude cold vortex over the southeastern sea of Honshu transformed into a tropical disturbance. At 1:00 PM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned the disturbance the designation 95W. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." On August 2 at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 14W. On August 4 at 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On August 6 at 5:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On October 7, 2015, at 1:30 AM, 08C in the central Pacific crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific region, and thus came under the jurisdiction of the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) for reporting. At 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression. On October 9, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.
PAGASA: Onyok

On December 20, 2015, Tropical Depression 29W developed as a leeward low pressure area over the sea west of Sabah. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On December 24 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.
The following timeline lists the formation and dissipation times of typhoons this year, and details of each storm can be found in the sections above.

Tropical cyclones formed in the Northwest Pacific region are named by the Tokyo Typhoon Center in Japan (i.e., international naming). Once the tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, names from the following list are used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting five names, arranged alphabetically by the English name of the country. In the list of names used in 2015, five names were replaced: the new names "Barijat," "Mun," "Lan," "Bailu," and "Yagi" replaced "Utor," "Fitow," "Vicente," "Haiyan," and "Lingling," respectively. Storm names in 2015 may overlap with some storm names from 2002-2003 and 2008-2009. Note:

At the 48th session of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, it was decided to retire the 13th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Soudelor," and the 22nd named tropical cyclone of the season, "Mujigae," due to the significant damage caused by the typhoons in mainland China and Taiwan. It was also decided to retire the 24th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Koppu," and the 27th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Melor," due to the significant damage caused by the typhoons in the Philippines.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list rotates every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2015, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list enumerates all typhoons that were active in the Northwest Pacific in 2015, including their intensity, duration, names, landfall locations, death tolls, and total damages. All damages are calculated in US dollars. The storm names in parentheses are the local names used by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration; unnamed tropical depressions are identified using storm numbers provided by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The formula for calculating ACE:

∑ v_max^2 / 10^4

Data is taken every 6 hours, with the unit being 10^4 kt^2. [33]

Article_Name: 颱風科羅旺 (2015年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Krovanh (English: Typhoon Krovanh, International Number: 1520, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 20W) was the 18th named storm of the 2015 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Krovanh" was provided by Cambodia, referring to white cardamom, which is abundantly produced in Cambodia, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, Sri Lanka, and also cultivated in China's Yunnan, Guangdong, and Guangxi regions.

A low-pressure area formed east of Guam on September 13, 2015, and was designated as tropical disturbance 96W by the United States Naval Research Laboratory. On the following day (14th) at midnight, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," but three hours later, it skipped the "medium" rating and directly upgraded it to "high," issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Additionally, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the low-pressure area to a tropical depression at 2 a.m. and issued a gale warning at 8 a.m.  

At 2 a.m. on September 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 20W. That day, the system developed slowly, with loose organization and erratic movement, following a serpentine path. After moving west-northwest, it suddenly turned 90 degrees to the northeast, but half a day later, under the influence of the subtropical ridge, it turned northwest again, resuming its original direction. The system then began to consolidate in an environment with weak vertical wind shear, steadily intensifying. On the following day (16th) at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the tropical depression to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 1520, and named it Krovanh. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded Krovanh to a tropical storm at the same time. Nine hours later, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Krovanh to a severe tropical storm. By this time, Krovanh's central dense overcast had formed, and it began to develop a "cloud-filled eye."  

Due to the subtropical ridge dominating the northwest Pacific, the deep easterly flow to its south guided Krovanh steadily on a west-northwest track at a speed of about 15 kilometers per hour. Benefiting from weak vertical wind shear, warm sea temperatures, and favorable upper-level outflow, Krovanh continued to intensify on the 17th, establishing dual outflow channels toward the equator and the poles. Its central dense overcast further consolidated, and an eye opened. At 2 a.m., both the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Krovanh to a typhoon. That day, Krovanh moved to the southwest side of the subtropical ridge, with its path shifting northwestward and maintaining a speed of about 15 kilometers per hour. Krovanh also reached its peak intensity that evening.  

On the following day (18th), Krovanh turned clockwise along the western side of the subtropical ridge, taking a north to north-northwest track. At the same time, dry air intrusion on its western side weakened convection, and the system began to be affected by the westerlies, with vertical wind shear significantly increasing, causing Krovanh to weaken.  

On the 19th, Krovanh's movement gradually shifted northeastward, and its intensity continued to decline. The eye became blurred, turning into a "cloud-filled eye." The Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded Krovanh to a tropical storm at 8 p.m., and the Japan Meteorological Agency followed suit at 2 a.m. on the 20th, downgrading it to a severe tropical storm. Due to stronger wind shear and reduced energy supply from cooler sea temperatures, Krovanh's central dense overcast was destroyed, deep convection was displaced northeastward, and the eye was completely filled. The low-level circulation center was even partially exposed. With cold air intrusion, Krovanh gradually developed frontal characteristics, beginning its transition into an extratropical cyclone. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on Krovanh at 8 p.m., and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm, stating at 2 a.m. on the 21st that Krovanh had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  

The system continued to move northward but suddenly turned southward east of Hokkaido before gradually shifting eastward. Krovanh's remnants persisted for a full week, eventually dissipating on the 28th.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴莫拉菲 (2015年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Molave (English: Tropical Storm Molave, International Number: 1514, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP152015) is the 14th named storm of the 2015 Pacific typhoon season. "Molave" is a tropical cyclone name provided by the Philippine meteorological department in 2004, referring to the Vitex parviflora, a type of hardwood commonly used in furniture making in the Philippines.

On August 5, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the eastern sea of the Northern Mariana Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low." On August 6, at 6:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system's rating to "medium." At 1:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the system. On August 7, at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 15W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Molave. On August 8, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 9, at 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a subtropical depression and issued its final warning. On August 11, Molave's cloud system began converging toward its center, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center determined that it once again met the structural conditions of a tropical cyclone. At 2 p.m., it was reclassified as a tropical storm, with a maximum one-minute average wind speed of 45 knots, later adjusted to 50 knots. On August 14, at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Molave had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴海神 (2015年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Haishen (English: Tropical Storm Haishen, International Number: 1505, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP052015) was the fifth named storm of the 2015 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Haishen" was provided by mainland China and refers to a deity in traditional Chinese customs that seafarers and fishermen pray to for safety before going out to sea or encountering severe weather. According to Digital Typhoon data, Haishen broke the record for the earliest fifth tropical cyclone in history, with the previous record holder being Typhoon Wanda in 1965.

On March 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 2:00 PM on March 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 7:30 AM on April 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 AM on April 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 05W. The Central Weather Bureau also followed suit and upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM on April 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Haishen." Simultaneously, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 4:00 PM, the Korea Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 AM on April 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. The Central Weather Bureau also downgraded it to a low-pressure area. The China Meteorological Administration also downgraded it to a tropical depression and ceased its numbering.
