Last system dissipated: January 4, 2015 (Tropical Storm Jangmi)  
Name: Typhoon Rammasun  
* Maximum wind speed: 215 km/h (130 mph) (10-minute sustained winds)  
* Lowest pressure: 900 hPa (mbar)  
Number of tropical depressions: 30  
Number of storms: 23  
Number of typhoons: 11  
Number of super typhoons: 8  
Death toll: 572 people  
Economic loss: $12.92 billion (2014 USD)

Article_Name: 2014年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2014 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2014. Although no official timeframe was set for this typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This year marked the first time since records began by the Japan Meteorological Agency that no tropical storms formed in the Northwest Pacific during August (except for Genevieve, which did not form in this region and actually developed in late July). [1] The scope of this article is limited to the Pacific Ocean and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms forming in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are referred to as hurricanes and are included in the 2014 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms forming in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency's Typhoon Center in Tokyo (international names) and are assigned international numbers starting with 14xx. The United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter "W." Any tropical depressions entering or forming within the Philippine Area of Responsibility are given a Philippine name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (with the international name being the official one). Additionally, as Hong Kong, Macau, and mainland China use the same Chinese name, and Taiwan may use a different Chinese name, a single storm may have two different Chinese names. The information for each tropical cyclone is based on its strongest form during its existence.

The Director of the Hong Kong Observatory (HKO), Shun Chi-ming, stated at a press conference held by the Observatory on March 17 that the number of tropical cyclones expected to enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong this year is approximately 4 to 7, which is considered close to normal levels. It is anticipated that the typhoon season in Hong Kong will begin in June or later. Subsequently, the Hong Kong Observatory revised the forecasted number of typhoons from 4 to 7 to 3 to 6, emphasizing that typhoons are most likely to occur in September, and the public should remain vigilant.

Director Cheng Ming-Dian of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) Forecast Center stated that there is a high chance of El Niño development in the second half of the year. The formation locations of typhoons are expected to be farther from Taiwan, and the typhoons at the beginning of the typhoon season are more likely to veer northward. However, attention should still be paid to the possibility of typhoons affecting Taiwan in August and September. On June 27, the Central Weather Bureau issued a press release stating that the total number of typhoons expected to form in the western North Pacific this year is approximately 29 to 32, which is higher than the climate average (25.7). As of the end of June, there have already been 7 typhoons formed in the western North Pacific, exceeding the climate average (4.3). Regarding typhoons affecting Taiwan, it is estimated that 3 to 5 typhoons will impact Taiwan this year, which is close to the climate average (3.6).

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau (Portuguese: SMG) stated in its summer quarterly climate forecast on May 30 that there is a higher likelihood of El Niño developing during the summer. The number of tropical cyclones affecting Macao this year is expected to be near normal (about 4 to 6), with approximately one tropical cyclone signal requiring the hoisting of Typhoon Signal No. 8 or above.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content:
PAGASA: Agaton  
On January 6, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Palau. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 10:30 AM on January 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2:00 PM on January 10, the JTWC canceled the rating. At 9:30 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. Its central wind speed reached 15 meters per second (54 kilometers per hour). At 2:00 AM on January 11, the JTWC again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2:00 PM on January 12, the JTWC canceled the rating. At 3:25 PM, the JMA issued a general warning. At 2:00 AM on January 13, the JMA downgraded it to a low-pressure area and canceled all warnings. Subsequently, the remnants of the system, which had been downgraded to a low-pressure area by the JMA, redeveloped over the sea northwest of Palau. At 8:00 AM on January 14, the JMA once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM on January 15, the JTWC again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2:00 PM on January 16, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 8:00 PM, the JMA reissued a gale warning. At 9:00 PM, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On January 17, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "HIGH." On January 18, at 8:00 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Lingling." At the same time, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 01W. At 5:00 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5:00 AM on January 19, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 AM on January 20, the JTWC issued its final warning. At 8:45 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression and canceled the gale warning. At 8:00 AM on January 21, the JMA downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On January 27, its remnants merged into the Intertropical Convergence Zone, where it redeveloped into another low-pressure system and continued to develop over the sea southeast of Guam. It was later upgraded to a tropical storm by the JMA on January 31 and named "Kajiki."  
Tropical Storm "Lingling" was the first tropical cyclone to form in the Northwest Pacific in 2014 and the first named tropical storm of the year. In the JTWC's post-season best track analysis, Lingling's intensity was revised downward, with its maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 30 knots, indicating it never reached tropical storm strength.

PAGASA: Basyang On January 27, 2014, the remnants of Tropical Storm Lingling merged into the Intertropical Convergence Zone, redeveloping into a low-pressure area southeast of Guam and continuing to develop in that area. On the same afternoon, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the designation 92W. On January 28 at 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On January 29 at 9:25 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On January 31 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 02W. At 9:10 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Kajiki." On February 1 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:45 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression and canceled the gale warning. On February 2 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. According to the Philippine National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council, Kajiki made landfall in Siargao Island in the southeastern Philippines, causing at least six fatalities and affecting tens of thousands of people.

On February 17, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Pohnpei. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 3 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On February 20 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating. On February 21 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On February 22 at 3 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating again. On February 23 at 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once more rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On February 26 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 11 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. On February 28 at 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 03W. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Faxai." On March 3 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On March 4 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. On March 5 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On March 6 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Faxai had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. Faxai was the first typhoon to form in the Northwest Pacific in 2014 and the first tropical cyclone to reach typhoon status in February since Typhoon Mitag in 2002.

PAGASA: Domeng On March 28, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. On March 29 at 12 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On March 30 at 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. On March 31 at 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it from a low-pressure area. On April 2 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it back to a low-pressure area. At 3 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." On April 3 at 4 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 6 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 05W. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On April 5 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Peipah." On April 6 at 9 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On April 9 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression and canceled the gale warning. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On April 10 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. Subsequently, its remnants redeveloped over the sea east of Mindanao. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." On April 11 at 3 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "LOW." On April 12 at 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating back to "MEDIUM." On April 13 at 10 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency again upgraded it to a tropical depression. On April 15 at 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating again to "LOW." At 3 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. At 4 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On April 17 at 9 AM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory decommissioned it.

On April 22, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northwest of Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 9 a.m. on April 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 10 p.m. on April 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 10 a.m. on April 27, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 06W. At 8 a.m. on April 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Tapah." At 2 a.m. on April 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on April 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m. on May 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 8 p.m. on May 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Tapah's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 50 knots and the minimum central pressure lowered to 985 hPa.

PAGASA: Ester  
On the afternoon of June 8, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Taiwan.  
At 11 a.m. on June 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, with a pressure of 1000 hPa at the time. At 10 p.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
At 6 a.m. on June 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 1 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a general warning for it.  
At 8 a.m. on June 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Mina."  
At 9 a.m. on June 12, as Mina moved northward, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Mina had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "LOW."

On June 11, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Hainan Island. At 12 PM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. On June 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On June 13 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, with a pressure of 998 hPa at the time. At 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a general warning for it. At 9 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. On June 14 at 3 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 10 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical storm and assigned it the number 07W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Hagibis." On June 15 at 9 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. On June 16 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On June 17 at 6 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center re-upgraded it to a tropical depression and reissued warnings. At 12 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency re-upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 18 at 3 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Hagibis had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.

PAGASA: Florita  
On June 30, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W.  
At 6:00 AM on July 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 3:00 AM on July 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM."  
At 2:00 AM on July 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 08W. At 9:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  
At 2:00 AM on July 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Neoguri." At 5:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2:00 AM on July 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  
At 1:00 AM on July 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon.  
At 2:00 AM on July 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 3:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 11:00 PM on July 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.  
At 12:00 AM on July 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Neoguri had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Neoguri's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained winds near the center adjusted to 100 knots.  
In the post-analysis best track yearbook released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, Neoguri's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained winds near the center adjusted to 140 knots.

PAGASA: Glenda  
On July 9, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the eastern waters of Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On July 10 at 9 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 AM, the JTWC raised its rating to "MEDIUM." At 3 PM, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 10 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 09W.  

On July 11 at 2 AM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. At 8 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 12 at 2 AM, the JTWC downgraded its earlier classification as a tropical storm and adjusted its intensity back to a tropical depression. At 3 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Rammasun." At 8 PM, the JTWC once again upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On July 14 at 8:45 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 3 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 9 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. On July 15 at 2 PM, the JTWC directly upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 8 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  

On July 16 at 2 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 8 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. On July 17 at 8 AM, the JTWC once again upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2 PM, the JTWC downgraded it again to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8 PM, the JTWC once again upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon.  

On July 18 at 2 AM, the JTWC directly upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 2 PM on July 18, Rammasun made landfall in Wenchang, Hainan Province, as the strongest typhoon ever recorded to make landfall in China. A sea-level pressure of 899.2 hPa was recorded on North Point Island, the lowest sea-level pressure ever recorded in Asia.  

On July 19 at 8 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon and issued its final warning. At 6 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:50 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 20 at 8 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 21 at 3 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  

In the post-analysis best track released by the JMA, Rammasun's central minimum pressure was revised downward to 935 hPa. In the post-analysis best track annual report released by the JTWC, Rammasun's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained winds near the center adjusted to 140 knots, making it the first-ever Category 5 super typhoon in the history of the South China Sea.

PAGASA: Henry  
On July 14, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea west of Yap Island. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On July 16 at 1 PM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 6 PM, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 9:25 PM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it.  

On July 17 at 8 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 10W. On July 18 at 2 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3:30 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Matmo." On July 19 at 9 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 3 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon.  

On July 22 at 2 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. On July 23 at 2 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 3 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning.  

On July 25 at 3 PM, the JMA determined that Matmo had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. Subsequently, in the JMA's best track data, Matmo's wind speed was revised downward to 70 knots, and its central minimum pressure was revised upward to 965 hPa.

PAGASA: Inday  
On July 17, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Pohnpei. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W.  
On July 19 at 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "MEDIUM."  
On July 22 at 1 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 10 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered the tropical depression to have gradually dissipated.  
On July 23 at midnight, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further downgraded its rating to "LOW."  
On July 24 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency observed that its residual cloud system redeveloped over the northern sea of Palau, forming a new system, and classified it as a low-pressure area.  
On July 25 at 4 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating again to "MEDIUM."  
On July 26 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On July 27 at 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "LOW."  
On July 28 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating again to "MEDIUM."  
On July 29 at 3 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  
On July 30 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Nakri." At 7 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
On August 1 at 3 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 6 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
On August 2 at 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued another Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 3 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical storm and assigned it the number 12W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On August 3 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On August 4 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 5 PM, its cloud system began to gradually dissipate, but the Japan Meteorological Agency still considered its intensity to remain at a tropical depression level. The center had moved out of South Korea's land area into the Sea of Japan and was slowly moving eastward. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Jose  
On July 26, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea north of Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On July 28 at 2 AM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 9 AM, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 10 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the JTWC raised its rating to "HIGH." At 8 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 11W.  

On July 29 at 8 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 AM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. At 12 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Halong." On August 1 at 12 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On August 2 at 2 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 3 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the JTWC directly upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 2 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  

On August 3 at 2 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon. At 8 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. On August 4 at 2 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. On August 5 at 2 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. On August 6 at 2 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 2 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 8 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon.  

On August 10 at 2 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On August 11 at 8 AM, the JMA determined that Halong had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  

In the JMA's post-analysis best track, Halong's central minimum pressure was revised to 920 hPa.

At 11:30 AM on August 7, 2014, Genevieve crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific Ocean from the Central North Pacific, and thus came under the jurisdiction of the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) for reporting. At 3:25 PM, the JMA classified it as a typhoon, retaining the name Genevieve from the Eastern Pacific. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) classified it as a Category 4 typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon.  

On August 8 at 8:00 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. On August 9 at 8:00 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. On August 10 at 2:00 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon.  

On August 11 at 8:00 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On August 12 at 2:00 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 2:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On August 14 at 8:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On September 3, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Samar Island. On the same day, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 9 PM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM."

On September 4, at 2 PM, the JTWC downgraded its rating to "LOW." On September 5, at 5 AM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 5 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) classified it as a tropical depression. On September 6, at 8 AM, the JMA issued a general warning. At 10 AM, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 PM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At the same time, the JMA issued a strong wind warning. At 8 PM, the JMA issued a gale warning.

On September 7, at 8 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Fengshen." At the same time, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 13W. At 2 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 8, at 5 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 9, at 8 PM, the JTWC issued its final warning. On September 10, at 2 PM, the JMA determined that Fengshen had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

In the post-analysis best track released by the JMA, Fengshen's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained winds near the center adjusted to 60 knots, and the central minimum pressure lowered to 975 hPa.

PAGASA: Luis  
On September 8, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
At 2 PM on September 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 10 PM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM."  
At midnight on September 11, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 2 AM, the JTWC classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the number 15W.  
At 2 AM on September 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) classified it as a tropical depression. At 9:15 AM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. At 2 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Kalmaegi." Simultaneously, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 9:45 AM on September 13, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon.  
At 2 AM on September 15, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 AM, the JTWC re-upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon.  
At 11 PM on September 16, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on September 17, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. At 11 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8 AM on September 18, the JMA downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Mario  
On September 13, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Guam. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W.  
At 9:00 AM on September 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 7:00 AM on September 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 4:00 AM on September 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 16W.  
At 2:00 AM on September 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Fung-wong." At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2:00 AM on September 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to an extratropical cyclone. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2:00 PM on September 23, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.  
At 8:00 AM on September 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Fung-wong had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Fung-wong's intensity was revised downward to a tropical storm, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 45 knots, and the minimum central pressure revised upward to 985 hPa.

On September 21, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea north of Chuuk. On the same day, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On September 22 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. On September 23 at 3 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." On September 24 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Kammuri." At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 17W. On September 25 at 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 27 at 5 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 29 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On September 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Kammuri had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Neneng  
On September 26, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the waters east of Kosrae. At 2 PM, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
On September 27, at 2 AM, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) classified it as a low-pressure area. At 6:30 AM, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH."  
On September 28, at 4:30 AM, the JTWC canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 PM, the JTWC reissued the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On September 29, at 2 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 18W. At 5 AM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. At 8 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Phanfone."  
On October 1, at 2 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon.  
On October 2, at 8 AM, the JTWC directly upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 2 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 8 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon.  
On October 3, at 8 PM, the JTWC once again upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  
On October 4, at 8 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon.  
On October 5, at 2 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon.  
On October 6, at 2 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 2 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. At 8 PM, the JMA determined that Phanfone had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Ompong  
On October 2, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the waters southwest of the Marshall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 1:00 AM on October 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating directly to "HIGH." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

At 2:00 AM on October 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 19W. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Vongfong."  

At 2:00 PM on October 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. On October 5, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 5:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon.  

At 8:00 AM on October 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it again to a Category 2 typhoon.  

At 8:00 AM on October 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  

At 2:00 AM on October 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon.  

At 2:00 PM on October 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  

At 2:00 AM on October 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon.  

At 8:00 AM on October 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

At 8:00 AM on October 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  

At 8:00 AM on October 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Vongfong had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.

PAGASA: Paeng Parrot is a massive and intense tropical cyclone, one of the strongest tropical cyclones of the Pacific typhoon season and globally that year. However, due to the system being far from land, its impact on land was minimal, mainly during its extratropical cyclone phase. The system originated from a large low-pressure area near Guam, and at 8 PM on October 28, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. The system developed into a tropical depression on October 30, became a tropical storm on October 31, and developed into a typhoon on November 1. The system underwent explosive intensification on November 2, rapidly clearing a small eye with a radius of less than 15 kilometers, and reached super typhoon intensity that evening, achieving its peak intensity early the next day. On November 3, the parrot began an eyewall replacement cycle, and its intensity gradually weakened. The parrot transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on November 7 and re-intensified to hurricane-force winds on the morning of November 8, with its pressure rapidly dropping to 924 hPa and a gale-force wind radius exceeding 3,300 kilometers, making it one of the largest storms in global history. The remnants of the extratropical cyclone Parrot brought a cold wave to North America, causing historically rare extreme cold weather during the same period.

PAGASA: Queenie On November 23, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 2 PM on November 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a low-pressure area. At 1 PM on November 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 21W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 AM on November 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Sinlaku." At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 PM on November 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 AM on November 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. In the best track analysis released afterward by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Sinlaku's intensity was revised downward to a tropical storm, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 45 knots.

PAGASA: Ruby On November 30, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Kosrae [14], and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a low-pressure area. At 9 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM."  

On December 1, at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH" [15]. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 22W [16]. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Hagupit" [17]. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm [18].  

On December 2, at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm [17]. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon [19].  

On December 3, at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon [17]. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon.  

On December 4, at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon, directly assigning it a rating of 155 knots [20].  

On December 5, at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  

On December 6, at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon.  

On December 7, at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon.  

On December 8, at 5 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm [17]. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm [21]. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm [17].  

On December 10, at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a severe tropical storm [17]. At 11 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm [17].  

On December 11, at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression [17]. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On December 12, at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning [22]. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered Hagupit to have gradually dissipated [23][24].

PAGASA: Seniang  
On December 23, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. On December 25, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory canceled the number. On December 26, the original tropical disturbance 98W redeveloped over the sea southwest of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the disturbance number 99W. On December 27 at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On December 28 at 2:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 23W. On December 29 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Jangmi." On December 30 at 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On December 31 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On January 1, 2015, at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On January 2 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Jangmi's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 40 knots and the minimum central pressure lowered to 996 hPa.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones considered tropical storms by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.

On March 11, 2014, a tropical disturbance formed over the sea east of Mindanao. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the evening of March 12 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Caloy On March 12, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Guam. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. On March 18 at 5:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On March 19 at 12:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On March 21 at 12:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 6:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." On March 22 at 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 04W. On March 23 at 4:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On March 24 at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 3:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On March 26 at 12:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating.

On April 13, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 10 PM on April 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 1 PM on April 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 PM on April 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "LOW." At 8 PM on April 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1 AM on April 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 PM on April 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled all ratings for it. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On August 19, 2014, the remnants of tropical disturbance 95W redeveloped over the coastal waters near Fujian. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 20 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had merged into a front and transformed into an extratropical cyclone.

On August 27, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the central South China Sea. At 10 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On August 28 at 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "LOW." On August 29 at 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On September 4, 2014, a cold-core low over the southeastern sea of Honshu transitioned into a warm-core system. At 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 8 a.m. on September 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had merged with a front and transformed into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Karding  
On August 30, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Guam. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W.  
At 9 PM on August 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low."  
On September 3, the low-pressure area passed through central Philippines, and the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that the low-pressure area had dissipated. However, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center maintained its rating as "low."  
At 8 AM on September 5, after the system entered the South China Sea, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that another low-pressure area had formed over the sea southwest of Luzon Island.  
At 2 AM on September 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert.  
At 2 PM on September 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 14W.  
At 2 AM on September 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.  
At 2 AM on September 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.
The following timeline lists the formation and dissipation times of typhoons this year, and details of each storm can be found in the sections above.

Tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Tokyo Typhoon Center in Japan (i.e., international naming). Once a tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, a name from the following list is used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting 10 names, arranged in alphabetical order based on the English name of the country. In the list of names used in 2014, the original "Bopha" was replaced with the new name "Ampil." [27] Names not used this year are shown in gray, and names already used in this year's typhoon season are in bold. Storm names for 2014 may overlap with some storm names from 2001 to 2002 and 2007 to 2008. Note:
The 47th session of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee decided to retire "Rammasun" due to the significant damage it caused in the Philippines and China.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list rotates every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2014, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all typhoons that were active in the Northwest Pacific in 2014. It includes the typhoon's intensity, duration, name, landfall locations, death toll, and total damages. All damages are measured in US dollars. The storm names in parentheses are the local names used by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration; unnamed tropical depressions are identified using storm numbers provided by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The formula for calculating ACE:

∑ v_max^2 / 10^4

Data is taken every 6 hours, with the unit being 10^4 kt^2. [31]

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴聖帕 (2013年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Sepat (English: Tropical Storm Sepat, International Number: 1322, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 21W) was the 20th named storm of the 2013 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Sepat" (Malay: Ikan Sepat) was provided by Malaysia and refers to a type of freshwater perch, a small fish often found in rivers, weed-filled swamps, or rice fields.

On September 27, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea west of Wake Island. In the early morning of the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 2:00 PM on September 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 3:25 PM on September 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a maritime gale warning. At 8:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1:30 AM on September 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 9:20 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Sepat. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 21W. At 5:00 PM on October 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM on October 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2:40 AM on October 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Sepat had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.
