Article_Name: 2013年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The 2013 Pacific typhoon season refers to any time during the year 2013 when tropical cyclones formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea. Although no specific timeframe was set for this typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to the waters of the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2013 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, with international numbers starting with 13xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in the region a number ending with the letter W.  

For tropical depressions that enter or form within the Philippine Area of Responsibility, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) assigns them a Philippine name for local warning purposes. Additionally, since China, Hong Kong, and Macau use the same translated names, and Taiwan may use different translated names, the same storm may have two different Chinese names and sometimes two different English names (international name and Philippine name). The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its strongest form during its existence.

The Director of the Hong Kong Observatory, Shun Chi-ming, stated on March 18 that it is expected that 4 to 7 tropical cyclones will enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong this year. Additionally, the Wetland Park, which is currently one of the reference anemometer stations for issuing No. 3 and No. 8 tropical cyclone warning signals, will be replaced by the Lau Fau Shan anemometer station.

According to the 2013 annual marine disaster forecast consultation opinions of the National Marine Environmental Forecasting Center of mainland China, it is expected that 24 to 27 tropical cyclones will form in the Northwest Pacific and South China Sea in 2013, slightly more than the average year. Among them, 7 to 9 are expected to make landfall along the coast, close to the average year. The main landfall areas will be along the coasts from East China to South China, with 1 to 2 more tropical cyclones affecting the East China Sea compared to the average year, and 2 to 3 tropical cyclones moving northward to affect the northern sea areas. [1]

Macau Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau Deputy Director Leong Ka Ching stated on April 10 that it is expected that 4 to 6 tropical cyclones will affect Macau this year, with 1 to 2 possibly requiring the issuance of Typhoon Signal No. 8. The tropical cyclones are expected to occur between late June and late September.

The Central Weather Bureau stated that sea temperatures are normal this year, and the summer will be hotter than in previous years, resulting in a higher number of typhoons forming. However, due to the weaker Pacific high-pressure system, the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan will be fewer, estimated at two to four. They are more likely to pass by the eastern or southern sides of Taiwan, but the accompanying southwest airflow should not be underestimated.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: PAGASA: Auring On December 31, 2012, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Yap Island. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On January 1, 2013, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:00 PM on January 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 9:25 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a marine strong wind warning. At 5:30 AM on January 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 01W. At 8:45 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Sonamu." At 11:00 AM on January 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:45 AM on January 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:50 PM on January 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:45 AM on January 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 AM on January 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. Sonamu was the earliest named tropical cyclone in the Northwest Pacific since 1979.

PAGASA: Crising  
On February 12, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the southeastern waters of Palau. On the same day, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 98W. On February 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 PM on February 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 PM on February 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1 AM on February 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 02W. At 10 AM on February 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a marine strong wind warning for it. At 9:10 AM on February 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the marine strong wind warning. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reissued the marine strong wind warning. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 9 AM on February 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Shanshan," making it the first typhoon named in February in the South China Sea. At 2:45 PM on February 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 AM on February 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Shanshan had gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Dante  
On June 5, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the waters east of the Philippines. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 98W.  
At 2:00 AM on June 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 2:00 AM on June 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "MEDIUM."  
At 6:00 AM on June 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "HIGH." At 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 10:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a marine strong wind warning. At 8:50 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 03W. At 9:20 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Mawar."  
At 5:00 AM on June 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 11:00 PM on June 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 12:30 AM on June 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center revised its report, further reducing its wind speed and issuing the final warning. At 2:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 9:00 AM on June 14, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 2:00 PM on June 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.

PAGASA: Emong  
On June 15, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the southeastern sea of the Philippines. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned the disturbance the designation 91W. At 4:00 AM on June 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

At 2:30 AM on June 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 3:15 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a marine strong wind warning. At 6:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "HIGH."  

At 5:00 AM on June 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 04W. At 9:20 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Leepi." At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

At 11:00 AM on June 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it again to a tropical storm.  

At 5:00 AM on June 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 8:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency indicated that Leepi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Fabian  
On June 19, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the central South China Sea. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 94W. At 7:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
On June 20, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a marine strong wind warning. At 12:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "HIGH." At 10:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 05W.  
On June 21, at 9:30 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Bebinca." At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On June 22, at 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On June 23, at 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  
On June 24, at 2:50 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Gorio  
On June 26, 2013, the previously decommissioned tropical disturbance 95W re-emerged over the southeastern Philippine Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it as disturbance 99W. On the morning of June 27 at 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. At 10:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "MEDIUM."  
On June 28 at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 4:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "HIGH." At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 06W. At 9:15 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Rumbia."  
On June 29 at 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 1 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 2:45 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On July 2 at 2:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8:45 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Huaning On July 5, 2013, a cold-core low pressure system over the western sea of Wake Island transitioned into a warm-core system. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 2 PM on July 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 9:30 AM on July 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a marine strong wind warning. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 10:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "HIGH." At 5 AM on July 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 07W. At 9:15 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Soulik." At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:50 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5 AM on July 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 5 AM on July 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it from a Category 2 typhoon to a Category 4 typhoon. At 11 AM on July 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2 AM on July 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. At 11:50 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:50 AM on July 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: On July 13, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the eastern sea of Palau. The United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 93W. At 4:00 AM on July 14, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2:00 AM on July 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 6:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded the development probability to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Simultaneously, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 AM on July 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 08W. At 9:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a maritime gale warning. At 9:30 AM on July 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Cimaron." At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 PM on July 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2:45 AM on July 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Jolina  
On July 26, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the central South China Sea. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 91W. At 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
On July 27, at 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the development probability to "LOW." At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.  
On July 28, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
On July 30, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM."  
On July 31, at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 4:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "HIGH." At 9:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Jebi." At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 09W. At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On August 2, at 2:50 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On August 3, at 2:45 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8:50 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
Subsequently, in the best track data released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, the wind speed of Jebi was revised down to 50 knots.

PAGASA: Kiko On July 31, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the central South China Sea. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 94W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW" at 2 PM that day. At 6:30 AM on August 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 PM on August 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 AM on August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 PM on August 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 10:25 AM on August 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency again upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 5 AM on August 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 10W. At 9:15 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Mangkhut." At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 AM on August 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 8:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Labuyo  
On August 8, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Guam. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 PM, the JTWC raised the development probability to "MEDIUM."  

At 12:30 AM on August 9, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 AM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. At 5 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 11W.  

At 3:05 AM on August 10, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Utor." At 5 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:45 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:50 PM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 11 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon.  

At 11 AM on August 11, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 5 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  

At 11 AM on August 12, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon.  

At 11 AM on August 13, the JTWC upgraded it again to a Category 3 typhoon. At 11 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon.  

At 5 PM on August 14, the JTWC downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8:55 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 PM, the JTWC issued its final warning.  

At 2:50 AM on August 15, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:45 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression.  

At 2 AM on August 19, the JMA finally classified it as a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Maring  
On August 14, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Taiwan. That evening, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. On August 16 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:20 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the sea. At 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 9:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM."  

On August 17 at 4:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 12W. On August 18 at 9:20 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Trami." At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On August 20 at 2:45 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On August 21 at 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. On August 22 at 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2:50 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 23 at 2:35 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

Subsequently, Pewa crossed the International Date Line into the Northwestern Pacific Ocean at 11 a.m. on August 18, prompting the Central Pacific Hurricane Center to issue its final advisory, with the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) taking over [5][6]. The JMA classified it as a severe tropical storm at 2 p.m. that afternoon [7]. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) classified it as a tropical storm [8]. On the 19th, Pewa improved its low-level circulation center (LLCC) due to favorable convergence and began developing an eye, leading the JTWC to adjust its intensity rating [9]. However, on the following day, Pewa was affected by increased wind shear on the northwestern side, causing the LLCC to become fully exposed, prompting both the JMA [10] and JTWC to downgrade the system's classification [11]. Although the wind shear on the northwestern side weakened on the 22nd and the LLCC was no longer exposed, Pewa's poor structure led the JTWC to downgrade it to a tropical depression at 5 a.m. on the 24th [12] and issue its final advisory at 11 a.m. on the 25th [13]. The JMA downgraded it at 8 p.m. on the 25th [14] and assessed that Pewa became a low-pressure area and gradually dissipated by the 27th [15].

On the afternoon of August 19, 2013, at 2:00 PM, Unala crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific region from the Central Pacific, and thus came under the jurisdiction of the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) for reporting. At 3:30 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical storm, retaining the Central Pacific name Unala. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, due to the influence of Typhoon Pewa, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. On August 20, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency further downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Nando  
On August 22, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the eastern sea of the Philippines. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W.  
At 2 PM on August 23, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 11 PM on August 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM."  
At 9:30 AM on August 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a high seas gale warning.  
At 11 AM on August 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 14W. At 3:15 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Kong-Rey." At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5:50 AM on August 27, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 8:50 AM on August 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 PM on August 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 2:50 AM on August 31, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Kong-Rey had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and continued to issue high seas gale warnings for it. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.

On August 30, 2013, an extratropical cyclone transformed into a low-pressure area over the sea north of Wake Island. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. That evening, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a general warning for it. On September 1 at 9:30 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Yutu." On the morning of September 2, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the disturbance number 97W. At 7 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On September 4 at 9 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 PM on September 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.

On August 31, 2013, the upper cloud system of Severe Tropical Storm Kong-Rey redeveloped over the northeastern waters of Taiwan. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the same evening, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 3:25 a.m. on September 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the sea area. At 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 5:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 15W. At 3:15 a.m. on September 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Toraji." At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:45 a.m. on September 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:35 a.m. on September 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency indicated that Toraji had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center stated that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and issued its final warning.

On September 10, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Guam. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of September 11, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. At 9:25 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the sea area. At 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 10:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On September 13, at 3:15 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Man-yi." At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 16W. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 14, at 8:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 15, at 2:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:50 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a severe tropical storm. On September 16, at 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8:40 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Man-yi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. Later, in the best track report released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Man-yi's wind speed was revised upward to 65 knots, its pressure was revised downward to 960 hPa, and it was considered to have reached typhoon status.

PAGASA: Odette  
On September 15, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the northeastern sea of the Philippines. At noon on the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned the disturbance the designation 99W. On September 16 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 9:30 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning for the sea. At 12:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it.  

On September 17 at 3:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Usagi." At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 17W. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On September 18 at 8:45 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:50 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon.  

On September 19 at 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center jumped it from a Category 2 typhoon to a Category 4 typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon, but in the post-event best track analysis, this upgrade was canceled.  

On September 20 at 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon.  

On September 21 at 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon.  

On September 22 at 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon and issued its final warning.  

On September 23 at 3:15 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 9:10 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3:10 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

On September 14, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the waters east of Guam. That evening, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 98W. On the morning of September 15 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On the morning of September 18 at 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating. At 6 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On the morning of September 19 at 5:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3:30 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the sea. On September 20 at 1 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On September 21 at 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 19W. At 3:20 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Pabuk." At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 22 at 2:50 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 23 at 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. On September 25 at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. On September 26 at 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. On September 27 at 8:50 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Pabuk had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. Subsequently, in the best track report issued by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Pabuk's pressure was revised downward to 965 hPa.

PAGASA: Zoraida On November 9, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the southeastern sea of Palau. On the same morning, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On November 10 at 3:30 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a maritime gale warning for it. At 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." On November 11 at 1 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert for it. On November 14 at 1 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reissued a tropical cyclone formation alert for it. At 9:15 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Yagi." At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 32W. On November 15 at 8:45 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones considered tropical storms by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.

PAGASA: Bising On January 5, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Palau. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. On January 6 at 7 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On January 7 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On January 8 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. On January 9 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On January 10 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a marine strong wind warning. On January 11 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." As it developed, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the previous wind warning at 8 PM. At 11 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded the low-pressure area that had entered its area of responsibility to a tropical depression, issued the first tropical cyclone advisory, named it Bising, and raised Signal No. 1. On January 12 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the development probability to "LOW." At 5 PM, the Philippine weather agency lifted all storm signals. On January 13 at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating. At 11 AM, the Philippine weather agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area and issued the final tropical cyclone advisory. Late that night into the early hours of the next day, 94W was completely absorbed into an extratropical cyclone.

On March 14, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea east of Yap Island. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. On the afternoon of March 20, at 4:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of March 21, at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On the morning of March 22, at 10:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.

On April 12, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea east of Kuantan. At 4:30 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:30 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On April 13, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. On April 15, 91W left the Northwest Pacific region's dedicated meteorological center's area of responsibility and entered the North Indian Ocean region's dedicated meteorological center's area of responsibility. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW," and later canceled the rating. On April 17, 91W "crossed back" from the Andaman Sea into the Gulf of Thailand, re-entering the Northwest Pacific region's dedicated meteorological center's area of responsibility. At 6:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "Medium." On April 18, at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.

On June 12, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the central South China Sea. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 99W. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 6 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On June 14 at 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 5 p.m., the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression, with near-center wind speeds of 16 m/s and a pressure of 994 hPa; some cities in Guangdong Province immediately issued a blue typhoon warning signal. On June 15, the Central Meteorological Observatory reported that it made landfall on the northeastern coast of Wenchang City, Hainan Province, at 4:50 p.m. At 8 p.m., the Central Meteorological Observatory ceased its designation.

On July 17, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the central South China Sea. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 94W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. On the morning of July 18, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a maritime gale warning. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." On July 19, at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the maritime gale warning. At 5:00 PM, the Central Meteorological Observatory stopped its designation. On July 20, at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the development probability to "LOW." At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. It subsequently weakened over the sea and dissipated.

On August 9, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the western sea of the Philippines. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 97W. At 2 a.m. on August 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 5:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m. on August 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating. On the same day, 97W gradually merged into Typhoon Utor.

On the morning of August 14, 2013, at 8:00 AM, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northwest of Guam. That evening, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. On the morning of August 16, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a general warning. At 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 9:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." 

At 3:25 AM on August 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a maritime gale warning for it. At 4:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 13W. 

At 5:00 AM on August 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 9:40 AM, the central pressure rose to 998 hPa (29.5 inches of mercury), and the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the maritime gale warning. 

In the early hours of August 19, 13W made landfall along the coast of Jiantiao Town, Sanmen County, Taizhou City, Zhejiang Province, China, with a central pressure rising to 1,002 hPa (29.6 inches of mercury). It quickly dissipated over land that morning. Additionally, the China Meteorological Administration did not recognize this tropical depression as having made landfall.

At 1:30 AM on August 21, 2013, 03C crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific region in the central Pacific, and thus came under the jurisdiction of the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA). At 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also classified it as a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.

On August 26, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the central South China Sea. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 8 a.m. on August 27, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 7:30 a.m. on August 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the development probability to "LOW." At 2 p.m. on August 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency considered 92W to be gradually dissipating.

On August 27, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northwest of Guam. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 7:30 a.m. on August 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 p.m. on August 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 2 p.m. on August 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the development probability to "LOW." At 8 a.m. on August 31, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered 93W to be gradually dissipating. At 8:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.

On September 6, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the central South China Sea. On the same day, the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 9:20 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a maritime gale warning. At 2:00 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 9:10 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the maritime gale warning. On September 7, at 2:00 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2:00 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.

On September 7, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Wake Island. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 8 a.m. on September 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression was gradually dissipating.

On September 16, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the central South China Sea. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the same morning, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 3:20 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the sea. On September 17, at 10:30 a.m., Vietnam's National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 18, at 4:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 3:25 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning and issued a strong wind warning for the sea. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 18W. On September 19, at 12:30 a.m., the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On September 21, at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that 18W was gradually dissipating.

On September 23, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea north of Wake Island. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression was gradually dissipating.

On the morning of October 1, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the sea east of Wake Island. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 a.m. on October 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the same morning, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 2 p.m. on October 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency indicated that 99W had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. That evening, gale-force winds appeared on the north side of 99W. At 2 p.m. on October 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 1 a.m. on October 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the "LOW" rating.

On October 17, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Guam. On the same morning, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 a.m. on October 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a maritime gale warning for it. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 27W. At 5 p.m. on October 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2 a.m. on October 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the maritime gale warning. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that 27W had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Wilma  
On the morning of October 31, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Guam. That evening, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W.  
At 6 PM on November 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 2 AM on November 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
At 8 AM on November 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency re-upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its development probability to "MEDIUM." At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 30W.  
At 6:45 AM on November 4, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded the low-pressure area that had entered its area of responsibility to a tropical depression, issued the first tropical cyclone advisory, and named it Wilma, raising Signal No. 1. At 3:30 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the sea. At 5 PM, the Philippine weather agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area, issued the final tropical cyclone advisory, and lifted Signal No. 1.  
At 11 PM on November 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on November 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory. At around 7 PM, it made landfall in southern Ninh Thuan Province, Vietnam. At 9:15 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning for the sea and issued a strong wind warning for the sea.  
At 2 AM on November 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the strong wind warning for the sea.  
At around 7 PM on November 8, 30W made landfall on the southern border of Thailand and exited to the sea from the southern border of Myanmar, leaving the area of responsibility of the Northwest Pacific Regional Specialized Meteorological Center and entering the area of responsibility of the North Indian Ocean Regional Specialized Meteorological Center.

On the morning of November 18, 2013, at 8 a.m., a tropical depression formed over the southern part of the South China Sea. On the same morning, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. On November 19 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it from a tropical depression. By 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it back to a tropical depression. On the morning of November 20, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the disturbance number 92W. On November 21 at 9:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." On November 22, this tropical depression exited the area of responsibility of the Northwest Pacific Regional Specialized Meteorological Center and entered the area of responsibility of the North Indian Ocean Regional Specialized Meteorological Center.

On December 2, 2013, a low-pressure area formed over the sea west of Guam. That evening, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. On the morning of December 3 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 33W. On the morning of December 4 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that 33W had gradually dissipated. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.
This year's Pacific typhoon season has 31 named tropical cyclones.

Tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency's Tokyo Typhoon Center. When a tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, names from the following list are used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting 10 names, arranged alphabetically by the English name of the country. In the name list used in 2013, the new name "Hato" replaced "Tianying." Names used in 2012 but not used this year are shown in gray, and names already used this year are in bold. The storm names for 2013 may overlap with some storm names from 2000 to 2001 and 2006 to 2007. Additionally, the Central Weather Bureau changed 38 typhoon translations starting from July 19, 2013. Note:

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) uses its own naming system for naming tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. Unlike the Japan Meteorological Agency, PAGASA assigns names to tropical cyclones as long as they indirectly affect the Philippines or surrounding countries, regardless of their intensity. The list of names is reused every four years, so this year's list is the same as the one used during the 2009 Pacific typhoon season. Unused names for this year are shown in gray, while names already used this year are in bold.

This list includes all typhoons that were active in the Western Pacific in 2013. It includes the typhoon's intensity, duration, name, landfall locations, fatalities, and damages. All damages are measured in US dollars. Cyclone names in parentheses are the local names used by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration; unnamed tropical depressions are identified by storm numbers provided by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The formula for calculating ACE:

∑ v_max^2 / 10^4

Data is taken every 6 hours, with the unit being 10^4 kt^2. [20]

Article_Name: 强烈熱帶風暴鴻雁 (2012年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Kirogi (International designation: 1212, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP132012) was the 12th named storm of the 2012 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Kirogi" (Korean: 개리) was provided by North Korea, meaning a migratory bird that flies to Korea in autumn and migrates northward in early spring.

On August 3, 2012, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the tropical disturbance 90W located over the sea east of Minamitorishima to a tropical depression. On August 4, 2012, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning, predicting it would strengthen into a tropical storm; on the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On August 5, 2012, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 13W. However, on August 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to an extratropical cyclone. Until August 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center did not downgrade it and continued to issue reports, further increasing the wind speed to 45 knots. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning but did not classify it as a tropical cyclone. However, at 9 a.m. on August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency directly upgraded it to a tropical storm, named it Haikui, and assigned it the international designation 1212. On the afternoon of August 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm, but downgraded it to a tropical storm later that evening. At 2:40 p.m. on August 10, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone while still over the sea east of Hokkaido, Japan, without making landfall. The Central Meteorological Observatory also stated at 3 p.m. that Haikui had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and ceased its designation at 2 p.m.

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Sanvu (English: Severe Tropical Storm Sanvu, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP032012, International Number: 1202) was the second named storm of the 2012 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Sanvu" was provided by Macau and refers to a hard substance commonly used in jewelry.

On May 21, 2012, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the tropical disturbance 94W located in the western Pacific to a tropical depression. On the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also issued a tropical cyclone warning and upgraded it to 03W. On May 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the number 1202, and named it Sanvu. On May 23, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm and further upgraded it to a typhoon the following day. On May 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On May 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Sanvu had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.
On May 25th, the eye of Coral passed over Iwo Jima, with continuous rainfall in the area.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Noru (English: Tropical Storm Noru, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 16W, International Number: 1113) was the 13th named storm of the 2011 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Noru" was provided by South Korea and refers to a type of deer, which is gentle in nature, small in size, and lives in the wild forests. [1]

On September 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated this tropical disturbance as MEDIUM. At 10:00 (UTC) on the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to HIGH and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 22:00, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 3 at 17:00, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 16W. At 15:00 (UTC) on the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the number 1113, and named it Omais. On September 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Omais had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Merbok (English: Severe Tropical Storm Merbok, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP122011, International Number: 1110) was the 10th named storm of the 2011 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Merbok" was provided by Malaysia, referring to a type of bird favored by Malaysians, a spotted-neck dove commonly found in the countryside and wastelands. [1]

On August 2, a tropical disturbance formed at 162°E longitude and 23°N latitude, rated as Medium by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM the same day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Khanun, while the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Khanun to a tropical depression and issued the first report. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Khanun to a tropical storm. It is likely to continue strengthening into a severe tropical storm, tending to dissipate over the sea, with a chance of affecting Russia's Pacific islands. On August 5, the storm intensified into a severe tropical storm. On August 10, the storm transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Article_Name: 颱風馬勒卡 (2010年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Malakas (English: Typhoon Malakas; International designation: 1012; JTWC: 13W) is one of the tropical cyclones of the 2010 Pacific typhoon season. The name was provided by the Philippines, meaning strong and powerful.

On September 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reported the formation of a tropical depression, subsequently designated as 13W. On September 21, 13W intensified into a tropical storm near the Northern Mariana Islands and was named "Malakas" by the Japan Meteorological Agency. Initially, Malakas moved slowly westward under the influence of a subtropical high-pressure system to its north. Later, the subtropical high weakened and retreated eastward due to the influence of a westerly trough. Malakas absorbed the warm seawater from the weak point of the subtropical high, prompting the Japan Meteorological Agency to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center even briefly upgraded it to a typhoon, but downgraded it the next day (later upgrading it again when Malakas moved significantly northward). After being upgraded by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Malakas nearly stalled near the Iwo Jima area in Japan. On September 23, Malakas began moving significantly northward, rapidly intensifying into a typhoon after passing through the waters near Iwo Jima. On September 24, after entering the westerlies, it was further upgraded to a severe typhoon by the Hong Kong Observatory, with its eye becoming notably large. At 6:50 PM on September 25, Malakas transitioned into an extratropical cyclone over the waters east of Honshu, Japan. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued its final warning, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also issued its final warning at noon on September 26. Subsequently, in the best track analysis released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Malakas' wind speed was revised upward to 85 knots, and its pressure was revised downward to 945 hPa.

On the night of September 24, the eye of Typhoon Malakas approached the southeastern sea area of Honshu, bringing heavy rain to the southeastern part of Honshu, Japan, through its associated outer rainbands.
