Article_Name: 2017年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2017 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2017. Although no official timeframe is set for the typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to the waters of the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2017 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) with international names and are assigned international numbers starting with 17xx. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter "W." Tropical depressions that enter or form within the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) are given local names by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (with the international name being the official one). Additionally, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau may differ from those used in Taiwan. The information for each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak intensity during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

The Hong Kong Observatory (HKO) reported the latest developments of the observatory on March 23, 2017, indicating that 2016-2017 was one of the warmest winters on record since 1884. The observatory predicted that the annual rainfall would be normal to below normal, with four to seven tropical cyclones entering within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong, a number close to the normal level. However, during June to August of that year, four consecutive storms directly hit Hong Kong, prompting the observatory to issue tropical cyclone warning signals of No. 8 or above, far exceeding expectations. As a result, the observatory revised its forecast in late August to six to nine tropical cyclones, reaching the normal level.

Lau Ying Wai, Senior Technical Officer and Meteorological Consultant of the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau (Portuguese: SMG), stated during the tropical cyclone prevention meeting held by the government civil defense structure on April 5 that it is expected that 5 to 7 tropical cyclones will affect Macao this year, with the first and last tropical cyclones anticipated to appear in mid-June and late September, respectively. This year, 5 to 7 tropical cyclones are expected to affect Macao, and all agencies and departments within the civil defense structure must remain vigilant and carry out prevention and publicity work.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (CWB) presented the 2017 weather outlook and risk assessment at the 3531st Executive Yuan meeting on January 12, predicting that 3 to 4 typhoons would hit Taiwan during the summer, and the formation of the first typhoon in the Northwest Pacific would occur earlier than the previous year. On June 26, the Central Weather Bureau held a typhoon outlook press conference, forecasting that 3 to 5 typhoons would hit Taiwan during the summer, with the climate average being 3.6. The total number of typhoons forming in the western North Pacific was estimated to be about 21 to 25, close to the climate average of 23.1. Lu Guochen, director of the Weather Forecast Center, stated that the climate this year is normal, with a low likelihood of El Niño or La Niña events. Therefore, the formation and impact of typhoons this year are also expected to be normal. Regarding the intensity of typhoons hitting Taiwan, he mentioned that there is a 70% to 80% chance of them being of moderate typhoon strength or higher, and the possibility of autumn typhoons cannot be ruled out, reminding the public to prepare for typhoon prevention.

The China National Marine Forecast Center predicted that 11 to 13 typhoons in the Northwest Pacific and South China Sea would affect China's seas in 2017, with 6 to 7 typhoons making landfall on China's southeastern coast. Additionally, according to the Fujian Meteorological Bureau's forecast on April 11, 6 to 7 tropical cyclones would affect Fujian Province during the typhoon season (June to September), with 1 to 2 typhoons possibly making landfall or severely impacting Fujian Province in the summer.
The Philippine PAGASA predicts that 8-12 tropical cyclones will enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility from April to September this year.

The Vietnam Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center predicts that ENSO will transition to El Niño in the second half of this year. The typhoon season will become increasingly evident in the latter half of the year, with an estimated 13-15 storms entering the South China Sea, of which about 3-4 are expected to directly or indirectly affect Vietnam.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content:
PAGASA: Dante  
In mid to late April 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Chuuk near the equator. Although this low-pressure area formed over the open ocean, its center was initially very disorganized. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W at 9 a.m. on the 20th of the same month, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 8 a.m. on the 21st. With the assistance of high atmospheric pressure, low wind shear, and relatively high sea temperatures, the low-pressure area began to consolidate, and its structure became more organized. Major weather agencies predicted its movement path to be west-northwest, with some agencies optimistic about its development and intensity, while others were less so.  

The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression at 8 p.m. on the 23rd, followed by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raising its rating to "medium" at 4 a.m. on the 24th and then to "high" at 1 p.m. the same day. Benefiting from favorable environmental conditions nearby, the low-pressure area continued to develop. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 03W at 2 a.m. on April 25, while the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for Tropical Depression 03W at 8 a.m. the same day. As Tropical Depression 03W rapidly developed and intensified, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm at 2 a.m. on April 26, and the Japan Meteorological Agency followed suit at 8 a.m., upgrading it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 1701, and naming the tropical cyclone "Muifa," making it the first named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season.  

Although the tropical storm was named, major weather agencies were not optimistic about its subsequent intensity development and predicted it would change direction, shifting from west-northwest to north and then to east-northeast, due to the influence of the eastward-moving westerly trough. As expected, "Muifa" moved along the weak point of the subtropical ridge southeast of Japan, gradually moving toward the westerly trough and slowly weakening. As "Muifa" weakened, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression at 8:50 p.m. on April 27, with the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issuing its final warning at 5 a.m. the next day. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 8 p.m. on the 29th. Finally, "Muifa" dissipated over the open ocean east of the Philippines, with some of its cloud systems merging into an extratropical cyclone.

Merbok was the second named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 04W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. It was also the first tropical cyclone to impact the South China region that year. After the formation of Muifa in April, the Northwest Pacific remained calm throughout May until a low-pressure area developed in central Philippines in June. It intensified into a severe tropical storm, named Merbok, and crossed the South China Sea towards eastern Guangdong, eventually moving inland and gradually dissipating.

PAGASA: Emong, also known as Nanmadol, was the third named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 05W. Initially identified as disturbance 98W, it was later reclassified as 99W. It moved northwestward from the waters east of the Philippines to the waters east of Taiwan, gradually intensifying into a severe tropical storm before turning northeastward. Its first landfall was in Nagasaki City, Nagasaki Prefecture, Japan; the second landfall was in Uwajima City, Ehime Prefecture; and the third landfall was in Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture. Ultimately, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Talas was the fourth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 06W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Talas originated from a monsoon depression, and initially, some weather agencies predicted it would merge with a tropical disturbance near the Philippines and strike the Pearl River Delta. However, it eventually developed independently and intensified into a severe tropical storm. It made landfall in Vietnam's Nghe An Province at 2:10 a.m. on July 17. After landfall, its intensity rapidly weakened due to the frictional effects of the terrain, and it dissipated on July 18. Although it had dissipated, the trailing airflow brought heavy rain to the northern South China Sea and the coastal areas of South China.

Olu was the fifth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 07W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of the 19th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Olu to a tropical depression, at which time it was over the sea 2,000 kilometers southeast of Japan. Six hours later, authorities issued a gale warning, and subsequently, on the morning of the 21st, it was upgraded to a tropical storm, given the international designation 1705, and named Olu. On the afternoon of the 23rd, it began to be influenced by Tropical Storm Rose and took a southeastward path, while also starting to intensify rapidly. Between the 25th and 27th, it gradually absorbed Rose and resumed a westward path, with its intensity significantly decreasing. On the evening of the 27th, it shifted to a southwestward movement, approaching the Ogasawara Islands. From the night of the 30th to the 31st, it intensified rapidly again to reach the strength of a Category 5 hurricane, weakening to a typhoon on August 5 and making landfall on Yakushima, Japan. On the morning of August 8, although its structure had already become loose, it still affected northern Japan. In the Joint Typhoon Warning Center's best track data, Olu's maximum wind speed was downgraded from 140 knots (equivalent to a Category 5 hurricane) to 135 knots (equivalent to a Category 4 hurricane).

Rose was the sixth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 09W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. As Mawar intensified, a baroclinic system west of the International Date Line gradually transformed into a low-pressure area on the morning of the 19th, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 97W at 9 a.m. The low-level circulation center of this low-pressure area was partially exposed to the west due to dry air intrusion and vertical wind shear, but its eastern outflow channel continued to improve, and the warm sea surface provided sufficient energy. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded this low-pressure area to a tropical depression at 2 a.m. on the 20th, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 5 a.m.

In the afternoon, its deep convection gradually filled the previously exposed eastern side of the low-level circulation center, forming a broader low-level circulation center. Its extratropical cyclone characteristics also gradually weakened. As the system was located under a strong upper-level low-pressure area, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium" at 2 p.m. and classified the system as a subtropical depression. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning at 3:30 p.m., indicating the possibility of intensifying into a tropical storm within a day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system to a subtropical storm at 8 a.m. on the 21st, then raised its rating to "high" at 1:30 p.m. and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency officially upgraded the tropical depression to a tropical storm at 3:15 p.m., naming it Rose and assigning it the international number 1706. The China Meteorological Administration followed suit at 3:48 p.m. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center subsequently classified the system as a tropical storm at 5 p.m., designating it as Tropical Cyclone 09W.

Initially influenced by a deep subtropical ridge, Rose moved northward before shifting westward on the morning of the 22nd, approaching Tropical Cyclone Mawar and developing a "pinhole eye" in the afternoon. In the evening, Rose moved into cooler waters, and its subtropical characteristics re-emerged. Temperature scanning systems indicated that Rose developed partial cold-core structures, suggesting it was a "hybrid system." Its low-level circulation center was exposed again, with upper-level convection nearly dissipated, though low-level clouds continued to spiral into the center. By the 24th, it formed a central dense overcast area. On the 25th, Rose began interacting with Mawar, whose outflow caused strong vertical wind shear on Rose, leading to significant weakening. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Rose to a tropical depression at 5 p.m. and 9 p.m., respectively, with the latter issuing its final warning at 11 a.m. on the 26th. Rose moved counterclockwise around Mawar and was fully absorbed into Mawar's circulation by midnight on the 28th.

PAGASA: Fabian, Roke is the seventh named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 10W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Following the appearances of Nesat and Haitang, another disturbance emerged over the waters southeast of Eluanbi. On July 21 at 12:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Roke to a tropical depression. On the afternoon of the 22nd at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and subsequently named it Roke. Afterward, it continued moving northwest toward the South China Sea and made landfall near Sai Kung East Country Park in Hong Kong. As it moved over Shenzhen, it rapidly weakened due to terrain disruption.

Sanka was the eighth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 08W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Shortly after Talas dissipated, a low-pressure area formed in the central Philippine Sea on July 19, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. Initially, major agencies believed Sanka would develop further, with a chance of making landfall near the Pearl River Estuary. However, predictions later changed, forecasting it to move toward Hainan Island as a tropical depression. Initially, it had strong convection, but after entering the southern South China Sea, its intensity began to weaken due to high wind shear and low sea temperatures. However, as it moved to the central South China Sea, it strengthened again, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression at 11 a.m. on July 21. Although it redeveloped, its intensity did not significantly increase and it lingered near the waters off Hainan Island, even exhibiting a slight Fujiwhara effect with Roke. After Roke moved inland into Shenzhen, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Sanka at 3 p.m. on July 23. Subsequently, it made landfall in Quang Binh Province, Vietnam, at 4:30 p.m. on July 25. By 8 p.m., as it moved further into Laos, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression due to land friction.

PAGASA: Gorio Nesat is the ninth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 11W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Nesat to a tropical depression at 3 PM on the 25th and issued a gale warning six hours later. At 11 AM on the 26th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. On the morning of the 28th, various agencies adjusted its path westward, indicating it would head directly toward Taiwan. At 7:10 PM on the 29th, it made landfall in Su'ao Township, Yilan County, Taiwan, and at 10:30 PM the same evening, it exited into the Taiwan Strait from Zhunan Township, Miaoli County. On the morning of the 30th, it made landfall in Fuzhou, Fuqing City, Fujian, and weakened into a severe tropical storm, continuing to weaken on the same day.

PAGASA: Huaning (Nesat) is the 10th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 12W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On July 26 at 4 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned disturbance number 92W to a low-pressure area that formed northeast of the Paracel Islands. The next day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Nesat to a tropical depression at 2 p.m. On July 28, as its structure gradually improved, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert at 5 a.m., later upgrading it to a tropical depression at 3 p.m. and assigning it the tropical cyclone number 12W. The following day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. On the afternoon of July 30 at 4:30 p.m., it made landfall in Fenggang, Fangshan, Pingtung, Taiwan. At 12:30 a.m. on July 31, it exited into the sea from Fangyuan, Changhua. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a remnant low-pressure system.

Nesat was the eleventh named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 13W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of August 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. It weakened and dissipated on August 6.

The banyan tree was the twelfth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 14W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The banyan tree formed on August 10 in the northwest Pacific, moved northwest, and gradually strengthened. It began to weaken on the evening of the 15th and dissipated on August 17.

PAGASA: Typhoon Hato was the 13th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 15W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Hato formed on the afternoon of August 20, with the Japan Meteorological Agency assigning it the international designation 1713. Benefiting from the favorable environment of the Luzon Strait and the South China Sea, along with reduced vertical wind shear and warm sea waters that stored energy for nearly a month, it began to intensify rapidly. At this time, satellite imagery revealed the gradual development of an eye structure at its center. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded its intensity from the upper limit of a tropical storm to the upper limit of a severe tropical storm at 2:50 PM, and further upgraded it to a typhoon at 11:40 PM. That night, it slowed down again before resuming a steady west-northwest path by early morning on the 23rd, heading directly toward the area west of the Pearl River Estuary. At noon on the 23rd, it passed over the waters near the Pearl River Estuary and made landfall south of Zhuhai, Guangdong, at 12:50 PM, gradually weakening thereafter. Supported by an active southwest monsoon, its weakening slowed as it crossed the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region on the 24th. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression at 2:40 PM.

PAGASA: Jolina Paka was the 14th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 16W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On August 23, Paka formed as a tropical depression over the waters east of the Philippines, with the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigning it the disturbance number 96W. On August 24, it continued to develop with a well-organized structure. At 8 PM, the China Meteorological Administration first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 AM on the 25th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Paka, assigning it the international number 1714. On the evening of the 25th, it crossed central Luzon, where its intensity temporarily weakened due to the terrain of Luzon, before entering the central South China Sea the following morning. After entering the South China Sea, its movement speed significantly increased, moving northwestward at approximately 30 kilometers per hour, heading directly towards the area west of the Pearl River Estuary, and re-strengthening. Paka made landfall along the southeastern coast of Taishan, Guangdong, around 9 AM. It subsequently weakened into a tropical storm, moved into the inland region of Guangxi by the evening, and dissipated on the 28th.

Coral was the 15th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 17W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On August 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Coral to a tropical storm. On August 30, various meteorological agencies upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On August 31, it was gradually upgraded to a typhoon by various meteorological agencies. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Mawar was the sixteenth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 18W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the afternoon of August 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Mawar to a tropical depression. At 3 a.m. on September 1, it was upgraded to a tropical storm. It dissipated on September 4.

PAGASA: Kiko (Gu Chao) was the 17th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 19W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of September 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Gu Chao to a tropical depression. On September 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it back to a tropical depression. On September 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency indicated in the weather chart that it had merged into a frontal system.

PAGASA: Lannie (Talim) is the 18th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 20W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On September 9, it was confirmed by the Japan Meteorological Agency to have intensified into Talim. At 2 a.m. on September 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 9 a.m. on the same day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 15, it began to weaken. On September 18, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Maring Doksuri was the 19th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 21W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. At 3 a.m. on September 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Doksuri to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning six hours later. On September 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to Tropical Depression 21W. That evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, naming it Doksuri and assigning it the international designation 1719. After being named, it began to intensify. On the afternoon of September 15, it made landfall in Vietnam and quickly weakened, completely dissipating by September 16.

PAGASA: Odette Kanu was the 20th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 24W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. At 12:40 AM on October 13, Kanu made landfall in Santa Ana, Cagayan, Philippines, shortly went out to sea, continued moving towards the coast of mainland China, and intensified. On October 15, it made landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula and weakened. On October 16, it lingered in the Gulf of Tonkin, soon weakened into a tropical depression, and completely dissipated the following day.

PAGASA: Paolo Lan is the 21st named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 25W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and classified as a "super large" typhoon by the Japan Meteorological Agency. Influenced by a strong subtropical high-pressure ridge, there was a lull in the typhoon season in the Northwest Pacific from late September to early October, until the subtropical high-pressure ridge shifted northward, allowing tropical disturbances to redevelop in the Northwest Pacific. On October 11, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned disturbance number 91W to a low-pressure system near the Chuuk Islands. The combination of warm sea temperatures and weak wind shear facilitated the development of this disturbance, and on October 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to Tropical Depression 25W. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm the next day and named it, with other meteorological agencies following suit. On October 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On the morning of October 20, Lan's cloud-filled eye expanded into a large eye, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center indicated that Lan had entered a phase of rapid intensification. On the afternoon of October 20, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded Lan to a severe typhoon. At 2 a.m. on October 21, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center simultaneously upgraded Lan to a super typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a very strong typhoon at 8 a.m. On October 22 at 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded Lan to a moderate typhoon. At 3 a.m. on October 23, it made landfall in Kakegawa City, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded Lan to a mild typhoon, and at 2 p.m., the bureau determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Lan's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center increased from 95 knots (175 km/h) to 100 knots (185 km/h), and the central minimum pressure lowered from 925 hPa to 915 hPa.

PAGASA: Quedan (Saola) was the 22nd named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 27W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The Japan Meteorological Agency analyzed it as a low-pressure area at 9 a.m. on the 19th and later analyzed it as a tropical disturbance at 3 p.m. on the same day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert at 5:30 a.m. on October 19, designating it as Tropical Depression 27W, and subsequently upgraded it to a tropical storm. On the evening of October 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:25 a.m. on October 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. On October 24, it was upgraded to a tropical storm and named Saola. At 12:50 p.m. on October 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Ramil (Damrey) was the 23rd named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 28W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
At 9 a.m. on October 31, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the same day, at 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. On November 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Damrey. On the evening of November 2, various agencies upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At noon on November 3, it was upgraded to a typhoon by various agencies. On the morning of November 4, it made landfall in Vietnam and gradually weakened. At 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Salome, Hai Kui is the 24th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 30W. The Japan Meteorological Agency marked it as a tropical depression on the weather map at 8 a.m. on the 9th. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the designation Tropical Depression 30W. It was expected to gradually strengthen after entering the South China Sea and head towards the Hainan Island area. On the same day at 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the number 1724 and naming it Hai Kui. On November 12 at 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression and considered it to have completely dissipated a day later.

PAGASA: Tino (Haikui) is the 25th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 31W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. This tropical depression entered the South China Sea and gradually intensified. On November 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Haikui, with the designation 1725. It entered the central South China Sea in the afternoon of the 18th. At 3 a.m. on November 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Haikui to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Urduja (Kai-tak) was the 26th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 32W. Kai-tak formed on December 12. It then crossed the central Philippine islands and southwestern Palawan Island.  
On December 19, it moved southwestward across the southern South China Sea, heading toward the southern Malay Peninsula and Singapore area. On the morning of December 22 at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Kai-tak to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Vinta (Tembin) is the 27th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 33W. On December 21, Tembin rapidly intensified into a severe tropical storm. Initially moving southwestward, it later shifted westward and made landfall on Mindanao Island in the Philippines in the evening. On December 22, it weakened into a tropical storm due to the influence of land terrain and crossed Mindanao Island to reach the Sulu Sea in the evening, moving westward toward Palawan Island and the South China Sea. On the evening of December 23, as its center passed near the southwestern coast of Palawan Island, it absorbed moisture and heat from the Sulu Sea, causing its cloud system to expand, deep convection to intensify, and the development of an eye-like feature. On December 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Tembin to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Agaton Bolaven is a tropical cyclone that spanned two years (2017 Pacific typhoon season to 2018 Pacific typhoon season). Its original low-pressure area formed on December 21, 2017, south of the Marshall Islands at low latitudes, and was assigned the disturbance number 98W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. However, the designation was later removed due to unfavorable development conditions. The low-pressure area redeveloped on December 28, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the disturbance number 99W. On December 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency marked this system as a tropical depression on its weather map. Subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 01W on January 2, 2018, and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm on January 3, naming it Bolaven. Bolaven thus became the first tropical cyclone of 2018 and was also the third earliest recorded storm in the Northwest Pacific to form and be named. However, after entering the South China Sea, its development was hindered by lower sea temperatures in the region, and the system eventually dissipated in the central South China Sea.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones assessed as tropical storms or tropical depressions by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, but only classified as tropical depressions by the Japan Meteorological Agency.

PAGASA: Auring, disturbance number 96W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, was designated as Tropical Depression 01W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
On January 7, 2017, a low-pressure area formed east of the Philippines and developed into the first tropical cyclone of 2017 the following day, receiving the tropical cyclone designation 01W from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Computer numerical prediction models accurately forecasted that it would pass over the Philippines and enter the South China Sea, though there was an error in intensity prediction. It weakened into a low-pressure area as it lingered over the Philippines, cut off from moisture supply for an extended period. However, after entering the South China Sea, it was able to rebuild its cloud bands, but vertical wind shear caused its intensity to fluctuate between a low-pressure area and a tropical depression. Subsequently, the northeast monsoon brought dry air, causing it to weaken significantly. It then made landfall in Vietnam and quickly moved out to sea but failed to reorganize, eventually dissipating near the Gulf of Thailand.

PAGASA: Bising US Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 98W → 99W.  
On January 31, 2017, a low-pressure area formed in the waters east of the Philippines, and the US Naval Research Laboratory assigned it disturbance number 98W. At that time, it was guided by the equatorial anticyclone and influenced by the northeast monsoon, developing slowly. However, under conditions of weak vertical wind shear, warm sea temperatures, and good upper-level divergence, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 2 PM on February 2, and upgraded it to "medium" at 2 PM the following day. Due to its convection becoming active, the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded it to a tropical depression and immediately issued a gale warning, indicating it would strengthen into a tropical storm within a day. However, on the 5th, vertical wind shear in the area significantly increased, exposing its low-level circulation center and dissipating its convection. The Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating back to "low" at 2 PM, and further canceled the rating at 2 PM on the 6th. The US Naval Research Laboratory also canceled its disturbance number. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency maintained its classification as a tropical depression, predicting it would remain stationary. As the northeast monsoon weakened, it became more favorable for it to absorb sea energy and gradually repair its low-level circulation center. The US Naval Research Laboratory assigned it a new disturbance number, 99W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as "low" at 2 PM on the 7th. Affected by an extratropical cyclone, it gradually weakened, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating again at 2 PM on the 8th. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 8 AM.

U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 91W.  
On the afternoon of March 17, 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the waters south of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 91W. At 2 p.m. on March 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of March 21 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m. on March 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it again to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Crising, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 92W, was designated as Tropical Depression 02W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
02W was a relatively weak tropical cyclone, but the heavy rains it brought caused disasters in the Philippines. After crossing the Philippines, it entered the South China Sea, where it was temporarily affected by dry air and vertical wind shear. Later, supported by moist air, it re-intensified several times, but after passing through the Luzon Strait, it weakened and dissipated again due to vertical wind shear.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 97W.  
On the morning of June 22, 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the northeastern waters of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it disturbance number 97W. At noon on June 22, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," raised it to "medium" on the 24th, and further to "high" at noon on June 25, simultaneously issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert, which was canceled at 5 a.m. the next day. Subsequently, its rating was downgraded to "medium" and "low," and the rating was canceled at 2 p.m. on the 28th. At 8 a.m. on June 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, at which time it was located over the waters east of Taiwan. In the early hours of June 30, it crossed the waters near Okinawa and entered the East China Sea, where its low-level circulation center was no longer clear on radar images. On July 1, it reorganized, causing strong winds, heavy rain, and lightning near Yakushima and Tanegashima in the early hours. After making consecutive landfalls on the two islands, its low-level circulation center was once again disrupted. It then moved northward along the coast of Kyushu, catching the jet stream.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 90W → 91W.  
After Severe Tropical Storm Nanmadol, another low-pressure area formed in the waters east of the Philippines and was assigned disturbance number 90W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, which was later canceled. On the morning of July 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, and on the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it a new disturbance number, 91W. At 4:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," but by 3 AM the next day, it was directly upgraded to "high," and a tropical cyclone formation alert was issued simultaneously, indicating a higher likelihood of it strengthening into a tropical depression within the next day and moving toward the waters east of Taiwan. After crossing the waters east of Taiwan and entering the East China Sea, it showed no signs of intensification, so the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its 24-hour tropical cyclone formation probability to "medium" at 3 AM on the 7th and canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert. By 2 PM, it was further downgraded, and the Japan Meteorological Agency also downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On the afternoon of July 12, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated a low-pressure area formed in the northwest waters of Iwo Jima as Disturbance 93W. The next day, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "medium" at 2 p.m. However, as it moved to higher latitude regions where the environment was unfavorable for tropical cyclone development, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the related assessment at 4 a.m. on the 15th, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 2 p.m. the following afternoon. It eventually transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 93W → 96W. On the morning of July 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded a low-pressure area near the International Date Line to a tropical depression [55]. Three hours later, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it disturbance number 93W. As it gradually moved southeast, the surrounding environment caused its warm system to gradually turn cold, and the U.S. Ocean Prediction Center classified it as a subtropical cyclone at 8 PM [56][57].  
On July 29, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it disturbance number 96W, and the U.S. Ocean Prediction Center continued to classify it as a subtropical storm [58][59]. At 10 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone [60].

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 98W was upgraded to a tropical depression by the Japan Meteorological Agency at 2 a.m. on the 26th, but soon dissipated and merged into the circulation of Pakhar.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 90W.  
On the afternoon of August 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression at 6 PM and issued a gale warning three hours later.  
On the afternoon of August 29, at 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area and canceled the gale warning.

PAGASA: Nando, designated as disturbance 90W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, was classified as Tropical Depression 22W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
A low-pressure area formed near the waters off Luzon in late September and gradually developed after moving into the northern South China Sea. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On September 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, with a central minimum pressure of 1002 hPa. Subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number "22W." It moved quickly west-northwest at a speed of about 30 km/h, interacting with the northeast monsoon, which strengthened winds along the Guangdong coast. The China National Meteorological Center reported that it made landfall in Wanning City, Hainan Province, at 9:20 PM on September 24. It then crossed the Beibu Gulf and began moving toward northern Vietnam, gradually weakening. It made landfall in Quang Ninh Province, Vietnam, at 2 PM on September 25 and dissipated on September 26.  
As the low-pressure area in the northern South China Sea intensified into a tropical depression, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 11:10 PM on September 23. Under the combined influence of its outer rainbands and easterly airflow, some areas in Hong Kong recorded over 20 mm of rainfall, and offshore areas experienced strong winds on the 12th. Among the Observatory's eight reference automatic weather stations, Cheung Chau recorded strong winds, and later Cheung Chau Beach experienced near gale-force winds. During this period, an incident occurred where a sudden voltage drop trapped 17 people in an elevator for about an hour before being rescued by firefighters. All tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 7:20 PM, with the system located about 520 km southwest of Hong Kong at the time. Under its influence, some offshore and highland areas recorded strong winds.  
Meanwhile, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted the No. 1 Signal at midnight on September 24, with the tropical depression located about 570 km south-southeast of Macao at the time. Strong winds were consistently recorded on the three major bridges during the day. The Meteorological Bureau updated a "Special Report" at 12:30 PM, advising drivers to exercise caution due to occasional strong winds and gusts on the bridges. All signals were lowered at midnight on September 25, with the signal duration lasting exactly one day. At that time, the system was located about 480 km southwest of Macao.  
Typhoon blue warnings were issued in Hainan, Guangdong, and Guangxi. Due to heavy rainfall, the China Meteorological Administration issued a yellow rainstorm warning for southern regions, with some areas experiencing up to 140 mm of precipitation. It made landfall in Quang Ninh Province, Vietnam, at 2 PM on September 25 and dissipated in northern Vietnam on the 26th. The heavy rains it caused triggered landslides, but fortunately, there were no casualties. The Vietnam Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center recorded 150 mm of rainfall in Hanoi, and waves as high as 3 meters (9.8 feet) were observed in Ha Long Bay.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 97W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as Tropical Depression 23W.  
On October 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, and at 8 PM the same evening, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 5 AM on October 9, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning.  
At 5:50 AM on October 10, it made landfall in Ha Tinh Province, Vietnam, and dissipated that evening.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 94W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigned it the number Tropical Depression 26W.  
A day later, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on it, and shortly after, it merged into Lan's circulation.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 95W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as Tropical Depression 29W. On the morning of October 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM on November 1, a maritime strong wind warning was issued, but it was canceled by 2 AM the next day as it failed to develop due to the influence of Typhoon Damrey. On November 3, it made landfall on the Malay Peninsula and gradually moved away from the Gulf of Thailand into the Andaman Sea, after which the Japan Meteorological Agency ceased tracking it. However, it later interacted with the remnants of Damrey through the Fujiwhara effect and returned to the Gulf of Thailand, at which point the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a low-pressure area.

The northern part of the Malay Peninsula was affected by it, bringing 15 hours of continuous storms to Penang starting in the afternoon of November 4. This caused over 80% of the area to suffer from flooding, land subsidence, landslides, storm surges, and other disasters, resulting in 7 deaths.
The following timeline lists the formation and dissipation times of typhoons this year, and details of each storm can be found in the sections above.

Tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (i.e., international naming). Once the tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, names from the following list are used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the Typhoon Committee of the World Meteorological Organization, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting 10 names, arranged alphabetically by the English name of the country. Names not used this year are shown in gray, while those used this season are shown in black. Storm names in 2017 may overlap with some storm names from 2000, 2004 to 2005, and 2011 to 2012.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list rotates every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2017, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list summarizes all systems that developed or moved into the North Pacific west of the International Date Line during 2017. It also outlines the system's intensity, duration, affected land areas, and any deaths or losses associated with the system.

Article_Name: 颱風珊瑚 (2017年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Sanvu (English: Typhoon Sanvu, International Number: 1715, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP172017) was the 15th named storm of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The name (Cantonese: Saan1 Wu4, IPA: [saːn.wȕː]) was provided by Macau, and as the name suggests, it refers to the marine organism coral that lives in the ocean. Coral is a hard substance often used in decorations, formed by the accumulation of the skeletons of countless tiny marine animals.

Coral was the 15th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, intensifying into a tropical depression on August 26. At 2 p.m. on August 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded it to a tropical storm and assigned it the international number "1715," while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan simultaneously upgraded it to a mild typhoon. Coral's circulation was extensive, with forecasts indicating that the diameter of Coral's circulation could reach 2,000 kilometers, covering a very wide area. On August 30, various meteorological agencies upgraded Coral to a severe tropical storm. On August 31, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded Coral to a moderate typhoon, followed by other agencies gradually upgrading it to a typhoon. On September 3, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded Coral to a mild typhoon. That evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Coral had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the "2017 Tropical Cyclone Best Track Data" released by the China Meteorological Administration on May 1, 2018, Coral's intensity was revised from 35 meters per second (125 kilometers per hour) to 40 meters per second (145 kilometers per hour), and Coral's central pressure was revised downward to 960 hPa.

Due to the influence of Typhoon Coral, heavy rain, strong winds, and high wave warnings were issued for the Ogasawara Islands, and high wave warnings were also issued for the Izu Islands. The outer circulation of the typhoon coincided with the autumn rain front, causing continuous rainfall in the Kanto region of Japan. Between August 30 and September 1, Typhoon Coral remained stationary around Chichijima, bringing about 330 millimeters of rainfall, setting a nearly 50-year rainfall record for Chichijima.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴聖帕 (2019年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Sepat (English: Tropical Storm Sepat, International Designation: 1903, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Dodong) is the third named tropical cyclone of the 2019 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Sepat" was provided by Malaysia, referring to a type of freshwater perch, small in size, often found in rivers, weed-filled swamps, or rice fields.

After the dissipation of Tropical Cyclone Butterfly, only a few tropical depressions developed, and the Northwest Pacific entered a lull in named tropical cyclone activity until a named storm reappeared in late June. A low-pressure area formed near the waters of the Caroline Islands on June 16, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 94W. Initial computer numerical forecast models indicated that the system would generally move toward the waters near Luzon. On the evening of June 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical depression, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the chance of the low-pressure area developing into a tropical cyclone within one day as "low" by 10:30 PM. Over the following days, the system moved northward at a speed of 20 km/h, developing in an environment of warm sea water, weak to moderate vertical wind shear, and good upper-level divergence, with increasing rotation. On the morning of June 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating to "medium," but by June 21, increased vertical wind shear hindered the system's development. At the same time, the system turned northwestward and accelerated west-northwestward by June 22. By June 23, the low-level circulation center of the system became partially exposed to the northeast, prompting the Joint Typhoon Warning Center to downgrade the rating to "low" by 9 AM.

On June 24, the system resumed moving northward at 20 km/h along the western side of the subtropical ridge, leaving the area of strong vertical wind shear, and its organization gradually improved. At this time, numerical forecast models indicated that the system would move toward the Ryukyu Islands and possibly transition into a subtropical cyclone and re-intensify. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating back to "medium" at 2 PM and further upgraded it to "high" at 10 AM on June 25, issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration also upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 2 PM and 5 PM, respectively, assigning it the number 07 and the local name "Dodong." At this time, the system had turned east-northeastward and accelerated to a speed of 25 to 30 km/h. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning at 3:10 AM on June 26, indicating that the system was expected to strengthen into a tropical storm within one day.

Starting in the early hours of June 27, the system exhibited some extratropical cyclone characteristics, with its cloud bands forming a comma shape and its low-level circulation center becoming difficult to identify, but it still slightly intensified. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center stated that the system had transitioned into a subtropical cyclone and strengthened into a subtropical depression, lowering the rating back to "low" at 9 AM and canceling the tropical cyclone formation alert. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency, which does not classify "subtropical cyclones," continued to rate the system as a tropical cyclone. As the system's central wind strength reached level 8, it was officially upgraded to a tropical storm at 6 PM and named Sepat, with the international designation 1903. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded Sepat to a subtropical storm at 8 PM. At this time, Sepat erupted with convection, further accelerating to a speed of 60 km/h, moving east-northeastward, and rapidly crossing the waters south of Japan's Honshu, causing a noticeable semicircular effect. However, the Hong Kong Observatory did not upgrade Sepat to a tropical depression until 6:45 PM, while the China Meteorological Administration upgraded Sepat to a tropical storm at 8:35 PM. On the morning of June 28, the system passed southeast of Tokyo, Japan. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled all ratings at 9 AM, and the Japan Meteorological Agency announced at 2:40 PM that Sepat had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

During its passage over Japan, Sepat brought severe weather to the southern coast, with Osaka also covered in thick clouds. Fortunately, it did not affect the G20 Summit held locally. Sepat passed over the seas south of Japan from June 27 to 28, bringing strong winds and heavy rain to the southern coastal areas. At 4:45 a.m., Miyakejima in Tokyo recorded a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 25.2 meters per second (91 kilometers per hour). In terms of rainfall, Shirahama in Shizuoka Prefecture recorded 52 millimeters of rainfall in one hour at 4:43 a.m. The warm and humid air currents brought by Sepat and the seasonal rain front caused heavy rain in the Hokuriku region, with hourly rainfall of 30 millimeters recorded in Komatsu City and Kanazawa City in Ishikawa Prefecture.

Article_Name: Furacão Carlos (2009) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Hurricane Carlos was a tropical cyclone that was active in the Northeastern Pacific Ocean in mid-July 2009. Being the fourth tropical cyclone, the third named tropical storm, and the second hurricane of the 2009 Pacific hurricane season, Carlos formed on July 10, 2009, more than 1,400 km south of the southern tip of the Baja California Peninsula. On the same day, Carlos intensified into a tropical storm and into a hurricane the following day. However, for unknown reasons, Carlos weakened into a tropical storm on July 12. Carlos maintained its intensity until July 14, when it became a hurricane again and reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 165 km/h on the morning of July 15. From then on, Carlos began to weaken rapidly due to less favorable weather conditions. The next day, Carlos degenerated into a remnant low-pressure area, and the National Hurricane Center (NHC) issued its final advisory on the system. As Carlos remained far from any coastal region, no hurricane-related impacts were reported.

A low-level cyclonic circulation associated with an area of low pressure more than 1,400 km south of the southern tip of the Baja California Peninsula, Mexico, began to show signs of organization as it disconnected from the intertropical convergence zone. On July 10, the cyclonic circulation and areas of deep convection were already well-organized enough for the National Hurricane Center (NHC) to classify the system as the fourth tropical depression of the 2009 Pacific hurricane season. Initially moving westward, the depression began to slowly intensify during that day, with two prominent storm bands, although the cyclonic center was located in an area with few deep convection zones. The tropical cyclone continued to form more areas of deep convection, and later that day, the system was well-organized enough to be declared by the NHC as Tropical Storm "Carlos." Under excellent meteorological conditions, such as warm waters and low wind shear, Carlos continued to gradually intensify. During the early hours (UTC) of July 11, Carlos began to develop a dense cloud center, indicating that the intensification trend would not stop. After a brief period of stabilization in the storm's intensity during the morning and early afternoon of July 11, due to changes in Carlos's internal structure, an eye wall began to form at the center of the cyclonic circulation, indicating the return of Carlos's intensification trend. The intensification trend continued throughout the rest of that day, and the NHC classified Carlos as the second hurricane of the season that night (UTC) as the cyclone presented an eye-like structure at its circulation center. Continuously moving westward due to the influence of a subtropical high to its north, Carlos stopped intensifying again due to internal changes in the hurricane's structure; its eye disappeared, and its cyclonic circulation became slightly more asymmetric, even under excellent meteorological conditions. The trend of disorganization in the internal structure continued, and on the afternoon of July 12, Carlos began to weaken slowly. As a result, the NHC downgraded Carlos to a tropical storm that night (UTC); the weakening trend went against all tropical cyclone forecast models, which indicated a rapid intensification of the cyclone amid excellent meteorological conditions, such as near-zero wind shear and warm ocean surface waters. The weakening trend of the cyclone, even under excellent meteorological conditions for its development, proved to be a "puzzle" for hurricane specialists at the National Hurricane Center (NHC), who stated: In the early hours of July 14, Carlos's weakening trend stopped, and the tropical storm maintained its stabilized intensity with maximum sustained winds of 85 km/h. However, the storm's cyclonic circulation was embedded in the intertropical convergence zone, which did not favor the resumption of its intensification. Nevertheless, Carlos was able to form new areas of deep convection starting from the night (UTC) of July 14 and began to gradually intensify again. At the same time, an eye-like structure formed at the center of its cyclonic circulation, indicating that the storm would strengthen again. Carlos remained stable until the night (UTC) of July 14, when it began to intensify rapidly again. A "pinhole" eye formed at the center of the cyclonic circulation, and the NHC reclassified the system as a hurricane. Carlos continued to intensify throughout the rest of that day and reached its peak intensity during the morning (UTC) of July 15, with maximum sustained winds of 165 km/h; at that moment, Carlos was a "dwarf" and annular hurricane, and its eye measured only 20 km in diameter. At a latitude of 10.2°N during its peak intensity, Carlos became the most intense hurricane to be active at latitudes below 11°N since reliable records of Northeast Pacific hurricanes began in 1966. However, Carlos began to gradually weaken from midday (UTC) on July 15 due to the continued degradation of its cyclonic circulation. Associated with this, the arrival of moderate wind shear began to negatively impact the cyclone; its areas of deep convection were displaced to the east of its cyclonic center. As a result, Carlos continued to weaken, and the NHC downgraded it to a tropical storm that night. During the morning (UTC) of July 16, the wind shear had already removed almost all of its areas of deep convection associated with the system, further deteriorating the storm. As a result, the NHC downgraded Carlos to a tropical depression. The system continued to decay amid moderate wind shear and being tied to the intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ). By that afternoon, nothing remained but a small cloud-free cyclonic spin of what was once a Category 2 hurricane. As a result, the NHC downgraded Carlos to a remnant low-pressure area and issued its final advisory on the system.

As Carlos did not threaten or hit coastal regions, no hurricane or tropical storm warning or alert was necessary. For the same reason, Carlos did not cause any impact on human society. Furthermore, no ship or weather station recorded its passage; the hurricane was monitored exclusively based on satellite images.

Article_Name: Furacão Guillermo (2009) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Hurricane Guillermo was an intense tropical cyclone that was active in mid-August 2009 in the Northeastern Pacific Ocean. Being the eleventh tropical cyclone, the seventh named tropical system, the fourth hurricane, and the second major hurricane of the 2009 Pacific hurricane season, Guillermo formed from an area of meteorological disturbances on August 12. Moving west-northwest, the system quickly intensified into a tropical storm. Under favorable meteorological conditions, Guillermo intensified into a hurricane on August 14. Guillermo became the second major hurricane of the season the following day, and shortly thereafter, reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 205 km/h and a minimum central atmospheric pressure of 954 hPa. Shortly after, Guillermo began to weaken as it started moving over cooler waters. Its weakening trend was intensified by increased wind shear, and Guillermo weakened into a tropical storm on August 16. Even under extremely hostile conditions, Guillermo managed to remain a tropical storm until August 19, when it weakened into a tropical depression. Guillermo completely dissipated early the following morning, north of Hawaii. Since Guillermo did not threaten or impact coastal regions, no hurricane or tropical storm warnings or advisories were necessary. For the same reason, Guillermo did not cause any impact on human society.

Hurricane Guillermo formed from a broad area of meteorological disturbances that persisted southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California Peninsula on August 12. Initially, the depression exhibited a well-defined low-level cyclonic circulation, and only modest intensification of the cyclone was forecast, as the depression moved west-northwest in response to a subtropical high to its north, and on this trajectory, it would encounter cooler waters. That day, the depression began to show the first signs of intensification as its upper-level outflow was well established, and two associated storm bands were well defined. Early on August 13, the application of the Dvorak technique, which determines the intensity of a tropical cyclone solely by its organization in satellite images, indicated that the depression was already well-organized enough for the National Hurricane Center to classify the system as a tropical storm, which was named "Guillermo." Continuing to move west-northwest, Guillermo gradually intensified while located in a region with favorable meteorological conditions. That morning, the storm displayed a cyclonic storm band covering more than half of its cyclonic circulation. That afternoon (UTC), Guillermo began to develop a dense cloud center and an embryonic eye structure, indicating that the storm could intensify further. That night, new areas of deep convection formed in the northern quadrant of its cyclonic circulation, which had previously been devoid of any storm bands. Guillermo's gradual intensification trend was interrupted early on August 14 as the storm underwent changes in its internal structure. However, the storm's internal changes revealed that Guillermo was consolidating its cyclonic circulation. The storm bands formed a ring of deep convection areas. Additionally, an eye began to be seen in satellite images. With these changes, Guillermo resumed intensification and became the fourth hurricane of the 2009 Pacific hurricane season later that morning (UTC). Guillermo continued to gradually intensify as its convection areas became better established. The system's intensification trend persisted until that night, when Guillermo reached the intensity of a Category 2 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson hurricane scale. However, Guillermo's intensification trend was again interrupted. The temperature at the top of its convection areas increased, and its eye was covered by clouds, indicating weakening. Nevertheless, its convection areas became even better organized. As a result, Guillermo maintained its stable intensity. However, changes in Guillermo's internal structure revealed that the storm was once again ready to continue its intensification trend. During the early hours (UTC) of August 14, Guillermo underwent another period of rapid intensification and became the second major hurricane of the season when it reached the intensity of a Category 3 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson scale. Guillermo continued to gradually intensify that day, reaching its peak intensity that afternoon, with maximum sustained winds of 205 km/h and a minimum atmospheric pressure in its eye of 954 hPa. However, from that night onward, Guillermo began to be negatively affected by cooler ocean waters (below 25°C) and more stable meteorological conditions, unfavorable for the continuation of a tropical cyclone. As a result, Guillermo began to gradually weaken and weakened to a Category 2 hurricane later that night (UTC). On August 15, Guillermo's weakening trend stopped, and the hurricane managed to maintain its intensity even in cold ocean waters for its sustenance. That afternoon, Guillermo also began to be affected by increased wind shear, which had been minimal in previous days. Even so, Guillermo managed to maintain its intensity with the formation of new areas of deep convection. However, Guillermo finally began to succumb to strong wind shear that night, when Guillermo weakened to a Category 1 hurricane. At that time, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) issued its final advisory on the system as the hurricane crossed the 140°W meridian, leaving its area of responsibility to enter the Central Pacific Hurricane Center (CPHC) area of responsibility, which continued to monitor the system. Guillermo's eye was no longer visible early on August 17 as strong wind shear displaced convection areas to the east of the cyclonic circulation, leaving the circulation center practically exposed. Guillermo's rapid weakening trend continued, and the system weakened to a tropical storm later that morning. That afternoon, Guillermo's center was already completely exposed, as all its convection areas had been removed from the storm and dissipated by west-southwest wind shear. However, the storm's weakening trend was again interrupted, even under very strong wind shear exceeding 75 km/h. The interruption was attributed to the narrow atmospheric pressure gradient between the storm and a strong high-pressure area to its northeast. Meanwhile, Guillermo began to move northwest in response to a break in the subtropical high. Even under strong wind shear, Guillermo continued to maintain its intensity while moving northwest. However, the system failed to produce new convection areas from the night of August 19. At that time, all convection areas associated with Guillermo disappeared, and the system was downgraded to a tropical depression. During the early hours of August 20, Guillermo degenerated into a low-pressure area, and the CPHC issued its final advisory on the system.

As Guillermo did not threaten or reach coastal regions, no hurricane or tropical storm warnings or advisories were necessary. For the same reason, Guillermo did not cause any impact on human society. Furthermore, no ship or weather station recorded its passage; the hurricane was monitored exclusively based on satellite images.

Article_Name: Furacão Boris (2008) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Hurricane Boris was the first hurricane and the second named tropical system of the 2008 Pacific hurricane season. Boris formed from a tropical wave that began to show signs of intensification on June 23 and became a tropical depression on June 27. Boris then began to gradually strengthen, becoming a hurricane on two occasions, on July 1 and 2, before encountering highly unfavorable conditions and dissipating on July 4. As Boris remained far from the coast throughout its life cycle, no preparations were made, and no impact was reported as a result of Boris's passage.

A tropical wave left the western coast of Africa on June 15 and crossed the tropical North Atlantic as a high-amplitude wave before reaching the Caribbean Sea and crossing Central America on June 23. As the tropical wave moved into the northeastern Pacific Ocean, it began to organize, and intense areas of convection formed in association with the system. On June 27, the wave became sufficiently organized to be declared Tropical Depression Two-E, about 920 km south-southwest of Manzanillo, Mexico. Initially, the cloud pattern was reasonably well-defined, with curved storm bands and well-established outflows. Low to moderate wind shear allowed new areas of convection to emerge, and later on June 27, the National Hurricane Center upgraded the depression to a tropical storm and named it Boris. However, the storm's strengthening trend was interrupted by increasing northwesterly vertical wind shear, which gradually confined the main areas of convection to the southeast of the low-level cyclonic center. But during the night (UTC) of June 29 and early morning of June 30, the vertical wind shear decreased, allowing the low-level cyclonic center to remain under the main areas of convection. As a result, Boris began to strengthen gradually again, and a rather irregular eye formed at the center of the cyclone, which soon dissipated with the formation of new areas of convection. Boris remained a strong tropical storm for about 24 hours before slightly strengthening and becoming a minimal hurricane on July 1. At the same time, an irregular eye reappeared in satellite images, along with a broken eyewall on its northern side surrounding the system. However, the eye did not persist, nor did its associated eyewall, indicating the beginning of a weakening trend. Consequently, later on July 1, Boris, moving into cooler waters, weakened to a tropical storm. Boris, which had been moving west-northwest and west since the beginning of its life cycle under the influence of a strong mid-level subtropical high, began to shift northwestward due to the weakening of the high caused by the passage of a mid-to-upper-level trough. Additionally, Boris began to move more slowly for the same reason. However, Boris unexpectedly strengthened again on July 2, becoming a minimal hurricane once more and showing a well-defined eye and eyewall. Nevertheless, Boris began to weaken rapidly as it encountered waters with temperatures around 24°C, which do not support tropical cyclone activity. As a result, later on July 2, the system weakened again to a tropical storm. From then on, the cold waters, wind shear, and dry, stable air began to rapidly weaken the system, and Boris weakened to a tropical depression early on July 4. The rapid weakening trend continued, and hours later, Boris degenerated into a remnant low-pressure area. Consequently, the NHC issued its final advisory on the system.
As Boris remained distant from any coastal region, it did not cause any preparations or impact. No ship or weather station directly recorded the passage of the system.

Article_Name: Furacão Genevieve (2008) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Hurricane Genevieve was a tropical cyclone that was active in the northeastern Pacific Ocean at the end of July 2008. Being the eighth tropical cyclone, the seventh named tropical system, and the fourth hurricane of the 2008 Pacific hurricane season, Genevieve formed from a tropical wave a few hundred kilometers off the Pacific coast of Mexico. Moving westward for almost its entire existence, Genevieve gradually intensified, strengthening into a hurricane four days later. However, the hurricane soon encountered more hostile weather conditions and began to weaken rapidly, ceasing to be considered a tropical cyclone on July 27 and dissipating completely four days later. Since Genevieve remained far from the coast throughout its life cycle, no preparations were made, and no impact was reported as a result of the cyclone's passage.

A tropical wave, which almost developed into an Atlantic tropical depression off the Caribbean coast of Nicaragua on July 17, entered the northeastern Pacific Ocean basin on July 18. Moving parallel to the Pacific coast of Central America and southern Mexico, areas of cloudiness and thunderstorms showed signs of organization, and on July 21, the low-pressure area associated with the system became organized and developed into Tropical Depression Eight-E about 400 km south-southeast of Acapulco, on Mexico's Pacific coast. Initially, the depression's center was in the southeastern quadrant of the main convection areas due to the effect of moderate wind shear. Hours later, new areas of deep convection formed within the system, helping to increase the maximum sustained winds from 55 km/h to 65 km/h. As a result, the National Hurricane Center upgraded the depression to a tropical storm, naming it Genevieve. However, the trend of rapid intensification was hindered by strong wind shear, which briefly compromised the cyclone's vertical structure, causing a slight displacement of the mid-level cyclonic center northwestward relative to the low-level cyclonic circulation. Nevertheless, the wind shear did not prevent Genevieve from slowly intensifying as areas of deep convection gradually increased, aiding the cyclone's strengthening. The intensification trend was interrupted again on July 23 when Genevieve began moving over cooler waters left by Hurricane Fausto days earlier. Shortly thereafter, Genevieve began to weaken slightly due to increased wind shear. The slow weakening trend continued, with most of Genevieve's associated deep convection areas dissipating by July 24; the remaining deep convection areas were asymmetrically distributed around the system's cyclonic circulation. However, later that day, Genevieve began to intensify slowly again. An irregular eye started to become visible within the convection areas. As a result, Genevieve became a Category 1 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson hurricane scale on July 25, the fourth of the 2008 Pacific hurricane season, about 945 km southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California Peninsula, Mexico. However, the intensity of a minimal hurricane, with maximum sustained winds of 120 km/h, was Genevieve's peak intensity. Its eye disappeared later that day, and Genevieve began to weaken rapidly as it entered a region of cooler ocean waters. Consequently, Genevieve weakened to a storm late on July 25. The rapid weakening trend continued, and its overall structure gradually deteriorated. As a result, on July 26, Genevieve lost all its deep convection areas due to the effects of cooler waters, wind shear, and a stable atmosphere, with satellite images showing only a nearly cloud-free cyclonic circulation. Rapidly degenerating, Genevieve became a tropical depression late on July 26, and the National Hurricane Center issued its final advisory on the system early on July 27 (UTC) when Genevieve degenerated into a remnant low-pressure area. Genevieve's remnant low-pressure area continued westward for several more days, dissipating completely on July 31 as it entered the central-north Pacific Ocean basin.
As Genevieve remained distant from any coastal region, it did not cause any type of preparation or impact. No ship or weather station directly recorded the passage of the system.
