Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Goni, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Jolina, or Typhoon No. 6 of 2009 in Vietnam. The typhoon's developments surprised many meteorologists.

At the end of July 25, the JTWC reported that a convective area had formed in a monsoon trough approximately 815 km (506 miles) northeast of Guam. Deep convection was erupting around the low-level circulation center. An upper-level storm and a tropical upper tropospheric trough were providing outflow. Over the next few days, the disturbance gradually developed before being declared dissipated early on July 28 as the low-level circulation center became poorly defined and higher vertical wind shear affected the system. However, the disturbance was regenerated early on July 30 while located about 630 km (390 miles) away, with the low-level circulation center of the disturbance elongated and showing signs of multiple circulation centers. Later that day, PAGASA reported that the disturbance had developed into a tropical depression and assigned it the local name Jolina. Jolina then further intensified early the next day and was reported to have become a tropical storm by PAGASA, with JMA designating it as a depression later that day. Early on August 1, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert as deep convection increased and began consolidating around a circulation center. However, later that morning, Jolina made landfall near Casiguran, in the province of Aurora, Philippines, before emerging into the South China Sea later that day. Early the next day, the JTWC reissued their TCFA while PAGASA issued their final warning on Jolina as it exited their area of responsibility heading towards a landfall in China. Subsequently, the JTWC designated the depression as 08W that day as infrared imagery showed deep convection being drawn into the low-level circulation center. On August 3, the JMA reported that the tropical depression had intensified into a tropical storm and assigned the name Goni to the storm. At 1700 UTC on August 4, Goni made its second landfall in Macau. Early the next day, the JTWC issued their final warning on Goni. On August 7, the JTWC noted that the remnants of Goni had re-entered the Gulf of Tonkin and had a low chance of regeneration. Later that day, the JTWC reissued advisories on the system, upgrading it to a tropical storm near Hainan Island.

When near the Philippines, it affected 38,589 families or 160,038 people in 119 villages in 25 towns and five cities in Ilocos Sur, Batangas, Cagayan, Nueva Ecija, Rizal, Occidental Mindoro, Palawan, Iloilo, Negros Occidental, Lanao del Sur, and Sultan Kudarat town in Maguindanao. Three people died and five went missing.
In Hainan province, approximately 92,000 people have been evacuated by authorities, 575 houses were destroyed, and 2,311 houses were damaged.

Article_Name: 颱風添姆 (1994年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Tim was a tropical cyclone in the 1994 Pacific typhoon season. After forming over the sea east of Luzon Island in the Philippines, Tim moved northwest and made landfall at the mouth of the Xiuguluan River in Hualien County, Taiwan, at 8 PM on July 10. It exited near Fangyuan Township, Changhua County, early on July 11, continuing northwest. It made landfall again in Zhangban Town, Hui'an County, Quanzhou City, Fujian Province, China, early on July 11, where its intensity quickly weakened. Strong winds and heavy rain were experienced across Taiwan. Rail and road transportation in the eastern and southeastern regions were disrupted. Agricultural damage occurred in Yilan, Hualien, Taitung, and southwestern regions, with Hualien County suffering the most severe disaster. A total of 17 people died, 6 went missing, and the entire island suffered severe injuries.

Whole_Text.content: Hurricane in Siberia (2023) - a natural disaster that occurred in several regions of Russia and Kazakhstan on November 18-19, 2023, resulting in significant damage to property and facilities in several cities of Kazakhstan and Western Siberia, with 4 people killed and at least 13 injured to varying degrees of severity.

On the evening of November 18, 2023, a hurricane-force wind struck Astana. According to meteorologists, the wind speed reached 23 m/s and caused significant damage (building wall cladding was torn off, roofs were ripped off, and advertising banners collapsed). On the evening of the same day and into the night of November 19, squally winds with a force of 30 m/s hit the Pavlodar region bordering Russia, resulting in power outages in about 100 settlements in the region, 42 roofs of residential and administrative buildings were torn off, and heating supply was disrupted in Pavlodar itself. On the night of November 19, hurricane-force winds, increasing to 32 m/s, struck the Altai Krai. Due to fallen trees on the roadway, traffic was partially halted on the K-03 highway "Zmeinogorsk-border of the Novosibirsk region" (passing through Rubtsovsk and along the Russian-Kazakh border), the Ribbon Forest highway in Barnaul, and the "Biysk-Sorokino" road. In Barnaul and Biysk, the wind felled numerous trees, damaged cars, and destroyed roofs. Seventy settlements were left without electricity due to power line breaks. On the morning of November 19, hurricane-force winds, increasing to 35 m/s and above, struck Novokuznetsk. In some parts of the city, there was no electricity or water supply. Moreover, the wind caused trucks to overturn, and fir trees were uprooted. Preliminary reports indicate three fatalities. Due to the power outage, the VHL hockey match "Metallurg" vs. AKM was canceled. The hurricane raged in Krasnoyarsk and then moved to the Irkutsk region. Electricity was cut off in several districts.

As a result of the hurricane, at least 100 roofs were torn off, at least 600 trees were felled, and more than 170 settlements were left without electricity or experienced power outages. In Biysk, due to squally winds, the wooden dome of the church in honor of the Kazan Icon of the Mother of God collapsed. Four people died due to the hurricane winds: a woman in Barnaul (swept away along with the roof), two pensioners in Novokuznetsk (crushed in a car by a fallen tree), and a guard in the village of Novy Gorodok (a roof collapsed). At least 13 people were injured (4 in Astana, 3 in Barnaul, and 6 in Novokuznetsk). The hurricane also disrupted transportation— all flights to Barnaul airport were redirected to Novosibirsk, which was unaffected by the hurricane. There were also disruptions in public transport in Barnaul, Biysk, and Novokuznetsk. Due to the damage caused to the city's utilities, the mayor of Novokuznetsk declared a state of emergency. Classes for the first shift in Novokuznetsk schools were canceled. During the aftermath of the hurricane, diesel generators were delivered to the villages of Abagur-Lesnoy and Listvyagi, and field kitchens were organized. In some areas, people were left without electricity, heat, and water for three days, and in the village of Kruglenkoye for five days. To oversee the elimination of the consequences, Deputy Prosecutor General of Russia Dmitry Demeshin arrived in the region.

In connection with the death of people in Novokuznetsk, the Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation initiated a criminal case on the grounds of a crime under Part 3 of Article 293 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation (negligence resulting in the death of two persons through carelessness)[27].

Info_Box:
Formed: November 18  
Dissipated: November 19  
Fatalities: 4  
Damage: unknown

Whole_Text.content: Shrove Tuesday, also called the Evil Tuesday, was a storm with a powerful and persistent snowstorm that affected large parts of southern and central Sweden on Tuesday, January 29, 1850. The most severely affected areas were the provinces of Uppland, Södermanland, and Östergötland. The sudden snowstorm surprised many people, which is why the number of fatalities was relatively high. The reports on exactly how many people perished vary, but it was around a hundred people. A low-pressure system moved eastward, over the border between Götaland and Svealand. Locally, it also rained, and on January 29, 1850, mild air spread around the freezing point.
The observations are primarily based on astronomical observations, as the event occurred approximately 10 years before regular meteorological observations began in Sweden.

The surprise was greatest in the Baltic Sea regions, where many unsuspecting people went out in the mild weather in the morning, poorly dressed. On Sweden's west coast and in northern Sweden, people were more prepared, as temperatures were colder even before the storm. Many were also without a chance as they were far from settlements.

The tornado in Wiener Neustadt in 1916 was a tornado that devastated parts of Wiener Neustadt on July 10, 1916, with a strength of F4/T8. At least 34 people lost their lives. It was the strongest tornado documented in Austria to date.

In the early afternoon of July 10, 1916, a thunderstorm cell formed in the Schneeberg area, which soon developed into a supercell with a pronounced mesocyclone due to significant wind shear. A funnel cloud formed. Two tornadoes were observed, although it is unclear whether the two merged into the devastating tornado or if one intensified while the other dissipated. Initial damage was documented in Peisching in the Piesting Valley, about 15 kilometers west-northwest of Wiener Neustadt. The tornado is said to have formed on a slope in the village. From there, a continuous path of destruction extended to the Leitha River east of Wiener Neustadt. In Dreistetten, a few houses were severely damaged, and the first personal injury occurred: a soldier on leave was swept into the air and suffered a severe leg injury. The tornado moved east-southeast at a speed of approximately 40 m/s. It crossed a small ridge, causing forest damage, before reaching the heated Steinfeld plain. Over the Wiener Neustadt airfield, there was a significant change in direction to the southeast. It is possible that the tornado merged here with the tornado moving in from the north. The tornado then crossed residential areas of Wiener Neustadt. It devastated the Josefstadt district with an intensity of F2 on the Fujita scale and changed its direction to the east. Over the Wiener Neustadt locomotive factory, it reached an intensity of F4, destroying most of the old factory. At the Daimler plant, the intensity was still F2. Shortly before the Leitha floodplain near Lichtenwörth, the tornado felled trees for the last time and finally dissipated. The tornado occurred between 5:30 PM and 6:00 PM, with no precise records of its start and dissipation times. It covered a total distance of about 20 kilometers. The average diameter of the tornado was 300 meters, its maximum damage-causing width was 600 meters, and the observed maximum diameter was 1,000 meters. According to modern calculations, it can be concluded that the tornado reached wind speeds of more than 300 km/h. Since there are no direct measurements of wind speed, the assessment of wind speed and intensity on the TORRO and Fujita scales was based on the damage patterns.

The northern districts of Wiener Neustadt were devastated, and the newly erected telegraph and telephone poles were destroyed. The tornado then struck the Wiener Neustadt locomotive factory, where it claimed the most lives. In total, at least 34 fatalities and 328 injuries were reported, and the financial damage amounted to 900,000 crowns. The tornado is still considered the most devastating weather event in Austria and the strongest tornado on Austrian soil to date. On the European list, the tornado ranks fourth in terms of the number of fatalities.

Wiener Neustadt is located in the southern Vienna Basin and additionally on the Steinfeld. Around Wiener Neustadt lies the Wiener Neustadt mountain range. Cold air flows down from the mountains and hills into the warm basin air. This repeatedly leads to the formation of supercells near Wiener Neustadt, which occasionally produce tornadoes. Along with the Mühlviertel and the Graz Basin, the area around Wiener Neustadt is among the most tornado-prone regions in Austria.
Besides the tornado in 1916, there have been and still are tornadoes near Wiener Neustadt, e.g.:

The tornado of August 23, 1950, refers to the severe weather that moved across the Netherlands from southwest to northeast over Gelderland on the evening of August 23, 1950, from Wekerom/Harskamp over the Veluwe to Vaassen.

During the storm, an F3-F4[1] tornado, with a damage path 400 to 1400 meters wide and 46 kilometers long, swept across the Veluwe. The tornado passed over Wekerom/Harskamp, Kootwijk, the Amsterdam - Zutphen railway line, and Kroondomein Het Loo, ending a few kilometers before Vaassen near the Tongeren/Wissel line at Epe. Because the tornado moved through sparsely populated areas, the number of destroyed houses was limited. One person was seriously injured. A total forest area of 460 hectares suffered severe damage, and high-voltage pylons were blown over.[2] Queen Juliana, accompanied by Princesses Irene and Margriet, visited the victims in Kootwijk and the royal domain near Hoog Soeren, which had also sustained damage.[3] Subsequently, she donated a significant amount to the National Disaster Fund Foundation for the benefit of the affected municipalities.[4]

The hurricane in the Bergisches Land in 1906 was a weather event on August 14, 1906, in the area of the Solingen and Remscheid districts, which caused significant damage and several fatalities. A thunderstorm moved from the southwest from the Rhineland over the Bergisches Land. A tornado formed, leading to considerable destruction of houses, bridges, and forests. The affected areas included the villages of I. Balkhausen, II. Balkhausen, Scharfhausen, Schaberg, Dorperhof, and Müngsten. The tornado also reached the Wupper near Beyenburg. There were three deaths and many injuries, as reported by the "Solinger Kreis-Intelligenzblatt," now Solinger Tageblatt.

Article_Name: Tornade du 10 septembre 1896 à Paris — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Modify - modify the code - modify Wikidata The tornado of September 10, 1896, is a violent meteorological phenomenon that affected the heart of Paris that day, a little before 3 p.m. It is the only known tornado in the history of the French capital.

Paris was already struck by a violent hailstorm on July 26, 1896, affecting the neighborhoods between Montsouris and Belleville. Numerous trees were uprooted, and the flowerbeds of the Jardin des Plantes were devastated. The press of the time reported that tramway traffic had to be interrupted at Quai Saint-Bernard due to tree trunks fallen on the roadway. Roofs were torn off in various places, such as Place d'Italie. The Bois de Boulogne and Bois de Vincennes were also affected. The event caused two deaths: an eleven-year-old girl killed in the collapse of a laundry at 85 Rue de Patay in the 13th arrondissement, and a young woman in her twenties who fell from the top of the fortifications at Porte d'Ivry.

The city is once again struck by a storm on September 10. Around 2:40 PM, at Place Saint-Sulpice, what the press of the time described as a "waterspout" or a "cyclone" forms. Likely categorized as F2 on the Fujita scale, it causes the death of at least five people and injures about a hundred others. The phenomenon, which moves almost in a straight line northward, spans a strip 150 to 300 meters wide and 6 kilometers long through the 6th, 1st, 3rd, and 10th arrondissements, affecting notably: Place Saint-Sulpice, Quai des Grands-Augustins, where trees are uprooted and booksellers' boxes scattered; the Seine, where several barges sink or are damaged; Pont Saint-Michel, Île de la Cité, Pont au Change; Place du Châtelet, where the theater's roof is partially torn off; Rue Réaumur, where the damage is most striking, Rue de Turbigo; Place de la République, Boulevard Saint-Martin, Boulevard de Magenta, then Canal Saint-Martin, where a woman and her child are thrown into the water; Hôpital Saint-Louis and Boulevard de la Villette, where a funfair is devastated. The press reports that, according to witnesses, the whirlwind does not rise higher than the treetops and notably leaves the top of the Saint-Jacques Tower intact. It also moves in the manner of a "rubber ball, by successive leaps." Among the victims are: an English jockey, Alfred Eyears, who was in an open carriage and was, according to sources, either thrown "ten meters high" or more soberly "crushed by the fall of a chimney" at Quai des Orfèvres; a laborer, Mr. Vanderhagle, killed by a lead sheet torn from a roof; a five-year-old child, Antoine Rouché, killed by a tree branch; a porter at Les Halles, suffering from a heart condition, who died the next day while recounting his accident; the wife of a bargeman, Mrs. Lefebvre, struck by a tree branch on her sinking barge. This phenomenon was the subject of several communications to the Academy of Sciences at the time.

The street cleaning work begins the next day, with broken windows needing to be replaced, scattered branches in the streets to be picked up, and wreckage from the Seine to be removed. The municipality allocates a budget of 10,000 francs and covers the funeral expenses of the victims.
On June 18, 1897, another tornado struck the Paris suburbs of Courbevoie, La Garenne-Colombes, Asnières, and Saint-Ouen. It caused around ten deaths.

The 1890 Dreux tornado was a violent storm that occurred on August 18. Shortly before 10:00 PM, a tornado damaged the municipality of Dreux, the valleys of the Blaise and Eure rivers, and the village of Brissard. According to descriptions provided by witnesses, around 10:00 PM, large black cumulonimbus clouds coming from the south were moving towards the city. These clouds continuously discharged lightning, followed by a heavy hailstorm accompanied by thunder.

Info_Box:
Type: tornado

Article_Name: 北海道佐呂間町竜巻災害

Whole_Text.content: The Saroma Town Tornado Disaster in Hokkaido refers to a disaster that occurred around 1:20 PM on November 7, 2006, in Wakasa, Saroma Town, Tokoro District, Hokkaido, where a tornado struck near a prefabricated hut used by workers at the construction site of the new Saroma Tunnel on National Route 333, resulting in the deaths of 9 people.

The worst death toll caused by a tornado in postwar Japan. The Japan Meteorological Agency initially announced the tornado's scale as provisionally "F2" or higher, but based on the extent of the damage, there was a strong view that it might be "F3" or higher. Subsequent investigations confirmed it to be "F3." Prior to the Meteorological Agency's "F3" announcement, Professor Toshiyuki Oshima of the Civil Engineering and Development Department (Structural Engineering) at Kitami Institute of Technology revealed through his research that the instantaneous wind speed reached 83 meters per second, and announced it as "F3."

On that day, a cold front was passing from Hokkaido to the Kanto region, and particularly along the Sea of Okhotsk coast in Hokkaido to the Sea of Japan side of the Tohoku region, the weather was extremely rough. Additionally, a low-pressure system near Hokkaido intensified, and the atmosphere above the Abashiri Subprefecture, where Saroma Town is located, was extremely unstable. For this reason, the tornado is believed to have been caused by a supercell. Furthermore, strong cold air was present on the western side of the cold front, and in Osaka, located on the western side of the front, the first "Kogarashi" (cold wind signaling the arrival of winter) was observed. However, in Tokyo, located on the eastern side of the front, temperatures were comparable to those of mid to late September. Around Saroma Town, it is believed that the area was within a meteorological zone with an extremely sharp temperature difference.

In the Wakasa district, where numerous casualties occurred, excavation work for the new Saroma Tunnel was underway, and three prefabricated huts for workers had been built at the exact location where the damage occurred. Two of these huts were blown away along with their roofs by a gust of wind and collapsed. At the time, many workers had gathered in the meeting room on the second floor of one of the prefabricated huts for a meeting, resulting in nine fatalities. The cause of death in all cases was brain contusion, which is typical of tornado disasters.  

On the other hand, despite the extensive damage to the residential area, the residents of the affected area suffered only nine injuries. This was because, at the time of the tornado, many residents were away from their homes, attending a funeral in the neighborhood, and thus coincidentally avoided the tornado's impact.  

At the site, large trucks were easily blown away, the roofs of relatively new houses were torn off, and utility poles were uprooted and blown away, illustrating the severity of the damage. Debris was scattered over areas more than 10 kilometers away from the disaster site.  

Due to the collapse of numerous utility poles, a power outage occurred in 631 households in parts of Saroma Town and Kitami City until around 10 p.m. on November 7 (as announced by the Hokkaido Electric Power Kitami Branch). Additionally, residents near the site were evacuated.

This entry is a draft related to Hokkaido. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this entry (Portal: Japan's Prefectures/Hokkaido).

Article_Name: Tornado de Córdoba de 2003, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Córdoba tornado was a meteorological phenomenon that occurred on December 26, 2003, in the city of Córdoba, Argentina.

The Argentine National Meteorological Service had warned several provinces in the central-west of the country that a system of strong thunderstorms, with heavy downpours, strong winds of 60 to 90 km/h, and occasional hail would affect the region. These storms impacted Mendoza, San Juan, La Rioja, San Luis, Catamarca, Córdoba, Santa Fe, and Buenos Aires. When the first damages were reported in the initial provinces, the people of Córdoba were almost caught off guard by the alert. The winds caused damage in other cities, such as fallen trees, power and light poles, and cars dented by hail that some said was the size of a tennis ball. The Meteorological Service extended the alert from four to seven days because it seemed to be gaining strength, and that’s when the inhabitants of La Docta began to worry.

On Friday, December 26, 2003, in the city of Córdoba, the temperature ranged between 35 and 36 °C in the shade. The oppressive heat was countered by gray and black clouds that began appearing from the mountains early in the morning, while news reports mentioned strong river surges in the mountainous areas and damage in towns like Villa Dolores, where hail and wind caused further destruction. In the capital, the occasional sound of fireworks explosions and remnants of the previous night's Christmas celebrations could still be heard. By 2:00 PM, some residents were preparing to take a nap with the drizzle that had started to fall. Then tragedy struck. At 3:15 PM, a funnel-shaped cloud began descending toward the ground. Many witnesses were stunned by the event until they started seeking shelter upon seeing houses, trees, cables, and other objects being lifted into the air. Sheets of metal from warehouses violently wrapped around trees that the winds could not uproot. The tornado moved forward with gusts exceeding 300 km/h, heavy rain, hail, and lightning. Some residents in the city center watched the phenomenon in amazement from tall buildings, while the tornado caused destruction in the area of the CPC on Route 20, particularly in the neighborhoods of Ameguino Norte, San Roque, and Villa La Tela, where most of the deaths, injuries, and damage occurred.

The National Meteorological Service informed Civil Defense authorities, Police, Emergency Services, Firefighters, and the media about what was happening in the afternoon in Córdoba. Surprised by the phenomenon, a strong rescue operation was organized for those affected by the tornado. Upon arrival at the scene, they encountered a desolate landscape: people mourning their material losses; furniture, beds, sheets, roofs scattered everywhere; fallen poles and cables; uprooted trees; etc. The tornado, which lasted 24 minutes, devastated two neighborhoods and an emergency settlement, and the winds caused damage in forty more neighborhoods, with intensity increasing as it approached the area where the funnel began. Unfortunately, five lives were lost, more than 90 people were injured, and about 5,000 were evacuated. The Police could not prevent unknown individuals from stealing belongings left outdoors after the storm. In other nearby towns like Villa Carlos Paz or La Calera, less intense damage was reported. The strong and sudden rise of rivers filled lakes and reservoirs to their limits, prompting the National Government and DIPAS to order the opening of floodgates, causing post-dam rivers to rise sharply as well. The tornado was classified as F3: that is, winds of 290 to 320 km per hour.

Info_Box:
Fatal victims (in total): 5  
Total damages: (estimate, {{{year}}})  
Affected areas: Neighborhoods of the CPC Ruta 20 sector in Cordoba Capital

Whole_Text.content: The Ficksburg tornado occurred on October 2, 2011, in the western parts of the informal settlement, Meqheleng, near Ficksburg. The storm broke out around 2:00 PM. In this disaster, a nine-year-old boy, Jama Mokhekhe, died due to trauma to the intestines and multiple wounds caused by flying debris, while dozens were injured (2 of them seriously) and hundreds were left homeless. One hundred and twenty-two RDP houses were destroyed. The ambulance service transported 42 injured people to the Phutuloha hospital and treated them for cuts, bruises, and bleeding. There are differences of opinion on whether this tornado should be identified as a freak occurrence or not. Although tornadoes do occur in South Africa during spring and summer, they typically only truly begin from November.

The tornado in Litovel was a tornado that swept through the town of Litovel on Wednesday, June 9, 2004. It was an F3 strength tornado, corresponding to wind speeds of 252 to 332 km/h. The phenomenon affected approximately one-third of the ten-thousand-strong town and caused damages exceeding 100 million Czech crowns. In the Litovel brewery alone, the damage was estimated at 30 million. The path of the greatest damage stretched along the branch of the Morava River in a relatively narrow strip from Víska to the brewery and Chořelice up to Březové. The most affected part of Litovel was G. Frištenský Street and its immediate surroundings. The storm broke trees, smashed doors and windows, and tore off roofs. Eleven houses were structurally damaged, and two were ordered to be demolished. The Security Council of the Olomouc Region declared a state of danger for the town and its local part, Chořelice. The entire integrated rescue system of the Olomouc Region was involved in the damage removal, and the army also assisted.

Article_Name: Tornado de San Carlos de 1981, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The San Carlos tornado of 1981 was a meteorological phenomenon that occurred on May 18, 1981, in the city of San Carlos, and also affected part of Cachapoal, now the Ñuble Region, Chile. This area, like the rest of the country, is not prone to this type of climatic phenomenon; however, a similar event occurred again in the city in 2013, though not as destructive as this one. It was classified as F3 on the Fujita-Pearson scale.

The tornado originated about 55 kilometers west of the city of San Carlos and disappeared 25 kilometers east of it, in the town of Cachapoal; that is, it traveled 80 kilometers from west to east in a time of 38 minutes. In San Carlos, it passed through the "Barrio Estación" and the very center of the city, passing by the potable water tank that supplies it. It originated at 10:10 local time.

In San Carlos, a large part of the San Carlos Station was destroyed, leaving it without a roof and windows. The Plaza de Armas was completely destroyed, trees over 50 years old were uprooted, the locally famous store "El Caballo" was destroyed, part of its building collapsed, as well as the municipal building and the fire station were affected. Small commercial establishments were also devastated, and many people and vehicles were thrown into the air like mere toys. It is, without a doubt, the most destructive tornado in the last 100 years in Chile, surpassing the one in Villarrica in 2011 and the one in Concepción in 1934. The power outage lasted several days due to the fall of at least 400 power poles, potable water was restored on May 22, and classes were suspended for 2 weeks. A total of 2 deaths, 1 missing person, 323 injured, and 1,524 affected individuals were estimated. About 480 homes were severely affected.

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about Belgium and firefighters or civil protection. The Oostmalle tornado is the name given to a tornado that struck, on June 25, 1967, the region of Oostmalle, in the north of Belgium, in the province of Antwerp, as well as part of the south of the Netherlands, where it is known as the Tricht tornado. This natural disaster caused seven deaths. The tornado was classified as an F3 on the Fujita scale.

Article_Name: Tornado de San Carlos de 2013, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The San Carlos tornado of 2013 was a meteorological phenomenon that occurred on Friday, May 31, 2013, in the city of San Carlos, Ñuble Region, Chile. This area, like the rest of the country, is not prone to this type of climatic phenomenon; however, a similar event occurred in the city in 1981. It was classified as F2 on the Fujita-Pearson scale according to National Geographic.

On Friday, May 31, 2013, the central and southern zones of Chile were affected by a frontal system coming from the Pacific Ocean for two days. The tornado occurred around 11:20 a.m. outside the San Carlos Municipal Cemetery, where it destroyed some flower shops, moved eastward along Navotavo Street, a busy area in the city, destroying and damaging houses in its path, and disappeared about 500 meters further up, where it destroyed a large part of a hardware store. It originated from the appearance of a cloud called "Cumulonimbus," which forms after a frontal system, such as the one that affected Chile during those days. The cloud, in turn, was caused by a sudden temperature change, explained by the warming of the ground and the cold air, which creates atmospheric pressure between the ground and the air; this produces a downdraft from the cloud to the ground, which spins at speeds between 200 to 250 kilometers per hour (the San Carlos tornado reached 228 km/h) and moves randomly with a force capable of destroying everything in its path. It is worth noting that the phenomenon remains active as long as the temperature difference between the ground and the air is significant, usually lasting no more than 20 minutes (the San Carlos tornado lasted 12) before disappearing.

ONEMI declared a state of emergency in the commune and surrounding areas, including the localities of Cachapoal (where a rumor mentioned that the tornado also affected this town), Ninhue, San Fabián de Alico, San Gregorio de Ñiquén, and San Nicolás. At the time of the tornado, the "Violeta Parra Sandoval High School" was in the middle of classes, with about 600 students and staff inside, who, according to local news reports, "took cover under the tables while the windows shattered and the roof was blown off." This caused chaos among parents in the area who, in addition to the confusion caused by this unusual event, were withdrawing their children amidst the chaos, with one person injured. Other schools and high schools in the city were also forced to release students due to the collective panic in the city. Regarding damages, the Violeta Parra High School was left with some classrooms without roofs and broken windows, classes were suspended for one week, a wall on Navotavo Street collapsed, blocking part of the road, city collective transit was halted, and a power outage affected Cachapoal, Ninquihue, and San Fabián de Alico. Additionally, two community centers and about five flower shops located outside the Municipal Cemetery were affected. However, the symbol of the disaster was the "Almet Hardware Store," which was severely destroyed and became the media figure of the tornado. In terms of personal injuries, no fatalities were reported, but there were two injuries: one inspector from Violeta Parra High School who was struck by a zinc sheet from the school's roof, and one pedestrian on Navotavo Street who was injured by the collapse of a wall. In the end, 103 homes were affected to varying degrees, 47 of them uninhabitable, with a total of 412 people affected and 232 displaced.

Article_Name: Tornado de Madrid de 1886, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Madrid tornado of May 12, 1886, was a violent storm episode in the south of the Spanish city of Madrid, which triggered a tornado in the then-independent municipality of Carabanchel Alto, also affecting the municipalities of Carabanchel Bajo and the city of Madrid itself. It followed a SW-NE trajectory. It caused severe material damage and fatalities (47, according to some sources). Augusto Arcimís—in his chronicle of May 22, 1886, in La Ilustración Española y Americana—details the occurrence of two separate tornadoes that day; one that reportedly began at 6:50 PM near Carabanchel Alto and another at 7:01 PM. The phenomenon was treated by scientists of the time as "the passage of a cyclone" rather than a tornado. The event is mentioned by Benito Pérez Galdós in his novel Misericordia.

Article_Name: Wirbelsturm in Oberbayern vom 14. Juli 1894 – Wikipedia

Whole_Text.header: Cyclone in Upper Bavaria on July 14, 1894
Whole_Text.content: The hurricane of July 14, 1894, caused significant damage to the northern edge of the Ebersberg Forest, about 30 km east of Munich.[1] The church tower of the church in the village of Forstern was severely damaged; the debris damaged the entire church. There were two fatalities and further injuries. Years earlier, damage had already been caused in the region by the nun moth infestation.[1] The Coburg newspaper reported: "Munich, July 16. Several localities in Upper Bavaria were struck by a cyclone-like whirlwind on Saturday; 200 properties were destroyed. 100 pioneers have been sent to provide assistance."[2] The Münchner Neuesten Nachrichten of July 17, 1894, reported: "A severe hailstorm descended on our city today between 2:30 PM and 3:00 PM amidst lightning and thunder. The sky was so dark that it was difficult to read indoors. The hailstones fell with terrible force and were the size of hazelnuts, some even the size of pigeon eggs. The paths in the parks were covered with leaves and branches. Around 6 PM, a strong storm wind developed as the air cooled, appearing in gusts and gaining significant force, then it began to rain with lightning and thunder. Trudering was heavily affected by the hail. Hailstones the size of chicken eggs fell from the sky, and all the windows on the west side of the newly built schoolhouse were shattered. Many birds, partridges, and hares were killed outdoors. Roofs in Feldkirchen and Salmdorf were also damaged by the hail."[3]

The tornado of Uetersen occurred on August 10, 1925. The affected areas were the city of Uetersen in Schleswig-Holstein, as well as the municipalities of Neuendeich, Heidgraben, Moorrege, and Tornesch. There was damage to buildings, fields, and forests. It was particularly reported that a "1/2 pound piece of ice" had pierced a roof. There was one fatality and many injuries. In June 2004, another tornado passed over Uetersen.

The tornado in Bützow was a tornado of level F3 (Fujita scale / TORRO scale) that passed through the town in 2015. This corresponds to wind speeds between 255 km/h and 335 km/h, tending towards the lower range.

The tornado passed through Bützow in the Rostock district on the evening of May 5, 2015, between 6:45 PM and 6:50 PM. About 30 people were injured. Further into the city, a car was displaced by 70 meters, which also indicates a storm of the mentioned strength. Sixteen houses were so severely damaged that they were declared uninhabitable and had to be sealed off. The tornado's path was 14.8 kilometers long and extended to the east of Kassow. The swath was on average 600 meters wide, and in some places up to 1,500 meters wide. It was a so-called "wedge tornado." The whirlwind was a so-called multi-vortex tornado, meaning it consisted of several sub-vortices. At the time of the tornado, the associated supercell displayed a clearly visible hook echo. By 2017, the majority of the damage, which amounted to around 40 million euros, had been repaired.

On May 5, 2015, the center of the low-pressure system Zoran was located over the British Isles. It brought warm air from North Africa and the Mediterranean region to Germany, causing daytime temperatures to rise to values between 20°C and 27°C. Ahead of the cold front, heavy rainfall with thunderstorms moved eastward over northern Germany from the Netherlands. A shortwave trough at high altitude intensified the lifting processes at the air mass boundary. In southern Germany, the development of thunderstorms was prevented until the evening by a strong foehn wind, which reached gusts of up to 120 km/h on the Zugspitze. In these thunderstorms, some of which were accompanied by hail, certain gusts reached hurricane strength. At least six tornadoes emerged from these thunderstorms in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, with the tornado in Bützow being the strongest. A tornado observed in Groß Laasch reached strength F2. The two tornadoes in Brüel and Ahrensbök reached strength F1. Additionally, there were several suspected tornado cases, including in Lübeck.

Article_Name: Tornados em Santa Catarina em 2015 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content:
Edit - edit source code - edit Wikidata  
On April 20, 2015, two tornadoes hit the western part of the state of Santa Catarina, Brazil. At least three cities were directly affected: Ponte Serrada, Passos Maia, and Xanxerê. Around 800,000 people were impacted by the effects of the tornadoes and strong winds that struck the region. Two people died. There were 300 emergency medical treatments, and 100 people were taken to hospitals. Of these, three had recorded amputations. At that time, there were at least 2,100 displaced people in the city and 186 homeless.

The tornadoes were produced by a high-precipitation tornadic supercell, based on radar and satellite images. In Xanxerê, a large "wedge" tornado, officially classified as F3, crossed the entire northwest/north/northeast of the municipality, traveling from west to east until dissipating at the outskirts of the municipality. Another rain-wrapped tornado affected Passos Maia and Ponte Serrada on the same day, and it was classified as F1.

The Federal Government sent the army to assist in the recovery and reconstruction of the affected neighborhoods in Xanxerê, the most affected city. A partial report from Civil Defense, released on April 22, indicates damages of R$ 29 million in Xanxerê. Still in Xanxerê, 115 houses were completely destroyed, 221 houses were partially destroyed, 251 houses were completely unroofed, and another 282 partially unroofed. The tornado hit 9 public buildings, including 4 schools, 1 health center, the municipal gymnasium, the municipal stadium, and 2 Socio-Educational Centers. According to public authorities' forecasts, the reconstruction of the damages may take three years. The Chaco Low-Pressure System, located between the southern region of Brazil, Argentina, and Paraguay, is considered the second most favorable place in the world for the development of major storms, which can result in tornadoes. This region is known as the Tornado Corridor of South America. The state of Santa Catarina has already recorded about seven tornadoes in recent years. A survey conducted by the University Center for Disaster Studies and Research (CEPED/UFSC) indicates that between 1976 and 2009, at least 77 tornadoes were recorded in the state.

Article_Name: Tornado de Estación López de 1992, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Tornado of Estación López was an F4 category tornado that affected the town of López, in the province of Buenos Aires, on Wednesday, May 6, 1992, causing 4 deaths, more than 100 injuries, and millions of pesos in material losses. According to experts, this tornado is one of the most destructive in South America, only behind the San Justo Tornado.

Minutes before 6:30 PM (the time when the tornado struck the town), a strong and typical storm with heavy rain and hail was occurring. Later, the rain had stopped, and like the hail, according to testimonies, everything was very "calm and silent." The clock struck 6:30 PM, and a massive funnel touched down a few meters from the station, moved towards it, and destroyed everything in its path. The tornado lasted just over 2 minutes, leaving only 5 houses standing. The wind exceeded 370 km/h [citation needed], and a 15-year-old girl was sucked in by the tornado, lifted about 7 meters, and then violently thrown to the ground.

The tornado left 4 dead and more than 100 injured. Only 5 houses were left standing. The local church was also destroyed. The railway station building, a solid English brick construction with 60 cm thick walls, was demolished by the tornado. Surprised by the event, the locals organized themselves and helped the injured out from under the rubble. The dead were transported to the city of Benito Juárez and buried in the cemetery. With the help of the provincial government of Dr. Eduardo Duhalde, Mayor Santana Estanislao Zabalza carried out the reconstruction of the station in 5 months, and on October 31 of the same year, the happy reconstruction of the station was celebrated with an event attended by the entire town.

Article_Name: Tornade de Sonnac du 16 septembre 2015 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content:
Modify - modify the code - modify Wikidata  
The Sonnac tornado is a moderate-intensity tornado that struck several municipalities in Charente-Maritime on Wednesday, September 16, 2015. The French Observatory of Tornadoes and Severe Storms (Keraunos) classifies it as an EF2 intensity tornado[1], on the Enhanced Fujita scale. It caused significant damage in its path, such as partially destroyed homes. It is part of a tornado outbreak (clustered tornado episode) that totaled 3 cases for the day of September 16, 2015, including the EF1 tornado in Courtenay (Loiret) and the EF1 tornado in Jandun (Ardennes)[1]. This tornado is said to have traveled more than 70 km, making it the second-longest distance traveled by a tornado in France, after the EF4 tornado in Saint-Claude on August 19, 1890[3],[4]. It formed at 4:10 PM in the municipality of Chaniers, crossed the municipalities of La Chapelle-des-Pots, Saint-Césaire, Saint-Bris-des-Bois, Villars-les-Bois, Migron, Mons, Prignac, Thors, Matha, Sonnac, Haimps, Massac, Beauvais-sur-Matha, Bazauges, Ranville-Breuillaud, Barbezières, Lupsault, Saint-Fraigne, Ébréon, Souvigné, Courcôme, Raix, La Faye before dissipating in Condac around 5:05 PM. In total, the tornado crossed 24 municipalities in Charente and Charente-Maritime[5]. Its maximum intensity seems to have been reached between the municipalities of Thors and Sonnac, where the damage was most significant.

The day of Wednesday, September 16, 2015, saw the placement of a depression trough of 985 hPa over the Bay of Biscay, inducing a strong southwesterly flow ahead of this depression. This barometric trough was located south of a large upper-level trough, which had also absorbed the former tropical storm Henri. At altitude, a fairly strong southwesterly jet stream had formed, bringing tropical and humid air. Already during the night of September 15 to 16, a succession of sometimes strong thunderstorms had formed near the Atlantic coasts, with instability becoming increasingly pronounced. These storms were quite windy with brief but strong gusts of wind. In the morning, the storms decreased slightly in intensity, but the instability was still present. The sky in La Rochelle, at dawn, was pre-stormy, with some breaks of blue sky to the west and distant lightning to the east. At 1 p.m., a few hours before the tornado formed, a new storm passed through Charente-Maritime. The electrical activity was relatively weak. In Bordeaux, Gironde, the radiosonde indicated moderate instability, with a convective available potential energy (CAPE) of 1,006 J/kg, as well as a lifting index (LI) of -5 K, which is quite significant. The jet stream was expected to reach 250 km/h. The relative helicity was measured at 535 m²/s² in the first three kilometers of altitude, and 208 m²/s² in the first kilometer, indicating a tornado risk. The temperatures at 2 meters were high in Bordeaux (27°C) but contrasted with those recorded in Blaye (18°C), for example. This strong thermal contrast is explained by the presence of a very active cold front between the two cities. The above radiosonde indicates the atmospheric conditions in Bordeaux at 2 p.m., just before the passage of the cold front. The radiosonde explains why a tornado had formed just south of the squall line. An additional warming of 1 or 2 K due to sunlight would have caused the lifting index (LI) to drop from -5 K to -7 K, which significantly increased the severity of the storms, even though the level of free convection varied little and the cumulonimbus clouds remained modest in thickness. The above radiosonde indicates that the top of the cumulonimbus was at about 300 hPa, or 9,000 m. The cumulonimbus was therefore not very thick. The photograph from the Keraunos site confirms this fact, showing that the cumulonimbus was not very spectacular.

At 1:45 PM, radar images revealed a storm cell over the Bay of Biscay, heading towards the Charente coastline. Quite active, this storm was quickly organizing into a retrograde-propagating linear system. At 3:00 PM, the storm reached the Charente coastline, initially between Rochefort and La Tremblade. Still fairly well-organized, producing gusts locally reaching 70 km/h. However, electrical activity remained low. The line was moving along a southwest/northeast axis, still in retrograde propagation. The northern part of the storm line tended to weaken, while the southern part retained its wind potential. No rotation was yet observed. At 3:30 PM, the line weakened in the north, where the rain became stratiform. Convective energy persisted in the southern part of the line, where unstable cells were developing and moving along the squall, heading northeast. These rare storms were most often embedded in the rainy mass. At 3:45 PM, a new cell developed at the extreme south of the line, near Royan. This particular cell would become tornadic several minutes later. At 4:00 PM, this same storm became quite active, with hail potential. This cell began to exhibit a low-top supercellular behavior (in English, Low Top or mini-supercell). A wall cloud quickly formed at the base of this mini-supercell. A shelf cloud was also visible ahead of the storm line. At 4:10 PM, a funnel cloud, or tuba, formed at the base of the wall cloud, followed by some debris starting to swirl. The tornado had thus formed, gaining intensity. On precipitation radars, the rotation was clearly visible above Chaniers. At 4:45 PM, the tornado reached its maximum intensity as it traveled through the commune of Sonnac and its surroundings. It was in this area that it caused the most damage. At 5:10 PM, the tornado finally dissipated, as did the storm cell, which became just a weakening rain line over the following minutes.

The tornado in Prague in 1119 was a tornado that struck Prague on July 30, 1119. A mention of it can be found in Cosmas's Chronicle of the Czechs: From the description, it is clear that it was a tornado; it is the oldest known mention of a tornado in the Czech lands. The strength of the tornado is estimated based on the description of the aftermath to be F3 to F4. If it were an F4 tornado, it would, along with the tornado in the Břeclav and Hodonín regions from June 2021, be the strongest known tornado in the Czech lands.
Drought in the Czech Republic 2015–2020

The tornado in Forbygda in 1967 occurred on July 11, 1967, in Budal and Singsås in Midtre Gauldal municipality. The tornado started at Storrø fellesseter in Budal and ended on the eastern side of Forbygda in Singsås. This is a distance of approximately 20 km in a straight line. Eyewitnesses estimated that the tornado traveled from Storrø fellesseter over Svardal, Bakkløkkja, up through Bakkmarka, Buslettkjølen, and Svartåsen. A wide path of about 20–30 meters was visible where the forest was twisted and mowed down. The storm occurred in the afternoon. At the Langrødstrø farm in Singsås, all four buildings were destroyed by the storm. Adresseavisen wrote that it began to thicken around 4 PM. This is recounted in the journal Far tå folk 2016[1]. Half an hour later, hailstorms came, and shortly after, it got even worse. At Langrødstrø, three people were present. They had to escape the skewed house by crawling out through a window. A witness on the other side of the valley told Adresseavisen that the whirlwind was gray like a cloud and moved at great speed. All the roofs at Langrødstrø were peeled off. The tornado continued down through the valley, a bit up the river, crossed it, and moved toward the farms on the other side. However, in the steep ascent, the tornado lost much of its strength. Corrugated iron sheets, magazines, and clothes fell around the farms, 1 km from where the wind had picked them up. The tornado caused significant damage to forests and buildings during the short time it lasted. The hailstorms contained hailstones as large as plums, according to witness accounts reported in Far tå folk. No people were injured. The destruction at Langrødstrøa attracted great attention in both local and national media. NRK had a report on Dagsrevyen on July 12, the day after, and Adresseavisen, Arbeideravisa, and Aftenposten had front-page coverage with pictures the same day. Several articles followed in other newspapers in the days afterward. A fundraising campaign was initiated for those affected by the storm. Midtre Gauldal municipality also provided financial assistance.[1]

Article_Name: Tornado im Kreis Viersen vom 16. Mai 2018 – Wikipedia

Whole_Text.header: Tornado in the Viersen district on May 16, 2018
Whole_Text.content: On May 16, 2018, between 5:50 PM and 6 PM, a tornado swept over parts of Boisheim, Schaag, Dilkrath, and the beginning of Amern. All the mentioned locations are in the Viersen district, a few kilometers apart. It was a tornado of category F2/T4 (Fujita scale & TORRO scale) (T4 stands for maximum wind speeds between 185 and 220 kilometers per hour). Furthermore, it was a so-called multi-vortex tornado, which appeared very impressive due to the swirling dust. The approximately 5.4-kilometer-long path of the tornado averaged 120 meters in width but was up to 240 meters wide in some places. A 23-year-old man was hit by falling branches and had to be treated in the hospital. The roofs of some houses were partially uncovered by the storm. Some roads were temporarily blocked by fallen avenue trees or branches; the country road between Boisheim and Brüggen (L 373) was closed near Dilkrath for over a week.

The tornado formed north of Boisheim and moved southwest directly into the city center, where it caused initial damage in the F1/T2 range (Fujita scale & TORRO scale) along a path up to 130 meters wide. After crossing the railway tracks in the northern part of the city, it continued across the entire city. In this section, damage was only recorded in the F0/T1 range; the tornado temporarily weakened in this area. The tornado regained strength as it reached the cemetery on the southwestern outskirts; at this point, it reached F1/T3 strength over a width of approximately 200 meters. Subsequently, the tornado turned south, maintaining a consistent width of around 190 meters up to the L3. When the tornado crossed the L3, a forested area was almost completely destroyed over at least 240 meters; at this point, the tornado reached F2/T4 intensity. After crossing the L3, the tornado moved southwest again, passing Heidend and Dilkrath, where it caused F0/T1 damage at the town entrance. The next 2.2 kilometers of the path ran over open fields without any known damage. The tornado caused its last damage at the town entrance of Amern, where it reached F1 status. The tornado likely dissipated a few meters further, as its trail disappears at this point.

Article_Name: Tornade du 18 juin 1897 à Asnières-sur-Seine — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The Asnières-sur-Seine tornado of June 18, 1897, is a violent meteorological phenomenon that affected Asnières-sur-Seine and its surroundings[1].

On June 18, 1897, a depression covered the west of Europe, and storms formed in the Paris region coming from the southwest. Large hail was reported from Meudon to Choisy-le-Roi. In Paris, there was only a little rain and small hailstones while the tornado followed a path from Courbevoie, to La Garenne-Colombes, to Asnières-sur-Seine, to Gennevilliers, to Saint-Ouen, and ended in Le Bourget. The total trajectory was 21 kilometers with an average width of 150 meters but sometimes up to 250 meters. The report from the Asnières meteorological station showed that the tornado passed at 4:50 PM, with the pressure dropping to 746.3 mm Hg (994.98 hPa) and the anemometer reaching its limit of 30 meters per second (108 km/h), thus unable to provide the exact speed. Another station 500 meters from the trajectory recorded no drop at all, showing that the effect was limited to the axis of movement. Its movement speed was estimated at 180 km/h, which should be taken with caution given the limited measurement tools of the time.

Along the trajectory, trees were uprooted or broken, crops were damaged, fences were overturned, fairground rides were destroyed, and buildings were damaged or destroyed. An individual was thrown a distance and killed by the fall, a car was thrown 29 meters along with its horse, two 20 kg concrete blocks and other objects were thrown a distance. Damage was notably reported by the press: According to this damage, the winds were estimated to be between 220 and 270 km/h.

Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata  
The Montville tornado, also called the Montville waterspout at the time, is the deadliest tornado ever recorded in France with seventy-five deaths. On August 19, 1845, it caused significant damage in the industrial valley of Malaunay and Montville, in Seine-Inférieure. This tornado is one of only two in France, along with the one in Palluel (Pas-de-Calais) in 1967, to have been classified (retrospectively and unofficially) at level 5 on the Fujita scale[1].

Around noon, a storm breaks out in the Rouen region, causing heavy rainfall. The tornado forms around 1 p.m. near the commune of Le Houlme and moves through the Cailly Valley towards Malaunay, quickly gaining immense strength. Along its path, it destroys homes and uproots hundreds of trees, some of which are carried away whole in the whirlwind. In the industrial valley, three textile mills are leveled. In Malaunay, the Neveu mill, a solid four-story building, is the first to be destroyed, followed by the Mare Frères workshops in the same commune and the Picquot-Deschamps mill in Montville. The latter was housed in a new brick building that could not withstand the tornado's power. The 150-meter chimney is torn down. According to analyses from the time, the tornado continues its path through the Clères forest, covering a total distance of about fifteen kilometers before dissipating in Grugny.

The damage is considerable. Debris was found in Saint-Victor and Torcy-le-Grand, 30 km from Montville, which testifies to the destructive force of the phenomenon. In the woods belonging to Deputy Charles Levavasseur, two to three hundred beeches were uprooted. The three mills in the valley, which concentrated most of the industrial activity, ceased to exist. The human toll is the heaviest ever recorded in France for a tornado. Among the 200 to 370 mill workers who were at work at the time, very few were able to take shelter, especially since, due to its large diameter, the funnel encompassed most of the valley. Dozens of bodies and injured people, sometimes horribly mutilated, were extracted from the debris by nearby residents who came to help. The interior of the factories is described as "a slaughterhouse of human flesh," according to the newspaper La Presse. Mr. Neveu himself was pulled alive from the rubble but was very shocked. He had protected his mother with his body, and she emerged unscathed. After three hours of prostration, he declared: "I know I am ruined, but I do not complain; I had the happiness of saving my mother." An ambulance service was set up, and doctors arrived from Rouen. The director of the Cheval-Noir, a local hotel, made his establishment, linens, and furniture available to them. The priest of Montville and other clergymen attended to the injured, offering prayers and comfort. The families of the victims were sent away to allow the doctors to work under the best conditions, which led to scenes of despair. As the mutilated bodies of two young girls were removed from Picquot's house, their mother recognized them and, in her grief, threw herself into the river, where she drowned. The clearing work lasted until the next day. In total, 75 deaths were counted after the disaster. On August 21, Prefect Henri Dupont-Delporte and the field marshal visited the injured and assessed the damage. A subscription for the benefit of the victims and their families was opened at the Rouen town hall, and Mayor Henry Barbet posted an appeal for donations throughout the city. Charity performances were held: in Rouen itself on September 9 and in Paris, at the Circus, on the same day, then at the Théâtre des Variétés, which was packed on September 12. The Norman writer Eugène Noël witnessed the disaster and participated in the rescue efforts with Charles Michelet (the son of historian Jules Michelet), who was among the survivors. He had been walking in the woods at the time of the tornado's passage.

Gustave Flaubert, a native of the region, mentions the event in one of his letters to Louise Colet, dated August 26, 1846: "How much I have heard, mercy! How much I endured last year of those magnificent dissertations on the Monville waterspout! – 'Why did it happen? How did it come about? Can one conceive of it? Is it the electricity from above or from below? In one second, three factories overturned and two hundred men killed! What a horror!'" The testimony of Eugène Noël was published in 1876 in the book *Trombes et cyclones* by Frédéric Zurcher and Élie Philippe Margollé.

A tornado near Novska in 1892 struck the area of the Novska railway station and nearby forests on the afternoon of May 31, 1892, at 4:17 PM, causing significant damage. The tornado derailed some train cars of a train that had departed for Nova Gradiška at 4:17 PM. The rear car, weighing over 13 tons, was thrown 30 meters away, even crossing telegraph wires. The train carried about fifty passengers, three of whom were seriously injured, and one shepherd was killed. Based on the direction of overturned train cars and trees in the nearby forest, Mohorovičić concluded that the wind in that area was cyclonic and estimated its speed to be between 46 and 158 m/s. The tornado consisted of two vortices, meaning there were two tornadoes. The storm developed on the southeastern edge of a storm front moving northeast. The edge of this front coincided with low air pressure in the northern Bosnia and Herzegovina region. Temperatures were very high for that time of year, and there was a significant temperature difference between the coastal area and the interior. During the tornado, the temperature dropped by 10°C. According to today's classifications, this would be a T6 tornado, or a moderately destructive tornado. Lieutenant Kaudermat recounts the following: After the train left Dubica, I saw terrifying clouds in the direction of Sisak; the heat was unbearable, and the humidity was oppressive. After leaving Jasenovac, I saw a similar cloud to the southwest, like a huge semicircle, dark brown in color. The rest of the sky was relatively clear, covered with thinner clouds. Shortly before the train departed from Novska, I saw a long funnel descending from that dark mass toward the ground, precisely over the forest (Greda). The funnel was wide where it connected to the main cloud mass, narrowing toward the ground, and then widening again just above the ground. Within the funnel, very rapid rotation around its axis could be seen, moving to the left. In the aftermath of the damage, particularly in the export of massive quantities of fallen Slavonian oaks, new settlers arrived from across Austria-Hungary, including a large number of craftsmen who permanently settled in the Novska area.

Due to heavy rain, water broke through the railway embankment in some places, and in the fields, it was up to one meter high. At the station itself, the roof of the main building, the warehouse, and the guardhouse was blown off. Up to 150,000 oaks and beeches were destroyed.

Info_Box:
Type: Tornado  
Damage: More than 155,000 trees destroyed, damaged structures near the railway station  
Casualties: 1 dead, 3 seriously injured  
Affected areas: Novska railway station and nearby forest

Whole_Text.content: The Roodepoort tornado of 1948 was, up to that time, the tornado that caused the greatest damage in Southern Africa. Late in the afternoon of November 26, the tornado developed about 20 km southwest of Roodepoort. At 5:45 PM, it reached the town along with a heavy thunderstorm and caused millions of rands in damage in just five minutes in a strip 300 m wide and 3 km long. Lightning, pouring rain, and a severe hailstorm worsened the storm damage. The eye of the whirlwind moved northeast at 40 km per hour. All 15 times the funnel touched the ground, it caused great destruction: 700 houses were flattened, and power and railway lines were destroyed. A miracle was that no fires broke out. After an hour, it had almost dissipated 64 km from its starting point. Miraculously, only 4 people died in the town, and 70 were injured. Strangely enough, a much less powerful tornado also struck the town in February 1935, blowing roofs off houses, uprooting trees, and toppling telephone poles. South Africa, with its high occurrence of thunderstorms, is very fortunate not to be plagued by a large number of tornadoes. Tornadoes are actually rare in the country. In the Western Cape, a tornado is an unknown phenomenon. Yet Malmesbury was struck by one on September 29, 1905. Five people died, many were injured, houses and business buildings were destroyed, and the full river flowed through the buildings. The most devastating tornado South Africa has ever experienced was on January 18, 1999, when Mount Ayliff was struck, resulting in 25 deaths and 500 injuries. Other well-known tornadoes include the Ficksburg tornado and the Duduza tornado.
The tornado in Kiel injured several people on Wednesday evening, September 29, 2021.

The tornado moved from south-southeast to north-northeast over a distance of 14.5 km through Meimersdorf, Gaarden, Kiel, Düsternbrook, Holtenau, Pries, and had a width of approximately 70 meters. Depending on the source, there is also mention of two separate tornadoes.

At 5:38 PM, an F1 tornado (Fujita scale: wind speeds of 118 to 180 km/h) passed through parts of the city of Kiel. Affected areas included the new development areas of Kiel-Meimersdorf and Kiel-Gaarden, where roofs were damaged. According to the police, several people were swept through the air and into the water along the Kiellinie. Four people were seriously injured, and three others sustained moderate injuries. Additionally, there were several minor injuries.

Article_Name: Tornado em Itaqui em 1997 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: The tornado in Itaqui in 1997 was a sequence of events that began on the morning of October 28. With winds estimated at over 250 km/h and hail, the storm injured 24 people and affected around 3,000 properties. A large part of the municipality was left without electricity, and approximately 12,000 people were left homeless.

The western region of the state of Rio Grande do Sul was experiencing one of the worst floods of the Uruguay River. Itaqui was the city most affected by the flood, 8,000 people were left homeless, in the rural area, about 4,500 hectares of rice were lost, and classes were suspended.

On the morning of October 28, the locality was directly hit by a violent storm accompanied by an F3 tornado, with winds estimated at over 250 km/h and hail. All the power poles in the municipality were knocked down, rice mills were destroyed, about 200 houses were completely destroyed, and 3,000 were unroofed. The municipality was left completely incommunicado. At least 24 people were injured, but no fatalities were reported. [citation needed]
The president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, and the governor of Rio Grande do Sul, Antônio Britto, called Mayor José Silas Goulart to inquire about the event.

Article_Name: Tornado de São Miguel das Missões em 2016 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.header: Tornado of São Miguel das Missões in 2016
Whole_Text.content: The Tornado of São Miguel das Missões occurred on April 24, 2016, affecting the northeastern region of Rio Grande do Sul and damaging many residences, including the hospital and the municipality's museum. The Tornado injured 8 people in the city. The locations received a lot of foreign aid, allowing the place to rebuild itself.
According to the Fujita Scale, the intensity of the phenomenon is debated between F2 and F3, with most pointing to F3, with winds from 180 km/h to 332 km/h.

Article_Name: Tornado em Sumaré e na região de Campinas em 2001 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.header: Tornado in Sumaré and the Campinas region in 2001
Whole_Text.content: The tornado in Sumaré and the Campinas region in 2001 occurred on May 4, 2001, and caused the Brazilian municipality of Sumaré to enter a state of emergency. It was classified as an F3 tornado on the Fujita Scale and hit several cities in the Campinas region.

In Sumaré, Mayor Dirceu Dalben (PPS) called on public employees to help clean the streets and restore the municipality. The strong storm, with winds of up to 300 km/h and lasting five minutes, uprooted trees, knocked down poles, unroofed houses, lifted sidewalks, and left a large part of the city without electricity. The Civil Defense and the Fire Department have not yet confirmed the total number of injured to date. The phenomenon was caused by the meeting of a cold front with the region's heat in recent days. Among the affected municipalities, in addition to Sumaré, are Americana, Paulínia, Itatiba, Campinas, and Santa Bárbara D'Oeste. 

On the morning of the following day, the city was still suffering from the consequences of the tornado. The electricity supply had not been fully restored, further compromising water distribution. Public telephones were not working during the morning, and communication services were seriously affected. 

Of the 150 displaced people, only four families have not yet been able to return to their homes, which were destroyed by the strong winds of up to 300 km/h. The mayor also said he is counting on private initiatives and donations of construction materials, as well as the provision of labor, to speed up the municipality's recovery efforts. 

The tornado affected an area of 40 kilometers. The city of Sumaré was in its path and was the most affected. The wind twisted power transmission towers, unroofed industries and houses, and uprooted at least four thousand trees. "For this type of damage to structures, such as breaking poles and bending transmission towers, the wind speed must have been approximately 300 km/h," assessed researcher Hilton Silveira from Unicamp.

The storm, which began around 4 p.m. in Piracicaba, passed through seven cities and reached Campinas around 5 p.m., lasting until 7 p.m. In Campinas, a Banco Real agency was partially destroyed. Neighborhoods in the eastern and northern zones of the city were without power until 10:30 p.m. A pile-up at kilometer 76 of the Santos Dumont highway involving three cars caused congestion in the early evening. There were no injuries. The winds also knocked down the fence of Penitentiary 2 in Hortolândia. In Americana, the rain lasted 15 minutes, and a house was hit by a tree in the Nova Americana neighborhood. There were no injuries.

Article_Name: Tornado tra Padova e Venezia del 1970

Whole_Text.header: Tornado between Padua and Venice in 1970
Whole_Text.content: The tornado between Padua and Venice in 1970 was a meteorological event that occurred on the night of September 11, 1970. The tornado, estimated to be an F4 category on the Fujita scale, traveled about 70 km in one hour, causing 36 deaths, around 500 injuries, and enormous damage estimated at 5 billion lire of the time.

At 8:45 PM, a powerful tornado began to form over the Euganean Hills, particularly affecting Teolo and Rovolon in the province of Padua. Moving eastward towards Abano Terme, the wind struck Selvazzano Dentro, the southern outskirts of Padua, and the lower Padua area, including Ponte San Nicolò. At 9:05 PM, the tornado caused the partial collapse of the Zen Foundries in Albignasego, resulting in the first death and injuries. Entering the province of Venice, the storm damaged more than 60 houses, with four injuries reported in Vigonovo, Tombelle, Caltana, and Fossò, followed by damage to 150 buildings in Camponogara (with four injuries) and 120 buildings in the Miranese area (particularly in Dogaletto and Giare di Mira), with nine more injuries. Reaching the "Camping Fusina" campsite, the tornado swept away over 2,000 trees, tents, and bungalows (causing one death and 14 injuries), continuing towards Venice, passing just south of the island of Giudecca. At 9:32 PM, the tornado severely hit the island of Le Grazie and its architectural complex, then uprooted trees and damaged roofs on the island of San Servolo. Upon reaching the San Marco Basin, between the Lido of Venice and Sant'Elena, the tornado struck the 400-ton motor vessel Aquileia (causing one injury) and only partially affected the motor vessel Altino. Shortly after, at 9:36 PM, motorboat 130 of line 2, operated by ACNIL (Municipal Company of Internal and Lagoon Navigation), while docking at Sant'Elena, was fully hit by the tornado, which lifted and submerged the 22-meter-long, 22-ton vessel, resulting in 21 deaths among the approximately 50 passengers. The entire island of Sant'Elena was devastated, with uprooted trees (one of which killed a person) and damaged buildings, including the Celli shipyard and the marina. Significant damage was also sustained by the "Francesco Morosini" Naval Military School and the Pier Luigi Penzo Stadium. After sweeping through the Lido of Venice, particularly the Venice-Lido "Giovanni Nicelli" airport (with extensive damage to light aircraft) and the church of San Nicolò, the tornado reached Punta Sabbioni, uprooting trees and damaging over 50 houses. Finally, at 9:42 PM, the tornado struck the Ca' Savio campsite, where it caused 12 deaths and 141 injuries among the 300 people present.
In memory of the victims, a marble stele is placed in the Park of Remembrance on the island of Sant'Elena, a few steps from the vaporetto landing.

In the area, several adverse weather events similar to that of 1970 have been recorded. On the afternoon of June 15, 2007, a powerful tornado struck the 30,000 spectators attending the mega concert of the Heineken Jammin' Festival at San Giuliano Park in Mestre. The wind caused the collapse of the six towers of the sound system, injuring 30 people. On July 8, 2015, an F4 tornado devastated the Riviera del Brenta between Dolo, Mira, and Cazzago di Pianiga, in the province of Venice. The toll was one dead, 72 injured, over 500 houses and hundreds of cars damaged or destroyed, with an estimated damage of 150 million euros.
Other projects

Info_Box:
Formation: September 11, 1970  
Maximum wind speed: 220 km/h (140 mph) (gusts)  
Minimum pressure: 740 hPa (mbar)  
Casualties: 36 dead, over 500 injured  
Damage: $8 million (1970 USD)  
Affected areas: Padua, Venice

Whole_Text.content: Cyclostrophic wind (Cyclostrophic wind) (cyclonic rotational wind) is a very high-speed wind that takes a highly curved rotational shape in its movement around a deep low-pressure center. These winds occur in low latitudes when the centrifugal force balances with the pressure gradient force, and when the Coriolis force is almost negligible. Such winds are observed in tornadoes and hurricanes.
The Geographic and Climatic Dictionary. Dr. Ali Musa This is a stub article about climatology or meteorology that needs expansion. Please contribute to editing it.

This page is a verified version Accuracy-checked The Nemere is a dry mountain-valley wind prevailing in the eastern part of Székely Land, in the Eastern Carpathians, in the Gyergyó Basin and the Csík Basin. It forms during the winter period due to the influence of the Siberian anticyclone. It got its name from the Nemere Mountains, as it blows from the direction of the mountain. It is a strong, stormy, cold, sometimes icy wind, which can last for weeks and sweeps away people, animals, and even houses. On April 19, 1902, in Csíksomlyó, the air humidity dropped to 12% during the Nemere.

The gradient wind in meteorology refers to a wind model in which forces are in equilibrium. Local effects, such as those caused by mountains or surface friction, are not taken into account. The gradient wind is an extension of the geostrophic wind as well as the cyclostrophic wind, so the term geostrophic-cyclostrophic wind is also used. It represents the best approximation of the real wind that can still be relatively accurately predicted from weather maps and upper wind measurements.
The speed of the gradient wind depends on the path imposed on it.

In a cyclonic movement, the air rotates around a low-pressure area. The Coriolis force \( F_{\rm{C}} \) together with the centrifugal force \( F_{\rm{Z}} \) points away from the center, while the pressure gradient force \( F_{\rm{D}} \) points toward the center. Consequently, solving for the velocity \( v \) results in two theoretically possible solutions due to the quadratic equation. However, the negative solution requires higher wind speeds and therefore never occurs in reality. For the actual velocity, it holds that because the Coriolis force here, together with the centrifugal force, balances the pressure gradient force, the cyclonic gradient wind is slower than the geostrophic wind (subgeostrophic).

In an anticyclonic movement, the air rotates around a high-pressure area. The pressure gradient force \( F_{\rm{D}} \) together with the centrifugal force \( F_{\rm{Z}} \) points away from the center, while the Coriolis force \( F_{\rm{C}} \) points toward the center. Consequently, solving for the velocity \( v \) results in a solution. Here, there are again two theoretically possible solutions, but the negative one requires a lower velocity and therefore occurs in reality. Since the Coriolis force must balance the pressure gradient force and the centrifugal force here, the anticyclonic gradient wind is faster than the geostrophic wind (supergeostrophic). With the same pressure gradient, the wind therefore blows stronger around a high-pressure area than around a low-pressure area.

In particularly small high-pressure areas with a strong pressure gradient, the high centrifugal force causes the gradient wind to be unable to achieve a balance between the Coriolis force and the sum of centrifugal and pressure gradient forces. High-pressure areas therefore become unstable below a certain minimum radius 

Rkrit

, equivalent to a large curvature. The air can no longer flow in a fixed circular path but instead flows outward away from the high-pressure area. In the process, the high-pressure area partially dissolves until the pressure gradient is so weak that a stable path can be reached again. The critical curvature 

κkrit

follows from the quadratic equation for solving the force balance of the anticyclonic gradient wind. For the velocity, there is only a real solution as long as the value under the square root does not become negative. For the anticyclonic gradient wind, it states that because the pressure gradient 

∂p/∂n

is always negative, negative values can occur under the square root. The minimum radius 

Rkrit

at which the term under the square root is just not negative is reached when solving for 

Rkrit

yields. For the critical curvature 

κkrit

, it follows that because the Coriolis parameter increases with increasing geographic latitude, larger curvatures and thus smaller highs are possible toward the poles. The wind speeds around a high-pressure area cannot become arbitrarily large due to this limitation of the pressure gradient force. Very strong winds can therefore only occur around low-pressure areas.
