Whole_Text.content: For articles with the same name, see Traverse (disambiguation). This article is a stub related to meteorology or climatology. The traverse is a west or northwest wind in the Jura, the Massif Central, the Alps, and the Lyon region. It is called ploudzaou in Cantal, high traverse in the southern Massif Central (where low traverse corresponds to a southwest wind). It is moderate to strong, generally blowing in gusts. Humid and warm in summer, with thunderstorms; cold in spring and winter. Its name speaks for itself; this wind crosses the country from west to east.
On other Wikimedia projects:

"It is a wind that descends from the valley of Menaggio, crosses the lake, and ends its course against the mountain. It arrives suddenly and in a few minutes unleashes havoc." (Aldo Ravasio, caretaker of the Bellano Sailing Club, July 25, 2005) The Menaggino is a stormy and impetuous wind of Lake Como that takes its name from the locality of Menaggio. It represents a rare occurrence: sometimes it does not appear for years, other times it occurs multiple times in the same year, during the summer or even in late spring.

It arrives from the west accompanying the storm disturbances coming from the Ascona-Lugano-Valsolda-Porlezza direction and reaching Lake Como through the Val Menaggio, which emerges from Switzerland onto the lake at Menaggio. The disturbance moves at a speed of about 20 km/h.

What happened in Bellano on Saturday, June 25? Around 2:00 PM, shortly after the start of the first regatta, a storm broke out: the Menaggino, a wind particularly feared by the people of Bellano, formed within a few minutes and strengthened to 50-60 knots, followed by a heavy hailstorm. No vessel was spared from the sudden storm: all the catamarans capsized with their crews clinging somehow to the hulls, the dinghies struggling, filled with water, searching for any missing persons; the firefighters were promptly alerted with all their available resources (including a helicopter), and all the emergency response forces in the lake area and the Dervio clubs assisted the CVB members in rescuing and securing all the crews. In the end, there was a lot of fear, some damage to sails and hulls, but no serious harm to people, all of whom were rescued.

Excerpt from the 2005 Bellanasco Cup report [1] Upon reaching Lake Como, blocked by the Grigne massif, the Menaggino fans out, channeling longitudinally along the water's surface with powerful gusts (50-60 knots) that raise short and irregular waves, 1-1.5 meters high (phase lasting 20-25 minutes), often followed by hail (2-5 minutes) and a violent downpour (15-30 minutes), during which the wind's strength diminishes and ceases due to the water column. The Menaggino always causes the inevitable capsizing of all sailing boats, from the first gusts, within a radius of about ten kilometers from Menaggio (essentially the water surface facing Menaggio, Varenna, Bellano, and more generally affecting navigation between Lierna – where, as well as in the locality of Fiumelatte, the Menaggino undergoes a clockwise rotation of almost 180° that makes it turn back – to the south, up to Dervio, to the north). In its initial phase, the wind's strength is such that it can even overturn motorized dinghies that, with little weight at the bow, keep their bow into the wind. The water surface ceases to be agitated as soon as the downpour begins, and overall the bad weather lasts just under an hour. The area of Lake Como north of Menaggio is affected by wind from the north and bad weather resulting from the Menaggino to a greater extent than the area to the south (Bellagio area), which is affected by wind from the south, where the bad weather disperses into the two branches – mainly into the Lecco branch and only to a limited extent into the Como branch – and quickly diminishes in intensity as it moves away from the point where the Menaggino appeared on the water's surface.

The expert navigators of Lake Como, especially the sailors, are accustomed to keeping an eye on the development of weather events occurring in the hinterland of Menaggio. From the moment a storm disturbance affecting the Val Menaggio in a west-east direction becomes visible from the lake, it takes about 10-15-20 minutes before it respectively reaches Varenna, Bellano, and Dervio, giving sailors the opportunity to prepare for the event. For sailboats near a landing (within 10-15 minutes), it is customary to head to shore and be hauled out, lowering the sails and storing them safely. For sailboats in the middle of the lake, it is advisable to escape the Menaggino as much as possible, moving away from Menaggio by taking advantage of the tailwind, traveling with it until the disturbance loses intensity and eventually passes the boat. However, if it is foreseeable that the force of the Menaggino will reach the vessel and cause it to capsize, it is best to remain in the center of the lake (away from the shores) and favor a 180° capsize (a 90° capsize, with the consequent sail effect of the hull, would cause a faster drift of the boat): the sail will produce an anchor effect reducing the drift, and at the same time, the overturned hull of the vessel will provide protection to the crew from any hail.

Whole_Text.header: The dates on which the Menaggino manifested itself
Whole_Text.content: June 25, 2005: It originated from a disturbance with winds of 50-60 knots that hit Ascona at 2:00 PM and Menaggio at 3:00 PM, while the annual Bellanasco Cup was taking place between Bellano and Dervio. 32 capsized catamarans in addition to countless smaller class boats, over 70 people in the water, torn sails, broken shrouds, boats adrift and then stranded on the shores of Dervio and Dorio. The recovery of the boats was completed at 8:00 PM. A seaplane was forced to make an emergency landing. Seven ambulances, one helicopter, firefighters, and civil protection intervened. "It was one of the worst afternoons in recent years. Fortunately, we managed to bring everyone to safety." (Giuseppe Ortelli, President of the Bellano Sailing Club) Considering the meteorological data of the day, the Menaggino was preceded by a stormy disturbance passing from Lugano-Massagno around 1:30 PM with winds at 23 miles; by 1:50 PM, the wind in Lugano had already returned to a speed of 3 knots, with only the strongest gusts remaining at 23 knots; from 2:50 PM onwards (and for at least an hour), the wind in Lugano dropped, resulting in absolute calm.
In Roman mythology, Africa is the personification of the southwest wind. The African continent is named after it, as it is south of Italy.
Each one is unique, some are with dust and smoke.
Patagon – the local name for very cold gusts of westerly wind, blowing in the southern part of Chile and bringing heavy precipitation, mainly snow, on the western slope of the Patagonian Andes.

Antibaric wind is the uniform horizontal movement of air without friction. In this case, the bar gradient (Cg) is in the same direction as the horizontal component of the deflecting force (A), and both are balanced by the centripetal force (C).[1]

Tehuano is a north to northeast wind that periodically blows over the Isthmus of Tehuantepec in southern Mexico. The wind is stronger than the trade winds that normally blow here. Among other things, it leads to increased upwelling along the coast, bringing cold, nutrient-rich water in the Gulf of Tehuantepec on the Pacific coast. Tehuano is created by a wave of cooler, drier air from the North American continent. Such waves are more common in winter but can occur at other times of the year as well. This air is heavier than the tropical air mass normally found in the area, thus creating a strong pressure gradient that generates the wind. The wind is further intensified as it is channeled through the Chivela Pass between the Bay of Campeche and the Pacific coast. The same conditions are the cause of the Papagayo wind off the coast of Costa Rica and Panama further south.

The Krivec is a cold wind blowing from the northeastern and eastern parts of the Pannonian Plain. The Krivec occurs in the winter period during the stable East European polar anticyclone. This wind can last for several weeks. It also blows in northeastern Slovenia. This geography article is a stub. Help Wikipedia by expanding it.
Kåra is primarily a nautical term meaning "to blow gently." A kåre is a breeze or shiver. A common usage is the expression "Cold shivers run down the spine."

In general, the name "vendaval" is given to any strong wind that blows from the sea, such as the southwest wind experienced on the coasts of Spain, which is quite strong in winter. The winds that were used to return from the Indies, ranging from the south to the northwest, were also called "vendavales." It is also the name given to the west wind that prevails on the coasts of Cumaná and Caracas, up to Nicaragua, from July to December.
Six Benevolent Winds is a fictional character created by Terry Pratchett.

Six Beneficent Winds comes from the Counterweight Continent and works as a tax collector for the emperor. He appears in Interesting Times. Six Beneficent Winds is held there as a hostage by Cohen the Barbarian and the Silver Horde.

Article_Name: Viento de Chanduy, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Chanduy Wind refers to the winds that occur from the south of the province of Santa Elena towards the southeast of the province of Guayas. It is called this way due to the local assumption of the inhabitants of Guayaquil about its origin from the Chanduy area. It originates from sea winds coming from the Pacific Ocean that collide with the Chanduy or Ánimas hill and are directed towards Guayaquil. The inhabitants of Guayaquil referred to the breeze coming from northwest to southeast, specifically in the afternoon, from 4:00 PM, as the Chanduy Wind.

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub concerning meteorology or climatology. The Lombarde is a wind from the northeast to southeast sector that blows over the border ridges of the Alps. It mainly blows in Ubaye, on the Queyras, and in Maurienne. It can bring very heavy precipitation to the ridges because it is associated with an easterly return linked to bad weather over the Mediterranean Sea. The precipitation mainly occurs north of the Iseran Pass, near Abriès, and in the upper Maurienne between Modane and the Mont-Cenis Pass.
The Lombarde can be caused by the advection of continental polar air by a northeast flow or by the advection of warm and humid Mediterranean air.

On the ground, there is a depression over Western Europe accompanied by a depression over the Gulf of Lion or the Gulf of Genoa. An anticyclone is based over Central or Eastern Europe. According to Buys-Ballot's law, the surface flow will be from the south. At altitude, there is a deep trough extending from Great Britain to the Mediterranean Sea. Precipitation is generally light to moderate, and its intensity is linked to the configuration of the trough.

An anticyclone extends between Great Britain and Eastern Europe. A low-pressure area is more or less centered on the Gulf of Genoa. Similarly, at altitude, there is a trough over the Gulf of Lion accompanied by a cold drop. According to Buys-Ballot's law, an east to northeast flow will blow north of the Alps, which will be blocked by the Alps. As a result of the potential vorticity conservation theorem, a dynamic depression will form over the Gulf of Genoa, which will generate an easterly return over the Alps. Precipitation can be abundant on the ridge line. The cloud can thus be likened to a foehn wall that releases its precipitation on the ridge line. Downstream (to the west), precipitation will be less or nonexistent due to the foehn effect. A textbook case occurred on February 29, 2016. Guillaume Séchet had forecast bad weather across the entire southeast of France with burle, mistral, and lombarde on the Alpine border chain. A moderate mistral was blowing over Marseille, and the weather was clear. However, it was raining in Nice. The same was true in Cuneo. A deluge of snow indeed fell on the Queyras on February 29.

On Holy Saturday, April 5, 1969, a strong southeast flow was blowing over the region. Temperatures were still very cold, with lows ranging between −10°C and −12°C. A Lombard storm had blown all morning on April 5, 1969, over Mont-Cenis, and snow began to fall there from 12:00. Snowfall started at 7:00 PM in Bonneval-sur-Arc and at 8:00 PM in Bessans. These snowfalls ceased on Easter Sunday. Substantial rain fell between Turin and Susa, where 50 mm to 60 mm of rain was recorded. In the village of Montcenis, 1.8 m of snow fell. On the western slope, precipitation decreased very quickly moving westward. Lanslevillard received 70 cm of snow, Lanslebourg 50 cm, and only 12 cm fell in Termignon. Val-d'Isère received 90 cm of snow, while Bourg-Saint-Maurice experienced a foehn effect and no precipitation occurred. The snow in Maurienne had an unusual structure. It was composed of well-formed crystals that tended to "flow" (graupel?) and was therefore not very prone to avalanches. However, an avalanche struck the village of Bonneval-sur-Arc and damaged a few houses. A resident attempted to jump from the balcony of his chalet into the 3-meter-high avalanche mass and found himself stuck in the snow, requiring the help of neighbors to extricate him from the predicament. On Easter Sunday, the entire southern half of France was subjected to a southeast flow due to a depression centered south of the Gulf of Lion.

The Queyras is well sheltered from Atlantic disturbances as it is located on the leeward side of the Pelvoux massif. However, in the event of an easterly return locally called "lombarde," precipitation can be heavy near the border chain.  
Following a severe "lombarde" episode, 2 to 3 meters of snow can fall in a few days, which results in villages being blocked as it becomes impossible to clear the roads due to the ongoing deluge. After the episode ends, the landscape is of magical beauty with a thick blanket of snow under an azure blue sky. For example, 20 centimeters of snow fell per hour on December 16, 2008.  
Severe floods occurred in the Queyras from June 12 to 16, 1957, during an easterly return. A total of 302 mm of rain fell during this period. The heavy rains affected the entire border chain from Tinée to Isère. The easterly return regime is different from the "Lombarde" regime, with significant precipitation being confined to the border chain and not exceeding the left bank of the Durance.

A century ago, the phenomena of "retours d'est" and "lombarde" were little known. Thus, P. Jousset imprudently stated that: "It is the winds from the west, southwest, and south that contribute the most to rainfall in the Alps; the east wind only brings dry clouds, depleted by a prolonged journey over the continent: the sea is too far away." This statement may be partially true for the Northern Alps (see above) but is incorrect regarding the Maritime Alps.

For homonymous articles, see Wind (homonymy). The Wind, in Switzerland and France, is a southwesterly to westerly wind blowing over the Lake Geneva region in all seasons. It is sometimes called the Sudois. A summer variant of this phenomenon is the White Wind.

The wind blows when a depression moves from the British Isles to northern Europe while an anticyclone affects the Mediterranean, a fairly common occurrence, making it one of the most common winds in the region. Due to the configuration of the lake and the terrain that channels the airflow, it reaches between 35 and 70 km/h and can blow in any season. On the Upper Lake, at its eastern end, the Alpine peaks block its exit and deflect it, producing a vortex. The winds then rotate clockwise to return westward towards the mouth of the Rhône.

A weaker summer variant is called the White Wind. It mainly affects the Petit-Lac (western part), sometimes the Grand-Lac, but rarely further. The winds on the rest of the lake are generally null to southeast, a situation called Vaudron[1]. It usually develops in the afternoon with daytime warming[1].

The Wind rises when the depression passes relatively close to the north of Switzerland. Bringing a supply of mild and humid air from the Mediterranean, the Wind is therefore associated with rainy weather in Geneva and the Jura. In summer, as the cold front of the depression passes, it will be accompanied by thunderstorms and strong gusts. In winter, it is more associated with sustained rain or snow with gusts that can exceed 100 km/h. The white Wind variant occurs when Switzerland is closer to the Mediterranean anticyclone. It is linked to a more pronounced local summer warming around the Petit-Lac than in the rest of the region and sunny weather. It causes small waves and makes the leaves move.

Convective storms, also known as convective thunderstorms, are a set of phenomena associated with the occurrence of convective clouds of the cumulonimbus type. The set of phenomena includes wind gusts, intense rain, hail, lightning, etc. The meteorological explanatory and terminological dictionary defines "severe storms" as convective storms of "very strong intensity" that meet at least one of the following criteria: occurrence of a tornado, occurrence of hail with a diameter greater than 2 cm, occurrence of destructive winds exceeding a speed of 25 m·s−1. Sometimes the term thunderstorm is used as a synonym for a convective storm, but it is reserved for electrical, optical, and acoustic phenomena associated with convective storms. Although convective storms and thunderstorms are closely related, they are not the same phenomenon.
The most common classification of storms is based on their structure. The type of storm depends on instability and wind shear. Three basic types are distinguished:

The thunderstorm of August 2010 was a hurricane-strength storm that hit Estonia on the evening of August 8, 2010. According to radar data, the storm entered Estonia across the southern border at the Võru, Valga, and Viljandi county border section at around 6:30 PM. At the Suur Munamägi observation tower, the storm's arrival from the south-southwest direction as a massive cloud formation was observable at around 6:15 PM. This was followed by heavy rain, hail, storm winds, and lightning. The strongest storm wind was recorded in Väike-Maarja between 7:00 PM and 8:00 PM, reaching 36.5 m/s. It was likely a relatively rare type of thunderstorm known as a derecho.
Wind speed (m/s)[1] Väike-Maarja 36.5 Tooma 31.9 Tõravere (Tartu) 26.0 Kunda 25.6 Jõgeva 23.5 Võru 23.4

Approximately 40,000 – 60,000 customers of Eesti Energia were left without electricity. In RMK forests, storm winds caused severe damage to about 670 hectares, with nearly 200,000 m³ of forest requiring emergency logging. The forests of Lääne-Virumaa were the most severely affected, with about 430 hectares of forest requiring clear-cutting. For comparison, in Võrumaa, 58 hectares, in Jõgevamaa, 57 hectares, and in Tartumaa, 46 hectares of forest were subject to clear-cutting. By August 17, 2010, storm damages amounting to approximately 30 million kroons had been reported according to the Ministry of the Interior. Of this, about 15 million kroons accounted for Lääne-Viru County and 8 million for the Väike-Maarja area.

Whole_Text.header: The thunderstorm in Latvia on July 16, 2009
Whole_Text.content: The thunderstorm on July 16, 2009, in Latvia was one of the strongest thunderstorms that struck the territory of Latvia in 2009.

Already from the early morning, the LVĢMA warned that during the day in Riga, very heavy rain and thunderstorms were expected. July 16 was a hot day. On average, the air temperature in Latvia ranged from +22 to +27 degrees. In Riga, the air temperature reached +25.1 degrees, but in Saldus even +27.0 degrees. It was very humid weather with high relative air humidity. Starting from the south, a cold atmospheric front crossed Latvia. When the hot and humid air met a cooler air mass, significant cumulonimbus rain clouds formed, bringing with them intense rain, locally heavy, thunderstorms, and hail. In some places, strong wind gusts were also observed. The first precipitation points began to form around 11:30 AM in the vicinity of Dobele, moving in an E direction, rapidly gaining strength, and by 2:00 PM, two active thunderstorm fronts had already formed. One stretched from Tērvete in the SW direction to the western regions of Lithuania, while the other was located in the vicinity of Baldone and Iecava. At the same time, to the N of Riga, near Tukums, by Smārde, a third thunderstorm zone actively began to form, which started moving in an E direction. At 3:00 PM, the first two thunderstorm zones merged and became increasingly stronger, covering the area from Lielvārde to Bauska and further to Šiauliai, while the next thunderstorm zone reached Riga from the west, passing over Jūrmala. Around 4:30 PM, all the strong precipitation zones had merged into one large zone, stretching from NE Vidzeme to the central regions of Lithuania. This zone continued its movement in an E, SE direction, bringing more or less heavy rain to the central regions of Latvia, as well as throughout Zemgale and partially also to the S and E of Vidzeme, as well as the W regions of Latgale, but less heavy rain fell throughout Latgale. Around 6:00 PM, another thunderstorm zone formed and moved across the central regions of Latvia, but it was not as strong and brought only a small thunderstorm and light rain to Riga, bringing heavier precipitation to the vicinity of Jelgava and further moving in a S, SE direction, entering Lithuanian territory, bypassing Bauska.

A thunderstorm with heavy rain and gusty winds was observed in the central regions of Latvia — around Riga, especially to the east and southeast of the capital, Ikšķile, Baldone, as well as the central part of Zemgale — particularly Bauska, Bārbele, and Skaistkalne.

The powerful thunderstorm reached Riga shortly after 3:00 PM, with gusty winds reaching 22 m/s, very heavy and intense rainfall, and lightning. In many places, strong wind gusts broke trees and individual branches, which fell onto tram and trolleybus wires as well as cars parked under trees. In some areas, shop signs and construction scaffolding were damaged, and temporary traffic light malfunctions were reported. Within an hour, the air temperature dropped from +26 to +18 degrees. After the heavy rain, water puddles were visible in the basement restroom areas of the Saeima building, while on the second floor near the Saeima session hall, water seeped through the glass ceilings. Meanwhile, a burst drainage pipe at the eight-story State Revenue Service (SRS) building in Riga, at 1 Jeruzalemes Street, flooded the fourth floor, which housed the Strategic Development Department led by Vladimir Vaškevič and the SRS Personnel Department archive. A weaker thunderstorm with light rain was also observed in Riga shortly after 7:00 PM.

In the center of Riga, 33 mm of precipitation fell within an hour, causing an overload of rainwater collectors and significant accumulation of rainwater in the central part of Riga. Not only the lower streets, which usually form deep puddles after heavy rain, but also a large part of the central streets were flooded. In some places, the water level reached up to half a meter in depth. As a result of the heavy downpour, sewer covers were washed away in some parts of the city, such as at the intersections of Ģertrūdes Street and Valmieras Street, as well as Bauskas Street and Ziepniekkalna Street. During the heavy rain, protective barriers at construction sites were washed away in some places. Rainwater flowed into the basements and ground floors of buildings. Significant material damage was caused by rainwater entering basement stores, where goods were damaged and people's safety was endangered. Perhaps the most serious incident occurred on Tērbatas Street, in a shoe store, where water quickly flooded the store premises located in the basement, and a woman who had remained in the store was rescued by passersby. To address the consequences of the rain and wind in Riga, operational work was carried out by both street and traffic light maintenance companies. To clear the roads of water as quickly as possible, street maintenance companies performed additional water pumping in critical areas and cleaned rainwater drainage points of debris caused by the downpour. Roads were cleared of fallen tree branches. As a result of the rain and strong wind, a large tree branch fell onto the roadway on Krišjāņa Valdemāra Street near the Latvian National Theatre, causing traffic flow on Krišjāņa Valdemāra Street to be hindered. According to information from the Riga City Council Traffic Department's Traffic Management Center, traffic was most severely disrupted in Riga at the intersections of Krišjāņa Barona Street, Audēju Street, and Aspazijas Boulevard, as well as at the intersection of Matīsa Street and Tērbatas Street. Traffic was also hindered on Pētersalas Street, Krasta Street, Juglas Street under the Brīvības Street overpass, and elsewhere in the Vidzeme and Latgale suburbs. The movement of trams on routes 6 and 11 was disrupted because a high water level had accumulated on the tracks, preventing the trams from continuing their journey. Eyewitness accounts and photographs later published in photoblogs showed that on Matīsa Street, water puddles had formed so large that cars had to stop and turn around, while bicycles were submerged up to their wheels. The fire station on Matīsa Street was also reportedly flooded. In the western and northern neighborhoods of Riga, the rainfall was not as intense and prolonged as in the central part of the capital and the eastern neighborhoods of the city. For example, only 13 mm of precipitation was recorded at Riga Airport.

In Bauska, the strong thunderstorm began shortly after 2:00 PM and, with a brief pause, the rain continued until 6:00 PM. There was very heavy and intense rain accompanied by strong wind gusts that broke trees and their branches.

Info_Box:
Location: Central regions of Latvia, Zemgale  
Date: July 16, 2009, 11:30-19:00 (EEST (UTC +3))  
Thunderstorm: Moderately strong  
Precipitation: Heavy, very intense in some places. Riga 33 mm.  
Wind: Strong wind gusts. Riga 22 m/s.  
Other: Floods in Riga, Bauska, etc.  
Fatalities: None  
Injured: Unknown

Whole_Text.content: The thunderstorm on July 19, 2009, in Latvia was one of the strongest thunderstorms in Latvia in 2009, caused by the cold atmospheric front of a cyclone moving across Latvian territory in a NNE direction, accompanied by moderate lightning, heavy rainfall, and storm-force wind gusts. This was the strongest rainfall of the summer of 2009, according to information from the Latvian Environment, Geology, and Meteorology Agency, reported by the news agency BNS, and on this day, the highest air temperature was also recorded, reaching +30.7 °C in Jelgava.

The day of July 19, 2009, began very warm. The previous night, the air temperature in Latvia averaged around +18 degrees. Before the cold atmospheric front, the weather in many parts of Latvia was very hot and humid, with air temperatures close to +30 degrees, although it was quite windy. The highest air temperature among meteorological observation stations was recorded in Jelgava at +30.7°C and in Riga at +30.4°C. Already during the night, a cyclone approaching the Kurzeme coast brought very heavy rainfall to the Kurzeme coast, and the first heavy precipitation reached Liepāja and the southern coast of Kurzeme on July 18 at 11:00 PM. It moved northward and brought heavy rain to the entire Kurzeme coast, including Ventspils, where thunder rumbled and it rained frequently and heavily. During the night, 42 mm of rain fell in Liepāja, and 25 mm in Pāvilosta. Around 6 AM, a moderate and irregular precipitation zone approached Latvia from the south, stretching across the entire northern territory of Lithuania. This precipitation zone brought heavy rain to certain areas throughout Kurzeme, especially the southern part of Kurzeme, as well as the Baltic Sea coast and the western coast of the Gulf of Riga. The precipitation zone reached Riga around 10 AM, but it had already lost strength, so only moderate and short-term rain was observed in Riga and its surroundings. This precipitation zone also brought rain to the southeastern part of Zemgale. Between 1:00 PM and 5:00 PM, it caused short-term downpours and moderate thunderstorms in many parts of Latgale. However, as the sun rose, the skies cleared over most of Latvia, and the air quickly began to warm, creating favorable conditions for the development of strong thunderstorms ahead of the cold atmospheric front. The second, strong precipitation zone first reached the southern regions of Kurzeme, where around 1:00 PM, a very heavy downpour occurred in Liepāja, flooding many city streets. Continuing to develop rapidly, the precipitation zone moved in a north-northeast direction and by 5:00 PM had already reached Talsi and was rapidly approaching Zemgale from Lithuania. Around 6:00 PM, the thunderstorm zone reached Riga and the southern regions of Latgale. As observed on the Doppler-type meteorological radar of the Latvian Environment, Geology, and Meteorology Center (LVĢMA), after 6:00 PM, this thunderstorm front stretched across almost the entire territory of Latvia, from Daugavpils to Kolka. Continuing its movement in a northeast direction, it left Latvia's territory towards Estonia and Russia shortly after 9:00 PM. Behind the front, widespread small rain clouds formed, which brought light rain to the now cooler territory of Latvia, continuing in some places until 11:30 PM. Later, separate precipitation zones with fairly heavy rain also formed in some parts of Latgale and Zemgale, but no thunderstorms or significant wind gusts were observed in these areas anymore.

In Riga, the day was very hot, humid, and clear with a gusty southern wind. Around 5:00 PM, small cumulus clouds began to appear, and by approximately 5:15 PM, dark cumulonimbus rain clouds appeared on the southern horizon, rapidly approaching. The strong wind began to subside, and a relative calm set in. By around 5:30 PM, the storm front had already reached Riga, and 10 minutes later, a very strong and gusty wind suddenly began, bending trees and carrying small branches and leaves through the air. The wind speed in the center of Riga reached 22 m/s, while at Riga Airport, strong wind gusts of 16 m/s were recorded. The air temperature dropped from +30 to +25 degrees within 5 minutes. At 5:50 PM, the strong wind gusts were suddenly joined by a very heavy downpour with strong hail and intense thunder. The heavy rain lasted for about 15 minutes, during which the wind gradually began to subside. When the downpour ceased, light rain, accompanied by occasional thunder, continued for about half an hour. After the storm began, the air temperature dropped rapidly. Within an hour, the air cooled from +30 to +19 degrees.

A thunderstorm in many parts of Latvia brought heavy, in some places very heavy, rainfall, with a total of 70 mm in Kolka (within 12 hours), 65 mm in Liepāja, 59 mm in Pāvilosta, 34 mm in Stende, 31 mm in Mērsrags, 25 mm in Rucava, and in Riga, although it rained very heavily, it was for a short time, and the total rainfall was only 9 mm. Due to the cyclone, it rained heavily all day in Kurzeme, and the amount of rainfall in Liepāja almost reached the monthly norm. It was reported that the total rainfall at the ornithological station of the Pape Nature Park was 55 mm. Wind gusts in many places reached storm strength, breaking trees, large tree branches, and in some places completely or partially tearing off roofs of houses and causing other, smaller damages. Wind gusts in Rucava reached 26 m/s, in Saldus 23 m/s, in the center of Riga 22 m/s, while the meteorological observation station at Riga Airport recorded 16 m/s. However, in some places, the wind was likely slightly stronger (especially in parts of eastern Kurzeme and western Zemgale). As a result of the strong wind gusts, approximately 20,000 customers of the Latvian energy supply company "Latvenergo" were without electricity in the evening. The strong wind and thunderstorm left about 1,500 transformer substations across Latvia without power in the afternoon. Although power supply damages were recorded throughout Latvia, the strong wind caused the most damage in the areas of Saldus, Tukums, Talsi, Daugavpils, and Jelgava. In Riga, the strong wind and thunderstorm did not cause significant power supply disruptions. There were also observed disruptions in mobile phone and internet services. As informed by Andris Siksnis, head of the External Communications Department of "Latvenergo," the next day, approximately 3,000 customers were still without power. The damages were repaired the fastest in the Western region, while in the Central region of Latvia — Riga district, Ogre district, and in the Southern region — Jelgava, Bauska, Dobele, Tukums, Talsi districts, and Engure parish, they were repaired later due to the larger extent of the damages. At the beginning of the thunderstorm, wind gusts in Riga carried not only street litter and flower vendors' buckets but also advertising posters and even temporary road signs in some places. In Riga, on Mūkusalas Street, in the section between the Railway Bridge and the Island Bridge, the wind broke a tree, disrupting trolleybus and bus traffic. Meanwhile, due to a large puddle, cars could pass this area with great difficulty. On Valmieras Street, the metal roof of a house was completely torn off and fell onto the street. In Riga's neighborhoods, trees and tree branches were broken. The heavy rain flooded certain street sections and lower areas in many places, but the rain was not as prolonged as during the thunderstorm on July 16, so prolonged flooding did not occur. Due to the thunderstorm, rescuers received ten times more calls than on a regular working day. In total, 124 calls were received, and State Fire and Rescue Service (VUGD) employees participated in 104 rescue operations. Most calls due to wind-broken trees and torn-off roofs were in Riga and the Riga region.

Injured: Unknown

Whole_Text.content: The thunderstorm on July 18, 2010, in Latvia was one of the strongest thunderstorms to hit the territory of Latvia in 2010. On the night of July 18, a low-pressure trough with a very active occlusion front approached the western regions of Latvia, bringing heavy precipitation (63% of the monthly norm fell in Skulte and Dobele, while almost 60% fell in Riga), thunderstorms, and sharp wind gusts during the thunderstorm. During the day, the occlusion front continued to move eastward. Behind the front, the air temperature dropped sharply: in Bauska and Zīlāni by 10 degrees within an hour, in Skrīveri and Zosēni by 9, in Jelgava by 8, and in Riga by 7 degrees.

Other: Flooding in Riga  
Fatalities: None

Whole_Text.content: The thunderstorms in Latvia on June 11, 2011, were a series of strong thunderstorms that affected large areas of Latvia. In some places, they brought very heavy rain, storm-force wind gusts, and significant hail. In the evening, the wind uprooted several trees in Olaine, and strong wind gusts during the afternoon thunderstorms were also observed in parts of Riga—on the right bank of the city, the wind caused damage in Pļavnieki. Reports of hail were received from all regions, including significant hail in the areas of Kuldīga, Saldus, Ventspils, and Sigulda, and hail was also observed in Riga. The heaviest and most widespread rainfalls affected the Kuldīga and Saldus districts, according to meteorological radar data from the Latvian Environment, Geology, and Meteorology Center. Rain and thunderstorms continued in the evening in some parts of Kurzeme and Vidzeme, as well as in the Daugavpils area. The last strong thunderstorm, which moved across the Daugavpils district, left Latvian territory in a southwesterly direction shortly after 1:00 a.m. on June 12. Due to the thunderstorms, several thousand "Latvenergo" customers experienced temporary power outages, according to the power outage map on the company's website. Information at 11:50 p.m. indicated that emergency outages were registered in the areas of 224 transformer points affecting 2,342 customers, with the highest number recorded in the Daugavpils district (880), Krāslava district (745), Līgatne district (294), as well as in the districts of Aglona, Mazsalaca, Ludza, Dobele, Jelgava, and Valka, with the number of outages being 75, 45, 38, 35, 31, and 30, respectively.

Whole_Text.content: The Sylvi storm (also known as the Sylvi Day storm) was a thunderstorm that struck Southern and Western Finland on Sunday, August 8, 2010. It was the fourth and final storm within ten days at the turn of July and August that raged in Finland. The damages caused by the Asta, Veera, Lahja, and Sylvi storms totaled 81.5 million euros. Sylvi storm's share of the damages was the second largest, amounting to 15.1 million euros. The storm claimed one fatality. The Sylvi storm was a powerful thunderstorm front that developed in the Baltics and arrived at the Gulf of Finland coast as a 100-kilometer-wide MCS system, advancing deep into the inland. The Finnish Meteorological Institute warned authorities about the approaching storm with a special DANGER bulletin, but it was ignored across the country. In addition to severe thunderstorms and wind gusts, the storm involved strong downbursts. The Sylvi storm toppled trees and tore off building roofs across wide areas in Uusimaa, Kymenlaakso, Häme, South Savo, Pirkanmaa, Satakunta, and Ostrobothnia. Additionally, power outages affected thousands of households. The downbursts caused the most destruction in Pori. At the Kirjurinluoto arena, the Sonisphere festival with over 40,000 attendees was underway when the downburst struck the concert venue. About 40 people sustained injuries of varying degrees, and one of the injured later died in the hospital.

The thunderstorms in Latvia on August 8, 2010, were a series of storms that caused significant damage to many Latvian cities, particularly Madona, Preiļi, and Daugavpils. The first storm in the early morning of August 8 (from 05:00 to 09:30) moved from Lithuania in a northwest direction, affecting large areas in Kurzeme, bringing heavy thunderstorms, intense rainfall, and gusty winds. Previously, this storm had ravaged Lithuania, resulting in the deaths of 4 people under falling trees and many others sustaining various injuries. The most severe damage in Lithuania occurred in the Kaunas, Alytus, and Varėna regions. The second storm (15:00–22:00) also moved across Kurzeme, bringing heavy rainfall throughout the region, particularly in the northern part of Kurzeme and around Liepāja. In Talsi, trees were broken, and roofs were torn off some buildings. The third and most destructive storm, between 16:00 and 19:10, came from Lithuania and moved across the easternmost parts of Zemgale, a large part of Latgale, and the central and eastern regions of Vidzeme. The storm then entered Estonia, became even stronger, and reached as far as central Finland, where 40 people were injured (2 seriously) at the heavy metal music festival "Sonisphere 2010" in the city of Pori. In Estonia, hurricane-strength wind gusts of 36.5 m/s were recorded at the Väike-Maarja meteorological station. The fourth storm, which was a combination of multiple storm zones, reached Latvia's far eastern territories from Belarus at 18:00 and, moving northward, crossed Latgale and the easternmost regions of Vidzeme, bringing heavy rain and thunderstorms. The storm system completely left Latvia's territory shortly after 1:00 at night.

Data from the Latvian Environment, Geology, and Meteorology Center indicate that several thunderstorm clouds have passed over Latvia. In the afternoon, a thunderstorm cloud moved from south to north over Latgale and the eastern part of Latvia, which, by all accounts, was the most intense. However, later at the beginning of the night, another band of clouds passed over Latvian territory closer to the Russian border. Thunderstorms also affected Kurzeme. One of the largest recorded amounts of precipitation was in Rūjiena—23 millimeters, with heavy rain also in Stende and during the first half of the night in Kolka. In Rēzekne, 16 millimeters were recorded, which is also considered heavy rain. At 6:00 PM in Alūksne, large hail was recorded. Meanwhile, the strongest recorded wind was in Rūjiena around 9:00 PM—24 meters per second (m/s). In Stende, wind speeds reached 22 m/s. Meteorologists acknowledged that the center's meteorological stations do not capture all information, as, for example, in Daugavpils, the thunderstorm bypassed the station because the observation station is located a few kilometers outside the city, where the storm was not as severe. Similarly, information about Madona is limited for meteorologists. The storm that passed over the eastern part of Latvia affected large areas from the vicinity of Daugavpils to Valmiera and Alūksne. It tore roofs off houses, uprooted or broke trees, and even damaged high-voltage power lines, causing harm to people.

The strongest thunderstorm in recent years mainly affected the eastern regions of Latvia. News agencies reported that approximately 200 trees were broken in Daugavpils, 2 cars and 5 houses were damaged, while in the Dunava parish of Jēkabpils municipality, the roof of a school, installed the previous year for 30,000 Ls, was torn off. The storm also severely affected the surroundings of Līvāni. In the Rožupe parish, roofs were torn off some buildings, masonry walls were tilted, and trees were massively broken, blocking roads. In Strenči, a basketball camp was disrupted. The storm caused the most significant damage in Madona, Daugavpils, Preiļi, Viļāni, and other places, resulting in fallen trees, roofs torn off houses, and people left without electricity. The wind was accompanied by heavy rain and hail — eyewitnesses reported that hailstones were as large as plums. Approximately 33,000 Latvenergo customers were left without electricity. The storm also damaged three observation stations of the Latvian Environment, Geology, and Meteorology Center. Due to technical problems, data from Madona and Zosēni were not received, and the Daugavpils observation station only partially operated. Therefore, there is a possibility that the strongest wind gusts were not officially recorded.

On Monday, August 9, by four in the afternoon, 29,000 Latvenergo customers were still without electricity. After the storm, electricity was restored to 10,000 households within 24 hours. According to the company, work continues under difficult conditions, as trees broken by the storm have collapsed power lines, severing wires, and trees have broken supports. The damage is in hard-to-reach areas, delaying the restoration of power supply. The most damage by the afternoon of the next day was in the Daugavpils area, where 321 transformer substations and 7,335 customers were without power. In Preiļi, approximately 4,000 users were without electricity. In Madona, 4,791 users were without power, while in Gulbene, only 151 remained affected. In the Smiltene and Valka areas, the elimination of damage caused by the natural disaster and the restoration of electricity supply continued into the next day, with 6,940 customers still waiting, and approximately 4,000 households in the Valmiera and Rūjiena areas. In total, by the afternoon of August 9, 1,661 transformer substations were without power. As Madona municipality mayor Andrejs Ceļapīters suggested, electricity in rural areas of Madona municipality might only be restored by Tuesday evening, as "Latvenergo is still unable to get out of Madona." Access to the power lines torn by trees is currently not possible. He stated that high-capacity forest harvesting equipment is being sought.

Many drivers were unable to enter or exit Madona in the direction of Gulbene because a tree had been broken by the wind right at the border sign, blocking the roadway. Within approximately 20 minutes, drivers managed to clear one lane of the road on their own, allowing traffic to resume. The entire city was filled with broken tree branches, which hindered traffic, and in some places, the wind had also torn out road signs. The wind had ripped off a large number of mailboxes. Significant damage was caused by the wind to several buildings in Madona. The Northern Oil gas station and the Beta grocery store were forced to cease operations because the wind tore off the roofs of the buildings, while at the building housing the Eva gas station, the wind uprooted a birch tree, which fell directly into the gas station store. Meanwhile, at the Madona market, the wind overturned a few market stalls, tearing off the roofs of some. Additionally, the wind partially tore off the roof of the building housing the SEB Bank Madona branch. Roofs were also torn off some apartment buildings.

Initial information about the damage caused by the storm was received from Daugavpils. Mostly, people reported trees broken by strong winds, power supply disruptions, and in Daugavpils, tram wires were torn as a result of the storm. According to residents, the storm was short-lived but managed to cause significant damage. In Daugavpils, strong wind gusts broke several hundred trees, causing serious damage, and trees that fell onto the roadway blocked car traffic in several places in the city. To restore traffic on Daugavas Street for cars entering the city from the Riga side, the emergency brigade of the municipal services department, working together with the Daugavpils brigade of the State Fire and Rescue Service, needed about an hour. Falling trees in Daugavpils also caused damage to several buildings and damaged a car in the Daugavpils district area.

A powerful storm ravaged the Rožupe, Rudzāti, and Sutri parishes of Līvāni municipality, tearing roofs off residential houses and farm buildings, uprooting century-old oaks, and bending road signs. Livestock perished, falling tree branches damaged machinery and cars, and power lines were severed. The chairman of the Līvāni municipality council, Andris Vaivods, reported that people are in despair as many have nowhere to live—roofs have been torn off houses, in some farms only a pile of boards remains from barns, and crops, orchards, and forests have been devastated. Even the oldest residents do not recall such a storm. Century-old oaks were uprooted, falling branches crushed agricultural machinery and killed livestock. Fortunately, there were no human casualties in the storm, but many endured great fear, trapped in cars. Local residents, desperate over the destroyed buildings, massively sought help from the municipal government. The Līvāni municipality also committed to helping the residents. It was promised that timber for roof reconstruction would be provided to all whose homes were destroyed by the storm. The Līvāni municipality also sought assistance at the state level, as residents in this emergency situation were literally left without a roof over their heads, said the municipal leader.
The storm has significantly damaged Preiļi as well, especially the road section from Preiļi to Aglona. A tree broken by the storm has fallen on the Vilku Tavern.

Info_Box:

Thunderstorm: Strong  
Precipitation: Heavy, very intense in some places  
Wind: Very strong gusts. Vilani 26.5 m/s  
Fatalities: None

Article_Name: Unwetter in Berlin am 14. April 1902 – Wikipedia

Whole_Text.content: The storm in Berlin on April 14, 1902, was extraordinary in terms of the amount of rainfall and the season (severe thunderstorms usually occur in midsummer). After a cloudburst, the streets of Berlin were flooded for hours; there were embankment slides and house collapses to lament. A total of 166 mm of rain fell in eleven hours; this remained the highest amount of rainfall measured in Berlin in a single day until 1959.

The meteorologist Gustav Hellmann (1854–1939) published an article in the Meteorologische Zeitschrift about this, [1] which is partially reproduced here. Hellmann analyzed "the extremely severe thunderstorm that broke out on Monday, April 14, around 3 a.m., lasted until 8:45 a.m., and was accompanied by such heavy rain as Berlin had never experienced before. (...) The rainfall began shortly after 3 a.m., was heavy until around 9 a.m., and continued with interruptions, but much weaker, until around 2 p.m. During this period of barely 11 hours, the following measurements were recorded: The differences in rainfall are greatest in the direction from W to E. At the eastern edge of the city, the amount is 10–20 mm, only 4 mm at a distance of 7 km, and east of a line running approximately in the direction of Jüterbog – Zossen – Wriezen, i.e., only 28 km east of Berlin, there was no rain at all. The area of maximum rainfall, with approximately 150–170 mm, lies in the northwestern part of the inner city and is probably no larger than half a square kilometer. But even to the west, the decrease in rainfall is significant; only 11 km west of the maximum area, in Ruhleben near Spandau, only 29 mm were measured. The differences are, of course, smallest in the direction from NNE to SSW, in which the storm progressed. (...) The course of the cloudburst in Berlin itself is more closely documented by the records of some pluviographs at the municipal pumping stations (...). (...) The rainfall seems (...) to have been most intense between 5 and 6 a.m. Shortly after 6 a.m. (noted as 6:10 to 6:16 a.m.), heavy hail also fell in part of the inner city, lasting until around 6:40 a.m. It was washed away by the streams of water that had formed on the streets to lower-lying areas and into houses, where it remained until around noon, and in some places until the next day, and had to be removed in dozens of buckets. This hail certainly contributed, through the clogging of pipes, etc., to the fact that the enormous masses of water drained more slowly and the damage caused by them, which can be estimated at many hundreds of thousands of marks, was even greater than it would have been with just rainfall. Street traffic was significantly disrupted in the morning, and even school lessons had to be canceled, which had probably never happened in Berlin before." It should be noted that the article refers to the then city area of Berlin, which, until the expansion in 1920, only included today's immediate center. A city climate study from 1990 leaves open whether similarly high amounts of rainfall as in Pankow and Wedding fell in the higher areas of Wilmersdorf-Schöneberg-Tempelhof, which were not recorded due to a lack of measuring stations. [3] Hermann Stade (1867–1932) [4] published a study on the storm, [5] in which the evening edition of the Staatsbürger-Zeitung from April 14, 1902, is quoted (noted after the scan): "Around 2 a.m. (April 14), the thunderstorm approached the imperial capital from the northeast, initially only with lightning and thunder phenomena. Around 2:30 a.m., light rain began, followed by a violent hailstorm in some places around 3 a.m. At 3:45 a.m., particularly in the southwest, west, and center, such masses of ice fell that roadways and sidewalks were covered up to 10 cm high ... Finally, at 4:30 a.m., torrential rain began, initially affecting the north in particular. Within a few minutes, almost the entire Gesundbrunnen was under water, and the distressed residents of basement rooms were often unable to save their furniture. In three cases, firefighters had to rescue children floating in beds or cradles from their dangerous situation. And now the floodwaters spread over all parts of Berlin. Although all machines at all pumping stations were put into operation, hundreds of millions of liters of water were transported to the sewage fields, and all emergency outlets discharged enormous amounts of water into the Spree, the floods gushed fountain-like from the canals onto the streets." Stade himself writes: "Many streets and squares in Berlin were subsequently flooded for 3 (8?) hours and resembled large lakes. In the lower-lying parts of the city, such as Yorckstraße, the water level exceeded 1/2 (?) meter in the morning hours of April 14, but even in the higher-lying areas of the north and northeast, the water rose to nearly 1/2 (?) meter, so that the residents there were confined to their houses for hours. In many places, the pavement was torn up, and large amounts of washed-away sand clogged the access to the drainage canals; the same problem was caused in many places by the enormous masses of hail that were carried along by the water flowing down the streets. Extensive, long-lasting floods were the result. In several cases, houses collapsed due to the undermining of their foundations, and on the Northern Railway, a dam collapse occurred, which not only led to a multi-day interruption of rail traffic but also caused nearby houses to either collapse or become so severely endangered that they had to be evacuated. Numerous lightning strikes were reported from all parts of the city, particularly from the north. In many places, the support masts of the tramway were struck by lightning, and in several cases, the power supply points burned out. This, as well as the collapse of some support masts undermined by water, caused a disruption in Berlin's tram traffic of an extent that had never been seen before; not a single tram line was able to maintain uninterrupted operation."

Since 1902, only "traditional" weather observations near the ground were conducted, making the retrospective analysis of the weather situation uncertain. "Unfortunately, during this time, the kite stations now existing in Germany were not yet operational; therefore, there is no insight into the air pressure and temperature distribution of the upper air layers, which, of course, were actually decisive for the direction of the thunderstorms' progression." Neither H. Stade's investigation nor the synoptic archive of the Weather Center provide clear conclusions about the causes of the disaster. One possible interpretation is warm air flowing in near the ground, destabilized by an upper trough. Small air pressure differences at higher altitudes may have been the reason why the thunderstorm cells moved so slowly and lingered over the city for a long time. Unusual in this context is the direction of movement from northeast to southwest mentioned by Hellmann and supported by the synoptic archive of the "Weather Center," which suggests an "easterly" or "warm air intrusion thunderstorm." This type of thunderstorm is rare (according to H. Stade's investigation, Berlin meteorologists were surprised by its development) and only occurs at quasi-stationary warm fronts that move so slowly that wave formations become possible. Stade's note that several thunderstorm cells may have been present in and over the city also points in this direction. Thunderstorms of this type are often characterized by particular intensity. Additionally, nocturnal destabilization due to radiation at the cloud tops and the enhancement of precipitation activity by the "urban effect" may have had an amplifying effect. In Berlin's climatological records, only a precipitation value of 67.4 mm is recorded for April 14, 1902, corresponding to the amount measured at 7 a.m. at the climate station then located in Kreuzberg, without considering the individual sums measured at other Berlin precipitation stations. From 1848 (the beginning of observations by the Prussian Meteorological Institute) to 1983, daily precipitation totals of 100 mm were exceeded in Berlin on only two other days. Even Reinhard Süring cites the 1902 cloudburst as a Berlin record in his meteorology textbook. The precipitation amount of 166 mm was only surpassed in Berlin's urban area on August 15/16, 1959, during the so-called Riemeisterfenn rain, when 210 mm fell within 30 hours. On June 29, 2017, a record value for 24-hour precipitation in the state of Berlin was registered with 215.8 mm at the Tegel Forestry Office (a station of the urban measurement network of the Institute of Meteorology at the Free University of Berlin). However, the highest precipitation intensity within the city area is considered to be the 123.4 mm that fell at Berlin-Tegel Airport on the evening of August 25, 2006, within just 75 minutes. Previously, the so-called Siebenschläfer storm of 1964, with 80.8 mm in 2 hours measured at Berlin-Tempelhof Airport, had held the intensity record for 42 years. In Brandenburg, the highest daily precipitation total to date was measured on June 12, 1993, with 255.8 mm in Pritzwalk, while the strongest precipitation intensity occurred on June 29, 1994, when five severe hailstorms passed through Werder (Havel), dropping 176.7 mm within just 3 1/2 hours.

"On April 14, classes had to be suspended because a torrential storm, raging from 3 to 9 in the morning, had made most paths impassable for pedestrians and vehicles, so that at the start of classes, not even a quarter of the students were present in some classes, and those who were present were so soaked that they could not have stayed in their clothes for hours without risking a cold." A school closure due to a storm has not been recorded in the annals of the gymnasium since at least 1880! The gymnasium was located at Friedrichstraße 126. "On Monday, April 14, classes had to be suspended due to a severe storm that broke over Berlin in the morning." "Classes were canceled on April 14 due to the major storm, which flooded the courtyards and cellars of the school property." The isolated nature of the thunderstorm is indicated by the measured precipitation total of the nearby Potsdam weather station, which was "only" 26.5 mm, and the observation of the pastor and writer Heinrich Wolfgang Seidel, who was serving as a vicar in the town of Boitzenburg, about 80 km to the north, and regularly wrote letters from there, which were published in book form in 1951. On April 14, 1902, the mail coach from Berlin arrived in Boitzenburg many hours late "and brought terrible news about the Berlin cloudburst. Here, it had been such a lovely, radiant spring day with warm winds and birdsong that we were completely surprised."

Together with other Panke floods in 1904 and 1905, the flood was the reason for the planning, which began in 1911, to construct the Nordgraben, which diverts excess water from the Panke into Lake Tegel.

A large part of the precipitation (station values Bellermannstraße, Scharnhorststraße) fell in the area of the lower course of the Panke. Its riverbed, canalized in Gesundbrunnen and Wedding and tightly enclosed with walls, could not contain the masses of water and washed away the foundations of the adjacent houses. In Gerichtstraße in Wedding, a house, No. 23, collapsed early in the morning. (Today's No. 23, an Art Nouveau building from 1906, is located 100 meters "inland.") On General-Pape-Straße at the border of Schöneberg and Tempelhof, sections of the tram embankment slid away. A similar landslide blocked the Northern Railway within the city area.

Article_Name: 平成27年9月関東・東北豪雨

Whole_Text.content: The September 2015 Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rainfall was a heavy rain disaster that occurred in the Kanto and Tohoku regions from September 9 to 11, 2015.

Typhoon No. 18, which occurred on September 7, made landfall in the Tokai region on September 9 and later became an extratropical cyclone over the Sea of Japan that night. Although the direct damage caused by this typhoon was not significant, warm, moist air flowed in from the Pacific Ocean due to the extratropical cyclone that had transformed from the typhoon moving northeast over the Sea of Japan. This collided with moist winds blowing from Typhoon No. 17, which was approaching the Japanese archipelago from the sea east of Japan, resulting in the continuous formation of rain clouds (linear precipitation bands) stretching north to south. This caused heavy rainfall exceeding 300 mm in 24 hours, primarily in northern Kanto and southern Tohoku, leading to large-scale damage.

On September 9, heavy rain centered in northern Kanto occurred. According to AMeDAS observation data from midnight on September 7 to 5 p.m. on September 10, 24-hour rainfall by the morning of the 10th reached 551.0 mm in Nikko City’s Ikari and 541.0 mm in Nikko City’s Imaichi, with over 300 mm observed in various locations in Tochigi Prefecture. Additionally, total rainfall during the period was 645.5 mm in Imaichi, 622.0 mm in Ikari, 561.5 mm in Tōrobu, and 523.0 mm in Kanuma, with over 400 mm observed in various locations in Tochigi Prefecture. At 12:20 a.m. on September 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for the entire Tochigi Prefecture, and at 7:45 a.m., a similar warning was issued for almost all of Ibaraki Prefecture. In these regions, maximum caution was urged against river flooding, landslides, and inundation of low-lying areas, while surrounding prefectures were also called upon to exercise strict caution.

The area of rainfall gradually shifted to the Tohoku region, and at 3:20 a.m. on September 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for Miyagi Prefecture. The special heavy rain warnings issued for each prefecture were lifted at 6 a.m. on the 11th for Tochigi Prefecture, at 8:15 a.m. the same day for Ibaraki Prefecture, and at 7:30 p.m. for Miyagi Prefecture. On September 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency named the heavy rain and the resulting disaster that struck the Kanto and Tohoku regions as the "September 2015 Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rain." Additionally, the Geospatial Information Authority of Japan set up a special page on its official website titled "September 2015 Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rain," providing information on the disaster using data such as topographic maps and aerial photographs.

On October 6, the government decided in a cabinet meeting to designate the agricultural damage caused by the disaster as a "severe disaster" under the Act on Special Financial Assistance for Severe Disasters, and to designate specific areas in Minamiaizu Town, Minamiaizu District, and Showa Village, Onuma District, in Fukushima Prefecture as "localized severe disaster areas." This decision was promulgated and enforced on October 7. As a result, the proportion of government subsidies for municipalities conducting restoration work on farmland and agricultural facilities was raised to a maximum of approximately 90%.

The heavy rain in Tochigi Prefecture and flooding in Ibaraki Prefecture were compared to Typhoon No. 4 in 1998. While Typhoon No. 4 in 1998 recorded torrential rain and over 1,000 mm of precipitation, the Kanto-Tohoku heavy rain had a total rainfall of about 600 mm, with hourly rainfall of 50–70 mm (no record-breaking short-term heavy rain information was issued during the period).

The total rainfall observed from September 7 to September 11 was 647.5 mm in Imaichi, Nikko City, Tochigi Prefecture, and 536.0 mm in Hitsupo, Marumori Town, Miyagi Prefecture, exceeding 600 mm in the Kanto region and 500 mm in the Tohoku region, resulting in heavy rain exceeding twice the average monthly rainfall for September.

According to the summary of damages as of October 18, 2017, by the Fire and Disaster Management Agency (including damages caused by Typhoon No. 18), a total of 20 deaths have been confirmed: 15 in Ibaraki Prefecture, 3 in Tochigi Prefecture, and 2 in Miyagi Prefecture. Additionally, there were 82 injured nationwide, 81 houses completely destroyed, 7,090 partially destroyed, 384 partially damaged, 2,523 flooded above floor level, 13,259 flooded below floor level, and 1,722 non-residential buildings damaged. It was also confirmed that breaches, overtopping, leaks, flooding, and damage or collapse of embankment slopes occurred in 5 rivers under national management and 80 rivers under prefectural management. According to the tally announced at 5:00 PM on September 13, evacuation orders were issued to approximately 240,000 people in 1 metropolitan area and 19 prefectures from Iwate Prefecture to Kagawa Prefecture since the 8th, and evacuation advisories were issued to approximately 3.15 million people. Even one year after the breach of the Kinugawa River embankment, 79 households and 197 people in Joso City continue to live in temporary housing provided by the prefecture or city.

In the vicinity of Joso City, Ibaraki Prefecture, on the early morning of September 10, overflow and leakage from the embankments occurred at several locations along the Kinugawa River. At 12:50 PM, one embankment in Misaka Town of the same city collapsed. As a result, a wide area of Joso City, located between the Kinugawa and Kokaigawa Rivers, was submerged, causing significant damage, including two direct fatalities, 12 disaster-related deaths, and over 40 injuries. Additionally, the Joso City Hall main building, which had just been completed in 2014 incorporating lessons from the Great East Japan Earthquake, was flooded, and more than 5,000 houses were partially or completely destroyed. In response to this incident, Joso City established a verification committee and compiled a report. 

Furthermore, at Tokyo Electric Power's Kinugawa Power Plant (Nikko City), Doyahara Power Plant (Shioya Town), and Akagawa Power Plant (Nasushiobara City), generators were submerged, and facilities were damaged, leading to a halt in power generation. Additionally, a landslide caused a transmission tower to tilt and break, cutting off power supply to the Yagan Railway Aizu Kinugawa Line, resulting in the suspension of operations on that line. Moreover, at Kinugawa Onsen in Nikko City, Tochigi Prefecture, an open-air bath of a hotel facing the Kinugawa River collapsed.

Tochigi City Riheya Elementary School and Oyama City Hanakawa Nishi Elementary School in Tochigi Prefecture announced plans to resume classes by borrowing vacant classrooms from other schools after their school buildings and gymnasiums were submerged by the flood. The second semester closing ceremony was held in hallways and music rooms as the gymnasium was under renovation and unavailable. In March 2016, the renovation of Hanakawa Nishi Elementary School's gymnasium was completed, and a restoration ceremony was held on March 9.

At Oyama Driving School, facilities and vehicles were severely damaged, with 14 out of 18 vehicles submerged, leading to a suspension of operations. However, the school resumed operations on November 11, 2015.

On the 11th, the Mogami River in Mogami Town, Mogami District, Yamagata Prefecture, overflowed. In Osaki City, Miyagi Prefecture, the embankment of the Shibui River, part of the Naruse River system, collapsed, and in Tomiya Town and Taiwa Town, Kurokawa District, the Yoshida River and its tributaries, the Zen River and Chikurin River, overflowed. In Iitate Village, Soma District, Fukushima Prefecture, 395 bags containing decontamination waste from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant accident, which had been stored in the village, were washed away due to river flooding caused by the typhoon. At least 167 of the recovered bags were found to be damaged, and it is believed that soil, grass, and other contents were lost. Additionally, the contents of two bags that were washed away as far as Haramachi Ward, Minamisoma City, were also found to have been lost.

Tobu Railway suffered damage to various lines in Tochigi Prefecture. The Tobu Nikko Line was suspended between Shinkanuma Station and Shimo-Imaichi Station due to a landslide at Shimo-Koyama Station and embankment washout between Shinkanuma Station and Kita-Kanuma Station. The Tobu Utsunomiya Line was suspended between Yatsuka Station and Nishikawada Station due to the loss of the abutment and bridge girder of the No. 2 Sugata River Overflow Bridge between these stations. The Tobu Kinugawa Line was suspended between Shimo-Imaichi Station and Shin-Fujiwara Station due to embankment washout between Shintakatoku Station and Kosagoe Station, and track ballast washout between Kosagoe Station and Kinugawa-Onsen Station. Substitute bus services and transfers to other railway lines were provided for the affected sections. Some sections of Tobu Railway were restored by September 18, and the remaining sections were fully restored by October 7.

The Kanto Railway Joso Line was flooded between Koyama Station and Sodo Station due to the breach of the Kinugawa River embankment, and the Mito-Kaido vehicle base, which serves as the operational hub, was also damaged. As a result, the entire line between Toride Station and Shimodate Station was suspended. Train operations resumed between Toride Station and Mito-Kaido Station and between Shimotsuma Station and Shimodate Station by September 18. On October 10, train operations resumed between Mito-Kaido Station and Shimotsuma Station, but the service was significantly reduced due to emergency restoration. Normal operations resumed across the entire line on November 16, including the resumption of rapid services.

The Kominato Railway Line was suspended between Kazusa-Ushiku Station and Kazusa-Nakano Station due to embankment washout and other impacts between Kazusa-Okubo Station and Yoro-Keikoku Station. Train operations resumed between Kazusa-Ushiku Station and Tsukizaki Station by September 16, but the restoration of embankments and removal of landslides took time, and operations between Tsukizaki Station and Kazusa-Nakano Station resumed on October 24 of the same year.

Info_Box:

Meteorological Cause of the Disaster: Warm and moist air from the Pacific Ocean was brought in by the high-pressure system moving eastward over the Japanese Sea, and Typhoon No. 17 approaching the Japanese archipelago from the east of the Japanese Sea caused strong winds and heavy rainfall, leading to the occurrence of flooding.  
Maximum Rainfall: 551.0 mm in Hoymu City, Nikko City, 50 kilometers away [Note 1]  
Deaths: 20 [Note 2]

Injured Persons: 82

Partially Destroyed Houses: 7,090
